<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">City in the Levant region, Western Asia</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"Bayt al-Maqdis" redirects here. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Jerusalem_(disambiguation)" title="Jerusalem (disambiguation)">Jerusalem (disambiguation)</a> and <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Bayt_al-Maqdis_(disambiguation)" title="Bayt al-Maqdis (disambiguation)">Bayt al-Maqdis (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">

</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1063604349">.mw-parser-output .navbar{display:inline;font-size:88%;font-weight:normal}.mw-parser-output .navbar-collapse{float:left;text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .navbar-boxtext{word-spacing:0}.mw-parser-output .navbar ul{display:inline-block;white-space:nowrap;line-height:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::before{margin-right:-0.125em;content:"[ "}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::after{margin-left:-0.125em;content:" ]"}.mw-parser-output .navbar li{word-spacing:-0.125em}.mw-parser-output .navbar a>span,.mw-parser-output .navbar a>abbr{text-decoration:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-mini abbr{font-variant:small-caps;border-bottom:none;text-decoration:none;cursor:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-full{font-size:114%;margin:0 7em}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-mini{font-size:114%;margin:0 4em}</style><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Jerusalem_sidebar" title="Template:Jerusalem sidebar"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Jerusalem_sidebar" title="Template talk:Jerusalem sidebar"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Jerusalem_sidebar&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Jerusalem</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/dÊ/: 'j' in 'jam'">dÊ</span><span title="/É/: 'a' in 'about'">É</span><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/uË/: 'oo' in 'goose'">uË</span><span title="'s' in 'sigh'">s</span><span title="/Él/: 'le' in 'bottle'">Él</span><span title="/É/: 'a' in 'about'">É</span><span title="'m' in 'my'">m</span></span>/</a></span></span>; <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_language" title="Hebrew language">Hebrew</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="he">×Ö°×¨×Ö¼×©Ö¸××Ö·×Ö´×</span> <small><span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:He-Jerusalem.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/84/He-Jerusalem.ogg" title="He-Jerusalem.ogg"><span title="Hebrew-language romanization"><i lang="he-Latn">YerushalÃ¡yim</i></span></a></span></span></small>; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø§ÙÙÙØ¯Ø³</span> <span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:ArAlquds.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/5d/ArAlquds.ogg" title="ArAlquds.ogg"><span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn">al-Quds</i></span></a></span></span>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11"><a href="#cite_note-11">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12"><a href="#cite_note-12">[11]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Elihay2011_13-0"><a href="#cite_note-Elihay2011-13">[12]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14"><a href="#cite_note-14">[note 2]</a></sup> is a city in <a href="/wiki/Western_Asia" title="Western Asia">Western Asia</a>. Situated on a plateau in the <a href="/wiki/Judaean_Mountains" title="Judaean Mountains">Judaean Mountains</a> between the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Dead_Sea" title="Dead Sea">Dead Sea</a>, it is one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_oldest_continuously_inhabited_cities" title="List of oldest continuously inhabited cities">oldest cities in the world</a> and is considered to be a <a href="/wiki/Holy_city" title="Holy city">holy city</a> for the three major <a href="/wiki/Abrahamic_religions" title="Abrahamic religions">Abrahamic religions</a>: <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>. Both <a href="/wiki/Israelis" title="Israelis">Israelis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Palestinians" title="Palestinians">Palestinians</a> claim Jerusalem as their <a href="/wiki/Capital_city" title="Capital city">capital</a>, as <a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">Israel</a> maintains its primary governmental institutions there and the <a href="/wiki/State_of_Palestine" title="State of Palestine">State of Palestine</a> ultimately foresees it as its seat of power. Because of this dispute, <a href="/wiki/Status_of_Jerusalem" title="Status of Jerusalem">neither claim is widely recognized internationally</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15"><a href="#cite_note-15">[note 3]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16"><a href="#cite_note-16">[13]</a></sup>
</p><p>Throughout <a href="/wiki/History_of_Jerusalem" title="History of Jerusalem">its long history</a>, Jerusalem has been destroyed at least twice, <a class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Siege_of_Jerusalem_(disambiguation)" title="Siege of Jerusalem (disambiguation)">besieged 23 times</a>, captured and recaptured 44 times, and attacked 52 times.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Moment_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-Moment-17">[14]</a></sup> The part of Jerusalem called the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/City_of_David_(historic)" title="City of David (historic)">City of David</a> shows first signs of settlement in the 4th millennium BCE, in the shape of encampments of nomadic shepherds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Greenberg_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-Greenberg-18">[15]</a></sup> During the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canaanites" title="Canaanites">Canaanite</a> period (14th century BCE), Jerusalem was named as <i>Urusalim</i> on <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">ancient Egyptian</a> tablets, probably meaning "City of <a href="/wiki/Shalim" title="Shalim">Shalem</a>" after a <a href="/wiki/Canaanite_religion" title="Canaanite religion">Canaanite deity</a>. During the <a href="/wiki/Israelites" title="Israelites">Israelite</a> period, significant construction activity in Jerusalem began in the 9th century BCE (Iron Age II), and by the 8th century BCE, the city had developed into the religious and administrative center of the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Judah" title="Kingdom of Judah">Kingdom of Judah</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[16]</a></sup> In 1538, the <a href="/wiki/Walls_of_Jerusalem" title="Walls of Jerusalem">city walls were rebuilt</a> for a last time around Jerusalem under <a href="/wiki/Suleiman_the_Magnificent" title="Suleiman the Magnificent">Suleiman the Magnificent</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>. Today those walls define the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Old_City_(Jerusalem)" title="Old City (Jerusalem)">Old City</a>, which has been traditionally divided into four-quartersâknown since the early 19th century as the <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Quarter" title="Armenian Quarter">Armenian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christian_Quarter" title="Christian Quarter">Christian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jewish_Quarter_(Jerusalem)" title="Jewish Quarter (Jerusalem)">Jewish</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Muslim_Quarter_(Jerusalem)" title="Muslim Quarter (Jerusalem)">Muslim</a> quarters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20"><a href="#cite_note-20">[17]</a></sup> The Old City became a <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a> in 1981, and is on the <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_in_Danger" title="List of World Heritage in Danger">List of World Heritage in Danger</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[18]</a></sup> Since 1860, <a href="/wiki/Expansion_of_Jerusalem_in_the_19th_century" title="Expansion of Jerusalem in the 19th century">Jerusalem has grown</a> far beyond the Old City's boundaries. In 2015, Jerusalem had a <a href="/wiki/Demographic_history_of_Jerusalem" title="Demographic history of Jerusalem">population</a> of some 850,000 residents, comprising approximately 200,000 <a href="/wiki/Jewish_secularism" title="Jewish secularism">secular Jewish</a> Israelis, 350,000 <a href="/wiki/Haredi_Judaism" title="Haredi Judaism">Haredi Jews</a> and 300,000 Palestinians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Forbes1_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-Forbes1-22">[19]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[note 4]</a></sup> In 2016, the population was 882,700, of which <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">Jews</a> comprised 536,600 (61%), <a href="/wiki/Muslims" title="Muslims">Muslims</a> 319,800 (36%), <a href="/wiki/Christians" title="Christians">Christians</a> 15,800 (2%), and 10,300 unclassified (1%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PopRel_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-PopRel-25">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tanakh" title="Tanakh">Hebrew Bible</a>, King <a href="/wiki/David" title="David">David</a> <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Jebus" title="Siege of Jebus">conquered the city</a> from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jebusite" title="Jebusite">Jebusites</a> and established it as the capital of the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Israel_(united_monarchy)" title="Kingdom of Israel (united monarchy)">United Kingdom of Israel</a>, and his son, King <a href="/wiki/Solomon" title="Solomon">Solomon</a>, commissioned the building of the <a href="/wiki/Temple_in_Jerusalem" title="Temple in Jerusalem">First Temple</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bible-david_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-bible-david-27">[note 5]</a></sup> Modern scholars argue that Jews branched out of the <a href="/wiki/Canaan" title="Canaan">Canaanite</a> peoples and culture through the development of a distinct <a href="/wiki/Monolatry" title="Monolatry">monolatrous</a>âand later <a href="/wiki/Monotheism" title="Monotheism">monotheistic</a>âreligion centered on <a href="/wiki/El_(deity)" title="El (deity)">El</a>/<a href="/wiki/Yahweh" title="Yahweh">Yahweh</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[23]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[24]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rendsberg3_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rendsberg3-30">[25]</a></sup> These foundational events, straddling the dawn of the 1st millennium BCE, assumed central symbolic <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_in_Judaism" title="Jerusalem in Judaism">importance</a> for the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jewish_people" title="Jewish people">Jewish people</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1000BCE_31-0"><a href="#cite_note-1000BCE-31">[26]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[27]</a></sup> The sobriquet of holy city (Hebrew: <span dir="rtl" lang="he">×¢××¨ ××§×××©</span>, <small>romanized:Â </small><span title="Hebrew-language romanization"><i lang="he-Latn">'Ir ha-Qodesh</i></span>) was probably attached to Jerusalem in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Post-exilic" title="Post-exilic">post-exilic</a> times.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[28]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[29]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[30]</a></sup> The holiness of <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_in_Christianity" title="Jerusalem in Christianity">Jerusalem in Christianity</a>, conserved in the <a href="/wiki/Septuagint" title="Septuagint">Greek translation of the Hebrew Bible</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36"><a href="#cite_note-36">[31]</a></sup> which Christians adopted as their own "<a href="/wiki/Old_Testament" title="Old Testament">Old Testament</a>",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[32]</a></sup> was reinforced by the <a href="/wiki/New_Testament" title="New Testament">New Testament</a> account of <a href="/wiki/Crucifixion_of_Jesus" title="Crucifixion of Jesus">Jesus's crucifixion</a> and <a href="/wiki/Resurrection_of_Jesus" title="Resurrection of Jesus">resurrection</a> there. In <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni Islam</a>, Jerusalem is the third-holiest city, after <a href="/wiki/Mecca" title="Mecca">Mecca</a> and <a href="/wiki/Medina" title="Medina">Medina</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3rd_38-0"><a href="#cite_note-3rd-38">[33]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[34]</a></sup> The city was the first <a href="/wiki/Qibla" title="Qibla">qibla</a>, the standard direction for Muslim prayers (<a href="/wiki/Salah" title="Salah">salah</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[35]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Holiest_sites_in_Islam" title="Holiest sites in Islam">in Islamic tradition</a>, <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a> made his <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Isra_and_Mi%27raj" title="Isra and Mi'raj">Night Journey</a> there in 621, ascending to heaven where he speaks to <a href="/wiki/God" title="God">God</a>, according to the <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[36]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[37]</a></sup> As a result, despite having an area of only <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1020198016">.mw-parser-output .frac{white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output .frac .num,.mw-parser-output .frac .den{font-size:80%;line-height:0;vertical-align:super}.mw-parser-output .frac .den{vertical-align:sub}.mw-parser-output .sr-only{border:0;clip:rect(0,0,0,0);height:1px;margin:-1px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;position:absolute;width:1px}</style>0.9Â km<sup>2</sup> (<span class="frac" role="math"><span class="num">3</span>â<span class="den">8</span></span>Â sqÂ mi),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[38]</a></sup> the Old City is home to many sites of seminal <a href="/wiki/Religious_significance_of_Jerusalem" title="Religious significance of Jerusalem">religious importance</a>, among them the <a href="/wiki/Temple_Mount" title="Temple Mount">Temple Mount</a> with its <a href="/wiki/Western_Wall" title="Western Wall">Western Wall</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dome_of_the_Rock" title="Dome of the Rock">Dome of the Rock</a> and <a href="/wiki/Al-Aqsa_Mosque" title="Al-Aqsa Mosque">al-Aqsa Mosque</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre" title="Church of the Holy Sepulchre">Church of the Holy Sepulchre</a>.
</p><p>Today, the <a href="/wiki/Status_of_Jerusalem" title="Status of Jerusalem">status of Jerusalem</a> remains one of the core issues in the <a href="/wiki/Israeli%E2%80%93Palestinian_conflict" title="IsraeliâPalestinian conflict">IsraeliâPalestinian conflict</a>. During the <a href="/wiki/1948_Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_War" title="1948 ArabâIsraeli War">1948 ArabâIsraeli War</a>, <a href="/wiki/West_Jerusalem" title="West Jerusalem">West Jerusalem</a> was among the areas <a href="/wiki/Battle_for_Jerusalem" title="Battle for Jerusalem">captured</a> and later annexed by Israel while <a href="/wiki/East_Jerusalem" title="East Jerusalem">East Jerusalem</a>, including the Old City, was captured and later <a href="/wiki/Jordanian_annexation_of_the_West_Bank" title="Jordanian annexation of the West Bank">annexed</a> by <a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan">Jordan</a>. Israel captured East Jerusalem from Jordan during the 1967 <a href="/wiki/Six-Day_War" title="Six-Day War">Six-Day War</a> and subsequently <a href="/wiki/Israeli_annexation_of_East_Jerusalem" title="Israeli annexation of East Jerusalem">effectively annexed</a> it into Jerusalem, together with additional surrounding territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[note 6]</a></sup> One of Israel's <a href="/wiki/Basic_Laws_of_Israel" title="Basic Laws of Israel">Basic Laws</a>, the 1980 <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Law" title="Jerusalem Law">Jerusalem Law</a>, refers to Jerusalem as the country's undivided capital. All branches of the Israeli government are located in Jerusalem, including the <a href="/wiki/Knesset" title="Knesset">Knesset</a> (Israel's parliament), the residences of the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Israel" title="Prime Minister of Israel">Prime Minister</a> (<a href="/wiki/Beit_Aghion" title="Beit Aghion">Beit Aghion</a>) and <a href="/wiki/President_of_Israel" title="President of Israel">President</a> (<a href="/wiki/Beit_HaNassi" title="Beit HaNassi">Beit HaNassi</a>), and the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Israel" title="Supreme Court of Israel">Supreme Court</a>. The <a href="/wiki/International_community" title="International community">international community</a> rejects the annexation as illegal and treats East Jerusalem as <a href="/wiki/Israeli_occupation_of_the_West_Bank" title="Israeli occupation of the West Bank">Palestinian territory occupied by Israel</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[42]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[43]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[44]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[45]</a></sup>
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology_and_names">Etymology and names</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Names_of_Jerusalem" title="Names of Jerusalem">Names of Jerusalem</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h3>
<p>The name "Jerusalem" is variously etymologized to mean "foundation (Semitic <i>yry'</i> 'to found, to lay a cornerstone') of the god <a href="/wiki/Shalim" title="Shalim">Shalem</a>";<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[46]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Binz_53-0"><a href="#cite_note-Binz-53">[47]</a></sup> the god Shalem was thus the original <a href="/wiki/Tutelary_deity" title="Tutelary deity">tutelary deity</a> of the Bronze Age city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[48]</a></sup>
</p><p>Shalim or Shalem was the name of the god of dusk in the <a href="/wiki/Canaanite_religion" title="Canaanite religion">Canaanite religion</a>, whose name is based on the same root <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S-L-M" title="S-L-M">S-L-M</a> from which the Hebrew word for "peace" is derived (<i>Shalom</i> in <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_language" title="Hebrew language">Hebrew</a>, cognate with <a href="/wiki/Modern_Standard_Arabic" title="Modern Standard Arabic">Arabic</a> <i>Salam</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[49]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[50]</a></sup> The name thus offered itself to etymologizations such as "The City of Peace",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Binz_53-1"><a href="#cite_note-Binz-53">[47]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hastings_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hastings-57">[51]</a></sup> "Abode of Peace",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bosworth_58-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bosworth-58">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DeGarmo_59-0"><a href="#cite_note-DeGarmo-59">[53]</a></sup> "Dwelling of Peace" ("founded in safety"),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[54]</a></sup> or "Vision of Peace" in some Christian authors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Harrison_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-Harrison-61">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>The ending <i>-ayim</i> indicates the <a href="/wiki/Dual_(grammatical_number)" title="Dual (grammatical number)">dual</a>, thus leading to the suggestion that the name <i>Yerushalayim</i> refers to the fact that the city initially sat on two hills.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[56]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[57]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ancient_Egyptian_sources">Ancient Egyptian sources</span></h3>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Execration_Texts" title="Execration Texts">Execration Texts</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Kingdom_of_Egypt" title="Middle Kingdom of Egypt">Middle Kingdom of Egypt</a> (c. 19th century BCE), which refer to a city called <i>rwÅ¡ê£lmm</i> or <i>ê£wÅ¡ê£mm</i>, variously transcribed as <i>RuÅ¡alimum</i>, <i>UruÅ¡alimum</i> or <i>RÃ´sh-ramen</i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[58]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[59]</a></sup> may indicate Jerusalem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[60]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[61]</a></sup> Alternatively, the <a href="/wiki/Amarna_letters" title="Amarna letters">Amarna letters</a> of <a href="/wiki/Abdi-Heba" title="Abdi-Heba">Abdi-Heba</a> (1330s BCE), which reference an <i>ÃruÅ¡alim</i>, may be the earliest mention of the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vaughn_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-vaughn-68">[62]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[63]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[64]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Hebrew_Bible_and_Jewish_sources">Hebrew Bible and Jewish sources</span></h3>
<p>The form <i>Yerushalem</i> or <i>Yerushalayim</i> first appears in the Bible, in the <a href="/wiki/Book_of_Joshua" title="Book of Joshua">Book of Joshua</a>. According to a <a href="/wiki/Midrash" title="Midrash">Midrash</a>, the name is a combination of two names united by God, <i>Yireh</i> ("the abiding place", the name given by <a href="/wiki/Abraham" title="Abraham">Abraham</a> to the place where <a href="/wiki/Binding_of_Isaac" title="Binding of Isaac">he planned to sacrifice his son</a>) and <i><a href="/wiki/Salem_(Bible)" title="Salem (Bible)">Shalem</a></i> ("Place of Peace", the name given by high priest <a href="/wiki/Shem" title="Shem">Shem</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[65]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Oldest_written_mention_of_Jerusalem">Oldest written mention of <i>Jerusalem</i></span></h3>
<p>One of the earliest extra-biblical <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hebrew" title="Hebrew">Hebrew</a> writing of the word <i>Jerusalem</i> is dated to the sixth or seventh century BCE<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[66]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[67]</a></sup> and was discovered in <a href="/wiki/Khirbet_Beit_Lei" title="Khirbet Beit Lei">Khirbet Beit Lei</a> near <a href="/wiki/Beit_Guvrin,_Israel" title="Beit Guvrin, Israel">Beit Guvrin</a> in 1961. The inscription states: "I am Yahweh thy God, I will accept the cities of Judah and I will redeem Jerusalem",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[68]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[69]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76"><a href="#cite_note-76">[70]</a></sup> or as other scholars suggest: "Yahweh is the God of the whole earth. The mountains of Judah belong to him, to the God of Jerusalem".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Naveh2001_77-0"><a href="#cite_note-Naveh2001-77">[71]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[72]</a></sup> An older example on papyrus is known from the previous century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Baruch_79-0"><a href="#cite_note-Baruch-79">[73]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Khirbet_Beit_Lei_inscription_A_close_up.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2736" data-file-width="3648" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Khirbet_Beit_Lei_inscription_A_close_up.jpg/220px-Khirbet_Beit_Lei_inscription_A_close_up.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Khirbet_Beit_Lei_inscription_A_close_up.jpg/330px-Khirbet_Beit_Lei_inscription_A_close_up.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Khirbet_Beit_Lei_inscription_A_close_up.jpg/440px-Khirbet_Beit_Lei_inscription_A_close_up.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Khirbet_Beit_Lei_inscription_A_close_up.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Close up of the <a href="/wiki/Khirbet_Beit_Lei_graffiti" title="Khirbet Beit Lei graffiti">Khirbet Beit Lei inscription</a>, showing the earliest extra-biblical Hebrew writing of the word <i>Jerusalem</i>, dated to the seventh or sixth century BCE</div></div></div>
<p>In extra-biblical inscriptions, the earliest known example of the <i>-ayim</i> ending was discovered on a column about 3Â km west of ancient Jerusalem, dated to the first century BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Baruch_79-1"><a href="#cite_note-Baruch-79">[73]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Jebus.2C_Zion.2C_City_of_David"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Jebus,_Zion,_City_of_David">Jebus, Zion, City of David</span></h3>
<p>An ancient settlement of Jerusalem, founded as early as the Bronze Age on the hill above the <a href="/wiki/Gihon_Spring" title="Gihon Spring">Gihon Spring</a>, was, according to the Bible, named <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jebusite" title="Jebusite">Jebus</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[74]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[75]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gagrinp113_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gagrinp113-82">[76]</a></sup> Called the "Fortress of Zion" (<i>metsudat Zion</i>), it was renamed as the "City of David",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[77]</a></sup> and was known by this name in antiquity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[78]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[79]</a></sup> Another name, "<a href="/wiki/Zion" title="Zion">Zion</a>", initially referred to a distinct part of the city, but later came to signify the city as a whole, and afterwards to represent the whole biblical <a href="/wiki/Land_of_Israel" title="Land of Israel">Land of Israel</a>.
</p>
<h3><span id="Greek.2C_Roman_and_Byzantine_names"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Greek,_Roman_and_Byzantine_names">Greek, Roman and Byzantine names</span></h3>
<p>In Greek and Latin, the city's name was transliterated <i>Hierosolyma</i> (Greek: á¼¹ÎµÏÎ¿ÏÏÎ»ÏÎ¼Î±; in Greek <i>hierÃ²s</i>, <i>á¼±ÎµÏÏÏ</i>, means holy), although the city was renamed <a href="/wiki/Aelia_Capitolina" title="Aelia Capitolina">Aelia Capitolina</a> for part of the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">Roman</a> period of its history.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Salem">Salem</span></h3>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aramaic_language" title="Aramaic language">Aramaic</a> <a href="/wiki/Genesis_Apocryphon" title="Genesis Apocryphon">Apocryphon of Genesis</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Dead_Sea_Scrolls" title="Dead Sea Scrolls">Dead Sea Scrolls</a> (1QapGen 22:13) equates Jerusalem with the earlier "Salem" (×©××), said to be the kingdom of <a href="/wiki/Melchizedek" title="Melchizedek">Melchizedek</a> in Genesis 14.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[80]</a></sup> Other early Hebrew sources,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[81]</a></sup> early Christian renderings of the verse<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[82]</a></sup> and <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Targumim" title="Targumim">targumim</a></i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[83]</a></sup> however, put Salem in Northern Israel near <a href="/wiki/Shechem" title="Shechem">Shechem</a> (Sichem), now <a href="/wiki/Nablus" title="Nablus">Nablus</a>, a city of some importance in early sacred Hebrew writing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[84]</a></sup> Possibly the redactor of the Apocryphon of Genesis wanted to dissociate Melchizedek from the area of Shechem, which at the time was in possession of the <a href="/wiki/Samaritans" title="Samaritans">Samaritans</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[85]</a></sup> However that may be, later Rabbinic sources also equate Salem with Jerusalem, mainly to link Melchizedek to later Temple traditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[86]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Arabic_names">Arabic names</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"Al-Quds" redirects here. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Al-Quds_(disambiguation)" title="Al-Quds (disambiguation)">Al-Quds (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p>In Arabic, Jerusalem is most commonly known as <span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø§ÙÙÙØ¯Ø³</span></span>, transliterated as <i>al-Quds</i> and meaning "The Holy" or "The Holy Sanctuary",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bosworth_58-1"><a href="#cite_note-Bosworth-58">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DeGarmo_59-1"><a href="#cite_note-DeGarmo-59">[53]</a></sup> cognate with <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_language" title="Hebrew language">Hebrew</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="he">××§××©</span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Hebrew" title="Romanization of Hebrew">romanized</a>:Â </small><span title="Hebrew-language romanization"><i lang="he-Latn">Ha-Qodesh</i></span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Literal_translation" title="Literal translation">lit.</a>â</small>'The Holy'. The <span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ù</span></span> (Q) is pronounced either with a <a href="/wiki/Voiceless_uvular_plosive" title="Voiceless uvular plosive">voiceless uvular plosive</a> (/q/), as in <a href="/wiki/Classical_Arabic" title="Classical Arabic">Classical Arabic</a>, or with a <a href="/wiki/Glottal_stop" title="Glottal stop">glottal stop</a> (Ê) as in <a href="/wiki/Levantine_Arabic" title="Levantine Arabic">Levantine Arabic</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Elihay2011_13-1"><a href="#cite_note-Elihay2011-13">[12]</a></sup> Official Israeli government policy mandates that <span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø£ÙÙØ±ÙØ´ÙÙÙÙÙÙ</span></span>, transliterated as <i>ÅªrÅ¡alÄ«m</i>, which is the cognate of the Hebrew and English names, be used as the Arabic language name for the city in conjunction with <span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø§ÙÙÙØ¯Ø³</span></span>. <span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø£ÙÙØ±ÙØ´ÙÙÙÙÙÙ-Ø§ÙÙÙØ¯Ø³</span></span>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[87]</a></sup> Palestinian Arab families who hail from this city are often called "<i>Qudsi</i>" or "<i>Maqdisi</i>", while Palestinian Muslim Jerusalemites may use these terms as a <a href="/wiki/Demonym" title="Demonym">demonym</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[88]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Jerusalem" title="History of Jerusalem">History of Jerusalem</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For a chronological guide, see <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Jerusalem" title="Timeline of Jerusalem">Timeline of Jerusalem</a>.</div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Cartography_of_Jerusalem" title="Cartography of Jerusalem">Historical maps of Jerusalem</a></div>
<p>Given the city's central position in both Jewish nationalism (<a href="/wiki/Zionism" title="Zionism">Zionism</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_nationalism" title="Palestinian nationalism">Palestinian nationalism</a>, the selectivity required to summarize some 5,000 years of inhabited history is often <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Historiography_and_nationalism" title="Historiography and nationalism">influenced by ideological bias or background</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT7k_95-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYT7k-95">[89]</a></sup> Israeli or Jewish nationalists claim a right to the city based on Jewish indigeneity to the land, particularly <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_and_Judaism_in_the_Land_of_Israel" title="History of the Jews and Judaism in the Land of Israel">their origins in and descent</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Israelites" title="Israelites">Israelites</a>, for whom Jerusalem is their capital, and their yearning for return.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[90]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[91]</a></sup> In contrast, Palestinian nationalists claim the right to the city based on modern <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Palestinian_people" title="Palestinian people">Palestinians</a>' longstanding presence and descent from many different peoples who have settled or lived in the region over the centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Intl1998_98-0"><a href="#cite_note-Intl1998-98">[92]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[93]</a></sup> Both sides claim the history of the city has been politicized by the other in order to strengthen their relative claims to the city,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bisharat_100-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bisharat-100">[94]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[95]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[96]</a></sup> and that this is borne out by the different focuses the different writers place on the various events and eras in the city's history.
</p>
<h3><span id="Overview_of_Jerusalem.27s_historical_periods"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Overview_of_Jerusalem's_historical_periods">Overview of Jerusalem's historical periods</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Jerusalem" title="Timeline of Jerusalem">Timeline of Jerusalem</a></div>
<div class="timeline-wrapper"><map name="timeline_po26l3hkx2vz0x0u3ilryhpzq4fuu29"><area alt="Reunification of Jerusalem" coords="790,457,868,481" href="/wiki/Reunification_of_Jerusalem" shape="rect" usemap="#timeline_po26l3hkx2vz0x0u3ilryhpzq4fuu29"/></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">Prehistory</span></h3>
<p>The first archaeological evidence of human presence in the area comes in the form of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flints" title="Flints">flints</a> dated to between 6000 and 7000 years ago,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Greenberg_18-1"><a href="#cite_note-Greenberg-18">[15]</a></sup> with ceramic remains appearing during the <a href="/wiki/Chalcolithic" title="Chalcolithic">Chalcolithic</a> period, and the first signs of permanent settlement appearing in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_Bronze_Age" title="Early Bronze Age">Early Bronze Age</a> in 3000â2800 BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Negev_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-Negev-103">[97]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freedman2000_104-0"><a href="#cite_note-freedman2000-104">[98]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Late_bronze_age">Late bronze age</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/City_of_David_(archaeological_site)" title="City of David (archaeological site)">City of David (archaeological site)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:City_of_David_-_The_Stepped_Stone_Stracture_IMG_5828.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/City_of_David_-_The_Stepped_Stone_Stracture_IMG_5828.JPG/220px-City_of_David_-_The_Stepped_Stone_Stracture_IMG_5828.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/City_of_David_-_The_Stepped_Stone_Stracture_IMG_5828.JPG/330px-City_of_David_-_The_Stepped_Stone_Stracture_IMG_5828.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/City_of_David_-_The_Stepped_Stone_Stracture_IMG_5828.JPG/440px-City_of_David_-_The_Stepped_Stone_Stracture_IMG_5828.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:City_of_David_-_The_Stepped_Stone_Stracture_IMG_5828.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Stepped_Stone_Structure" title="Stepped Stone Structure">Stepped Stone Structure</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze Age</a> and <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">Iron Age</a> on the southeastern slope of old Jerusalem</div></div></div>
<p>The earliest evidence of city fortifications appear in the <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age#Near_East" title="Bronze Age">Mid to Late Bronze Age</a> and could date to around the 18th century BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[99]</a></sup> By around 1550-1200 BCE, Jerusalem was the capital of an Egyptian vassal city-state,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[100]</a></sup> a modest settlement governing a few outlying villages and pastoral areas, with a small Egyptian garrison and ruled by appointees such as king <a href="/wiki/Abdi-Heba" title="Abdi-Heba">Abdi-Heba</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[101]</a></sup> At the time of <a href="/wiki/Seti_I" title="Seti I">Seti I</a> (r. 1290â1279 BCE) and <a href="/wiki/Ramesses_II" title="Ramesses II">Ramesses II</a> (r. 1279â1213 BCE), major construction took place as prosperity increased.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MurphyOConnor_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-MurphyOConnor-108">[102]</a></sup> The city's inhabitants at this time were Canaanites, who are believed by scholars to have evolved into the Israelites via the development of a distinct Yahweh-centric monotheistic belief system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[103]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[104]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rendsberg3_30-1"><a href="#cite_note-Rendsberg3-30">[25]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Iron_Age">Iron Age</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/City_of_David_(archaeological_site)" title="City of David (archaeological site)">City of David (archaeological site)</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_ancient_Israel_and_Judah" title="History of ancient Israel and Judah">History of ancient Israel and Judah</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Shiloach.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="194" data-file-width="400" decoding="async" height="107" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Shiloach.jpg/220px-Shiloach.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Shiloach.jpg/330px-Shiloach.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f1/Shiloach.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Shiloach.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Siloam_Inscription" title="Siloam Inscription">Siloam Inscription</a>, written in <a href="/wiki/Biblical_Hebrew" title="Biblical Hebrew">Biblical Hebrew</a>, commemorates the construction of the <a href="/wiki/Siloam_tunnel" title="Siloam tunnel">Siloam tunnel</a> (c. 700 BCE)</div></div></div>
<p>Archaeological remains from the ancient <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Israelite" title="Israelite">Israelite</a> period include the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Siloam_Tunnel" title="Siloam Tunnel">Siloam Tunnel</a>, an aqueduct built by <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Judah" title="Kingdom of Judah">Judahite</a> king <a href="/wiki/Hezekiah" title="Hezekiah">Hezekiah</a> and once containing an ancient Hebrew inscription, known as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Siloam_Inscription" title="Siloam Inscription">Siloam Inscription</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[105]</a></sup> the so-called <a href="/wiki/Broad_Wall_(Jerusalem)" title="Broad Wall (Jerusalem)">Broad Wall</a>, a defensive fortification built in the 8th century BCE, also by Hezekiah;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[106]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Silwan_necropolis" title="Silwan necropolis">Silwan necropolis</a> (9th-7th c. BCE) with the <a href="/wiki/Monolith_of_Silwan" title="Monolith of Silwan">Monolith of Silwan</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Silwan_necropolis#Tomb_of_the_Royal_Steward" title="Silwan necropolis">Tomb of the Royal Steward</a>, which were decorated with monumental <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hebrew" title="Hebrew">Hebrew</a> inscriptions;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[107]</a></sup> and the so-called <a href="/wiki/Israelite_Tower" title="Israelite Tower">Israelite Tower</a>, remnants of ancient fortifications, built from large, sturdy rocks with carved cornerstones.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[108]</a></sup> A huge water reservoir dating from this period was discovered in 2012 near <a href="/wiki/Robinson%27s_Arch" title="Robinson's Arch">Robinson's Arch</a>, indicating the existence of a densely built-up quarter across the area west of the Temple Mount during the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Judah" title="Kingdom of Judah">Kingdom of Judah</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[109]</a></sup>
</p><p>When the <a href="/wiki/Assyria" title="Assyria">Assyrians</a> <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Israel_(Samaria)#Destruction_of_the_kingdom" title="Kingdom of Israel (Samaria)">conquered the Kingdom of Israel</a> in 722 BCE, Jerusalem was strengthened by a great influx of refugees from the northern kingdom. When Hezekiah ruled, Jerusalem had no fewer than 25,000 inhabitants and covered 25 acres (10 hectares).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[110]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 587â586 BCE, Nebuchadnezzar II of the Neo-Babylonian Empire conquered Jerusalem after a prolonged siege, and then systematically destroyed the city, including <a href="/wiki/Solomon%27s_Temple" title="Solomon's Temple">Solomon's Temple</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:4_117-0"><a href="#cite_note-:4-117">[111]</a></sup> The Kingdom of Judah was abolished and many were <a href="/wiki/Babylonian_captivity" title="Babylonian captivity">exiled to Babylon</a>. These events mark the end of the First Temple period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BU22_118-0"><a href="#cite_note-BU22-118">[112]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Biblical_account">Biblical account</span></h4>
<p>This period, when Canaan formed part of the Egyptian empire, corresponds in biblical accounts to <a href="/wiki/Joshua" title="Joshua">Joshua</a>'s invasion,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[113]</a></sup> but almost all scholars agree that the Book of Joshua holds little historical value for early Israel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[114]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Solomons_Temple_10Century.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2069" data-file-width="3109" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Solomons_Temple_10Century.JPG/220px-Solomons_Temple_10Century.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Solomons_Temple_10Century.JPG/330px-Solomons_Temple_10Century.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Solomons_Temple_10Century.JPG/440px-Solomons_Temple_10Century.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Solomons_Temple_10Century.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Modern-day reconstruction of Jerusalem during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Solomon" title="Solomon">Solomon</a> (10th century BCE). <a href="/wiki/Solomon%27s_Temple" title="Solomon's Temple">Solomon's Temple</a> appears on top.</div></div></div>
<p>In the Bible, Jerusalem is defined as lying within territory allocated to the <a href="/wiki/Tribe_of_Benjamin" title="Tribe of Benjamin">tribe of Benjamin</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[115]</a></sup> though still inhabited by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jebusite" title="Jebusite">Jebusites</a>. <a href="/wiki/David" title="David">David</a> is said to have conquered these in the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Jebus" title="Siege of Jebus">Siege of Jebus</a>, and transferred his capital from <a href="/wiki/Hebron" title="Hebron">Hebron</a> to Jerusalem which then became the capital of a <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Israel_(united_monarchy)" title="Kingdom of Israel (united monarchy)">United Kingdom of Israel</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[116]</a></sup> and one of its several religious centers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[117]</a></sup> The choice was perhaps dictated by the fact that Jerusalem did not form part of Israel's tribal system, and was thus suited to serve as the center of its confederation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MurphyOConnor_108-1"><a href="#cite_note-MurphyOConnor-108">[102]</a></sup> Opinion is divided over whether the so-called <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Large_Stone_Structure" title="Large Stone Structure">Large Stone Structure</a> and the nearby <a href="/wiki/Stepped_Stone_Structure" title="Stepped Stone Structure">Stepped Stone Structure</a> may be identified with King David's palace, or dates to a later period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nytimes_124-0"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes-124">[118]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[119]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the Bible, King David reigned for 40 years<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[120]</a></sup> and was succeeded by his son <a href="/wiki/Solomon" title="Solomon">Solomon</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wwbible_127-0"><a href="#cite_note-wwbible-127">[121]</a></sup> who built the <a href="/wiki/Temple_in_Jerusalem" title="Temple in Jerusalem">Holy Temple</a> on <a href="/wiki/Moriah" title="Moriah">Mount Moriah</a>. Solomon's Temple (later known as the <i>First Temple</i>), went on to play a pivotal role in Jewish religion as the repository of the <a href="/wiki/Ark_of_the_Covenant" title="Ark of the Covenant">Ark of the Covenant</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[122]</a></sup> On Solomon's death, ten of the northern <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tribes_of_Israel" title="Tribes of Israel">tribes of Israel</a> broke with the United Monarchy to form their own nation, with its kings, prophets, priests, traditions relating to religion, capitals and temples in northern Israel. The southern tribes, together with the <a href="/wiki/Kohen" title="Kohen">Aaronid priesthood</a>, remained in Jerusalem, with the city becoming the capital of the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Judah" title="Kingdom of Judah">Kingdom of Judah</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[123]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_130-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-130">[124]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Classical_antiquity">Classical antiquity</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_during_the_Second_Temple_Period" title="Jerusalem during the Second Temple Period">Jerusalem during the Second Temple Period</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aelia_Capitolina" title="Aelia Capitolina">Aelia Capitolina</a></div>
<p>In 538 BCE, the <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Persian</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_kings_of_Persia" title="List of kings of Persia">King</a> <a href="/wiki/Cyrus_the_Great" title="Cyrus the Great">Cyrus the Great</a> invited the <a href="/wiki/Babylonian_captivity" title="Babylonian captivity">Jews of Babylon</a> to return to Judah to rebuild the Temple.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[125]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[126]</a></sup> Construction of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_Temple_of_Jerusalem" title="Second Temple of Jerusalem">Second Temple</a> was completed in 516 BCE, during the reign of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Darius_I_of_Persia" title="Darius I of Persia">Darius the Great</a>, 70 years after the destruction of the First Temple.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[127]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[128]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sometime soon after 485 BCE Jerusalem was besieged, conquered and largely destroyed by a coalition of neighbouring states.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[129]</a></sup> In about 445 BCE, King <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Artaxerxes_I_of_Persia" title="Artaxerxes I of Persia">Artaxerxes I of Persia</a> issued a decree allowing the city (including its walls) to be rebuilt.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[130]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (May 2017)">betterÂ sourceÂ needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Jerusalem resumed its role as capital of Judah and center of Jewish worship.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jerusalem_Modell_BW_2.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2222" data-file-width="3867" decoding="async" height="126" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Jerusalem_Modell_BW_2.JPG/220px-Jerusalem_Modell_BW_2.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Jerusalem_Modell_BW_2.JPG/330px-Jerusalem_Modell_BW_2.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Jerusalem_Modell_BW_2.JPG/440px-Jerusalem_Modell_BW_2.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jerusalem_Modell_BW_2.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Holyland_Model_of_Jerusalem" title="Holyland Model of Jerusalem">Holyland Model of Jerusalem</a>, depicting the city during the late <a href="/wiki/Second_Temple_period" title="Second Temple period">Second Temple period</a>. First created in 1966, it is continuously updated according to advancing archaeological knowledge</div></div></div>
<p>Many Jewish tombs from the <a href="/wiki/Second_Temple_period" title="Second Temple period">Second Temple period</a> have been unearthed in Jerusalem. One example, discovered north of the <a href="/wiki/Old_City_of_Jerusalem" title="Old City of Jerusalem">Old City</a>, contains human remains in a 1st-century CE <a href="/wiki/Ossuary" title="Ossuary">ossuary</a> decorated with the Aramaic inscription "Simon the Temple Builder."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[131]</a></sup> The Tomb of Abba, also located north of the Old City, bears an Aramaic inscription with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paleo-Hebrew" title="Paleo-Hebrew">Paleo-Hebrew</a> letters reading: "I, Abba, son of the priest Eleaz(ar), son of Aaron the high (priest), Abba, the oppressed and the persecuted, who was born in Jerusalem, and went into exile into Babylonia and brought (back to Jerusalem) Mattathi(ah), son of Jud(ah), and buried him in a cave which I bought by deed."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[132]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Tomb_of_Benei_Hezir" title="Tomb of Benei Hezir">Tomb of Benei Hezir</a> located in <a href="/wiki/Kidron_Valley" title="Kidron Valley">Kidron Valley</a> is decorated by monumental <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doric_columns" title="Doric columns">Doric columns</a> and Hebrew inscription, identifying it as the burial site of <a href="/wiki/Second_Temple" title="Second Temple">Second Temple</a> priests. The <a href="/wiki/Tombs_of_the_Sanhedrin" title="Tombs of the Sanhedrin">Tombs of the Sanhedrin</a>, an underground complex of 63 rock-cut tombs, is located in a public park in the northern Jerusalem neighborhood of <a href="/wiki/Sanhedria" title="Sanhedria">Sanhedria</a>. These tombs, probably reserved for members of the <a href="/wiki/Sanhedrin" title="Sanhedrin">Sanhedrin</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[133]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[134]</a></sup> and inscribed by ancient Hebrew and Aramaic writings, are dated to between 100 BCE and 100 CE.
</p><p>When <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a> conquered the <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Persian Empire</a>, Jerusalem and <a href="/wiki/Judea" title="Judea">Judea</a> came under Macedonian control, eventually falling to the <a href="/wiki/Ptolemaic_dynasty" title="Ptolemaic dynasty">Ptolemaic dynasty</a> under <a href="/wiki/Ptolemy_I_Soter" title="Ptolemy I Soter">Ptolemy I</a>. In 198 BCE, <a href="/wiki/Ptolemy_V_Epiphanes" title="Ptolemy V Epiphanes">Ptolemy V Epiphanes</a> lost Jerusalem and Judea to the <a href="/wiki/Seleucid_Empire" title="Seleucid Empire">Seleucids</a> under <a href="/wiki/Antiochus_III_the_Great" title="Antiochus III the Great">Antiochus III</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Seleucid_Empire" title="Seleucid Empire">Seleucid</a> attempt to recast Jerusalem as a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hellenistic_civilization" title="Hellenistic civilization">Hellenized</a> <a href="/wiki/Polis" title="Polis">city-state</a> came to a head in 168 BCE with the successful <a href="/wiki/Maccabees" title="Maccabees">Maccabean revolt</a> of <a href="/wiki/Mattathias" title="Mattathias">Mattathias</a> and his five sons against <a href="/wiki/Antiochus_IV_Epiphanes" title="Antiochus IV Epiphanes">Antiochus IV Epiphanes</a>, and their establishment of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hasmonean" title="Hasmonean">Hasmonean</a> Kingdom in 152 BCE with Jerusalem as its capital.
</p><p>In 63 BCE, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pompey_the_Great" title="Pompey the Great">Pompey the Great</a> intervened in a struggle for the Hasmonean throne and captured Jerusalem, extending the influence of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">Roman Republic</a> over Judea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[135]</a></sup> Following a short invasion by <a href="/wiki/Parthian_Empire" title="Parthian Empire">Parthians</a>, backing the rival Hasmonean rulers, Judea became a scene of struggle between pro-Roman and pro-Parthian forces, eventually leading to the emergence of an <a href="/wiki/Edom" title="Edom">Edomite</a> named Herod. As <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Rome</a> became stronger, it installed <a href="/wiki/Herod_the_Great" title="Herod the Great">Herod</a> as a <a href="/wiki/Vassal_state" title="Vassal state">client king</a> of the Jews. Herod the Great, as he was known, devoted himself to developing and beautifying the city. He built walls, towers and palaces, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Herod%27s_Temple" title="Herod's Temple">expanded the Temple Mount</a>, buttressing the courtyard with blocks of stone weighing up to 100 tons. Under Herod, the area of the Temple Mount doubled in size.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wwbible_127-1"><a href="#cite_note-wwbible-127">[121]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HarEl68_142-0"><a href="#cite_note-HarEl68-142">[136]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[137]</a></sup> Shortly after Herod's death, in 6 CE Judea came under direct Roman rule as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iudaea_Province" title="Iudaea Province">Iudaea Province</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[138]</a></sup> although the Herodian dynasty through <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Agrippa_II" title="Agrippa II">Agrippa II</a> remained client kings of neighboring territories until 96 CE.
</p><p>
Roman rule over Jerusalem and Judea was challenged in the <a href="/wiki/First_Jewish%E2%80%93Roman_War" title="First JewishâRoman War">First JewishâRoman War</a> (66-73 CE), which ended with a Roman victory. Early on, the city was devastated by a <a href="/wiki/Zealot_Temple_Siege" title="Zealot Temple Siege">brutal civil war</a> between several Jewish factions fighting for control of the city. In 70 CE, the Romans <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Jerusalem_(70_CE)" title="Siege of Jerusalem (70 CE)">destroyed Jerusalem and the Second Temple</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_145-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-145">[139]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-:1-146">[140]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_147-0"><a href="#cite_note-:2-147">[141]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_148-0"><a href="#cite_note-:3-148">[142]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[143]</a></sup> The contemporary Jewish historian <a href="/wiki/Josephus" title="Josephus">Josephus</a> wrote that the city "was so thoroughly razed to the ground by those that demolished it to its foundations, that nothing was left that could ever persuade visitors that it had once been a place of habitation."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[144]</a></sup> Of the 600,000 (Tacitus) or 1,000,000 (Josephus) Jews of Jerusalem, all of them either died of starvation, were killed or were sold into slavery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[145]</a></sup> Roman rule was again challenged during the <a href="/wiki/Bar_Kokhba_revolt" title="Bar Kokhba revolt">Bar Kokhba revolt</a>, beginning in 132 CE and suppressed by the Romans in 135 CE. More recent research indicates that the Romans had founded Aelia Capitolina before the outbreak of the revolt, and found no evidence for Bar Kokhba ever managing to hold the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EncJud_152-0"><a href="#cite_note-EncJud-152">[146]</a></sup></p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Half_Shekel.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="391" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="108" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Half_Shekel.jpg/220px-Half_Shekel.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Half_Shekel.jpg/330px-Half_Shekel.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Half_Shekel.jpg/440px-Half_Shekel.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Half_Shekel.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/First_Jewish_Revolt_coinage" title="First Jewish Revolt coinage">A coin issued by the Jewish rebels</a> in 68 CE. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Obverse" title="Obverse">Obverse</a>: "<a href="/wiki/Shekel" title="Shekel">Shekel</a>, Israel. Year 3". <a href="/wiki/Obverse_and_reverse" title="Obverse and reverse">Reverse</a>: "Jerusalem the Holy", in the <a href="/wiki/Paleo-Hebrew_alphabet" title="Paleo-Hebrew alphabet">Paleo-Hebrew alphabet</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:NinthAvStonesWesternWall.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3264" data-file-width="2448" decoding="async" height="293" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/NinthAvStonesWesternWall.JPG/220px-NinthAvStonesWesternWall.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/NinthAvStonesWesternWall.JPG/330px-NinthAvStonesWesternWall.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/NinthAvStonesWesternWall.JPG/440px-NinthAvStonesWesternWall.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:NinthAvStonesWesternWall.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Stones from the <a href="/wiki/Western_Wall" title="Western Wall">Western Wall</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Temple_Mount" title="Temple Mount">Temple Mount</a> thrown during the Roman <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Jerusalem_(70_CE)" title="Siege of Jerusalem (70 CE)">Siege of Jerusalem</a> in 70 CE</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:David_Roberts_-_The_Siege_and_Destruction_of_Jerusalem_by_the_Romans_Under_the_Command_of_Titus,_A.D._70.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3921" data-file-width="5906" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/David_Roberts_-_The_Siege_and_Destruction_of_Jerusalem_by_the_Romans_Under_the_Command_of_Titus%2C_A.D._70.jpg/220px-David_Roberts_-_The_Siege_and_Destruction_of_Jerusalem_by_the_Romans_Under_the_Command_of_Titus%2C_A.D._70.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/David_Roberts_-_The_Siege_and_Destruction_of_Jerusalem_by_the_Romans_Under_the_Command_of_Titus%2C_A.D._70.jpg/330px-David_Roberts_-_The_Siege_and_Destruction_of_Jerusalem_by_the_Romans_Under_the_Command_of_Titus%2C_A.D._70.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/David_Roberts_-_The_Siege_and_Destruction_of_Jerusalem_by_the_Romans_Under_the_Command_of_Titus%2C_A.D._70.jpg/440px-David_Roberts_-_The_Siege_and_Destruction_of_Jerusalem_by_the_Romans_Under_the_Command_of_Titus%2C_A.D._70.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:David_Roberts_-_The_Siege_and_Destruction_of_Jerusalem_by_the_Romans_Under_the_Command_of_Titus,_A.D._70.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Siege and Destruction of Jerusalem by the Romans (David Roberts, 1850)</div></div></div><p>Following the Bar Kokhba revolt, Emperor <a href="/wiki/Hadrian" title="Hadrian">Hadrian</a> combined <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iudaea_Province" title="Iudaea Province">Iudaea Province</a> with neighboring provinces under the new name of <i><a href="/wiki/Syria_Palaestina" title="Syria Palaestina">Syria Palaestina</a></i>, replacing the name of Judea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[147]</a></sup> The city was renamed <a href="/wiki/Aelia_Capitolina" title="Aelia Capitolina">Aelia Capitolina</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_145-1"><a href="#cite_note-:0-145">[139]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[148]</a></sup> and rebuilt it in the style of a typical Roman town. Jews were prohibited from entering the city on pain of death, except for one day each year, during the holiday of <a href="/wiki/Tisha_B%27Av" title="Tisha B'Av">Tisha B'Av</a>. Taken together, these measures<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SchÃ¤fer2003_155-0"><a href="#cite_note-SchÃ¤fer2003-155">[149]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ERPplaces_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-ERPplaces-156">[150]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[151]</a></sup> (which also affected Jewish Christians)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[152]</a></sup> essentially "secularized" the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[153]</a></sup> The ban was maintained until the 7th century,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[154]</a></sup> though Christians would soon be granted an exemption: during the 4th century, the <a href="/wiki/Roman_emperor" title="Roman emperor">Roman emperor</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constantine_I" title="Constantine I">Constantine I</a> ordered the construction of Christian holy sites in the city, including the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre" title="Church of the Holy Sepulchre">Church of the Holy Sepulchre</a>. Burial remains from the Byzantine period are exclusively Christian, suggesting that the population of Jerusalem in Byzantine times probably consisted only of Christians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[155]</a></sup>
In the 5th century, the eastern continuation of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a>, ruled from the recently renamed <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a>, maintained control of the city. Within the span of a few decades, Jerusalem shifted from Byzantine to <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Persian</a> rule, then back to Roman-Byzantine dominion. Following <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sassanid_Empire" title="Sassanid Empire">Sassanid</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Khosrau_II" title="Khosrau II">Khosrau II</a>'s early 7th century push through Syria, his generals <a href="/wiki/Shahrbaraz" title="Shahrbaraz">Shahrbaraz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shahin_Vahmanzadegan" title="Shahin Vahmanzadegan">Shahin</a> attacked Jerusalem (<a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="fa">Dej Houdkh</span>) aided by the Jews of <a href="/wiki/Palaestina_Prima" title="Palaestina Prima">Palaestina Prima</a>, who had risen up against the Byzantines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Strategos_162-0"><a href="#cite_note-Strategos-162">[156]</a></sup></p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:OCJ_VIW_20130109_101325.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2448" data-file-width="3264" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/OCJ_VIW_20130109_101325.jpg/220px-OCJ_VIW_20130109_101325.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/OCJ_VIW_20130109_101325.jpg/330px-OCJ_VIW_20130109_101325.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/OCJ_VIW_20130109_101325.jpg/440px-OCJ_VIW_20130109_101325.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:OCJ_VIW_20130109_101325.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Jerusalem mural depicting the Cardo during the Byzantine period.</div></div></div>
<p>In the <a href="/wiki/Sasanian_conquest_of_Jerusalem" title="Sasanian conquest of Jerusalem">Siege of Jerusalem of 614</a>, after 21 days of relentless <a href="/wiki/Siege" title="Siege">siege warfare</a>, Jerusalem was captured. Byzantine chronicles relate that the Sassanids and Jews slaughtered tens of thousands of Christians in the city, many at the <a href="/wiki/Mamilla_Pool" title="Mamilla Pool">Mamilla Pool</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[157]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[158]</a></sup> and destroyed their monuments and churches, including the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre" title="Church of the Holy Sepulchre">Church of the Holy Sepulchre</a>. This episode has been the subject of much debate between historians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[159]</a></sup> The conquered city would remain in Sassanid hands for some fifteen years until the Byzantine emperor <a href="/wiki/Heraclius" title="Heraclius">Heraclius</a> reconquered it in 629.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[160]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jerusalem reached a peak in size and population at the end of the Second Temple Period, when the city covered <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1020198016" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>twoÂ km<sup>2</sup> (<span class="frac" role="math"><span class="num">3</span>â<span class="den">4</span></span>Â sqÂ mi) and had a population of 200,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ERPplaces_156-1"><a href="#cite_note-ERPplaces-156">[150]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HarEl68_142-1"><a href="#cite_note-HarEl68-142">[136]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_Muslim_period">Early Muslim period</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Jerusalem_during_the_Early_Muslim_period" title="History of Jerusalem during the Early Muslim period">History of Jerusalem during the Early Muslim period</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Jerusalem_during_the_Middle_Ages" title="History of Jerusalem during the Middle Ages">the Middle Ages</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:1283_Descriptio_Terrae_Sanctae.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1180" data-file-width="726" decoding="async" height="276" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/1283_Descriptio_Terrae_Sanctae.jpg/170px-1283_Descriptio_Terrae_Sanctae.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/1283_Descriptio_Terrae_Sanctae.jpg/255px-1283_Descriptio_Terrae_Sanctae.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/1283_Descriptio_Terrae_Sanctae.jpg/340px-1283_Descriptio_Terrae_Sanctae.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:1283_Descriptio_Terrae_Sanctae.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>1455 painting of the Holy Land. Jerusalem is viewed from the west; the octagonal <a href="/wiki/Dome_of_the_Rock" title="Dome of the Rock">Dome of the Rock</a> stands left of the <a href="/wiki/Al-Aqsa_Mosque" title="Al-Aqsa Mosque">Al-Aqsa Mosque</a>, shown as a church, and the Church of the Holy Sepulchre stands on the left side of the picture.</div></div></div>
<p>Byzantine Jerusalem was conquered by the Arab armies of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Umar_ibn_al-Khattab" title="Umar ibn al-Khattab">Umar ibn al-Khattab</a> in 638 CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[161]</a></sup> Among the first <a href="/wiki/Muslims" title="Muslims">Muslims</a>, it was referred to as <i>Madinat bayt al-Maqdis</i> ("City of the Temple"),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[162]</a></sup> a name restricted to the Temple Mount. The rest of the city "was called Iliya, reflecting the Roman name given the city following the destruction of 70 CE: <i>Aelia Capitolina</i>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[163]</a></sup> Later the Temple Mount became known as <i>al-Haram al-Sharif</i>, "The Noble Sanctuary", while the city around it became known as <i>Bayt al-Maqdis</i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[164]</a></sup> and later still, <i>al-Quds al-Sharif</i> "The Holy, Noble". The <a href="/wiki/Islamization" title="Islamization">Islamization</a> of Jerusalem began in the first year <a href="/wiki/Hijri_year" title="Hijri year">A.H.</a> (623 CE), when Muslims were instructed to face the city while performing their daily prostrations and, according to Muslim religious tradition, Muhammad's night journey and ascension to heaven took place. After 13 years, the direction of prayer was changed to Mecca.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[165]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Watt1974_172-0"><a href="#cite_note-Watt1974-172">[166]</a></sup> In 638 CE the Islamic <a href="/wiki/Caliphate" title="Caliphate">Caliphate</a> extended its dominion to Jerusalem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gilbert7_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gilbert7-173">[167]</a></sup> With the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_Syria" title="Muslim conquest of Syria">Arab conquest</a>, Jews were allowed back into the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[168]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Rashidun" title="Rashidun">Rashidun</a> caliph <a href="/wiki/Umar" title="Umar">Umar ibn al-Khattab</a> signed a treaty with Christian Patriarch of Jerusalem <a href="/wiki/Sophronius_of_Jerusalem" title="Sophronius of Jerusalem">Sophronius</a>, assuring him that Jerusalem's Christian holy places and population would be protected under Muslim rule.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[169]</a></sup> Christian-Arab tradition records that, when led to pray at the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, one of the holiest sites for Christians, the caliph Umar refused to pray in the church so that Muslims would not request conversion of the church to a mosque.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[170]</a></sup> He prayed outside the church, where the <a href="/wiki/Mosque_of_Omar_(Jerusalem)" title="Mosque of Omar (Jerusalem)">Mosque of Umar (Omar)</a> stands to this day, opposite the entrance to the Church of the Holy Sepulchre. According to the Gaullic bishop <a href="/wiki/Arculf" title="Arculf">Arculf</a>, who lived in Jerusalem from 679 to 688, the Mosque of Umar was a rectangular wooden structure built over ruins which could accommodate 3,000 worshipers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-YShalem_177-0"><a href="#cite_note-YShalem-177">[171]</a></sup>
</p><p>When the Arab armies under <a href="/wiki/Umar" title="Umar">Umar</a> went to <i>Bayt Al-Maqdes</i> in 637 CE, they searched for the site of <a href="/wiki/Temple_Mount" title="Temple Mount"><i>al-masjid al-aqsa</i></a>, "the farthest place of prayer/mosque", that was mentioned in the <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hadith" title="Hadith">Hadith</a> according to Islamic beliefs. Contemporary Arabic and Hebrew sources say the site was full of rubbish, and that Arabs and Jews cleaned it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[172]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_Caliphate" title="Umayyad Caliphate">Umayyad</a> caliph <a href="/wiki/Abd_al-Malik_ibn_Marwan" title="Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan">Abd al-Malik</a> commissioned the construction of a shrine on the Temple Mount, now known as the Dome of the Rock, in the late 7th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[173]</a></sup> Two of the city's most-distinguished Arab citizens of the 10th-century were <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Al-Muqaddasi" title="Al-Muqaddasi">Al-Muqaddasi</a>, the geographer, and <a href="/wiki/Al-Tamimi,_the_physician" title="Al-Tamimi, the physician">Al-Tamimi, the physician</a>. Al-Muqaddasi writes that Abd al-Malik built the edifice on the Temple Mount in order to compete in grandeur with Jerusalem's monumental churches.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-YShalem_177-1"><a href="#cite_note-YShalem-177">[171]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><video class="thumbimage" controls="" data-durationhint="59" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" data-mwtitle="Urbs_Hierosolyma.webm" height="124" id="mwe_player_0" poster="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Urbs_Hierosolyma.webm/220px--Urbs_Hierosolyma.webm.jpg" preload="none" width="220"><source data-bandwidth="1017400" data-framerate="30" data-height="480" data-shorttitle="VP9 480P" data-title="SD VP9 (480P)" data-transcodekey="480p.vp9.webm" data-width="854" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/77/Urbs_Hierosolyma.webm/Urbs_Hierosolyma.webm.480p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm;
