Latin with English subtitles</div></div></div><p> Over the next four hundred years, Jerusalem's prominence diminished as Arab powers in the region vied for control of the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[174]</a></sup> Jerusalem was captured in 1073 by the <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_Empire" title="Seljuk Empire">Seljuk</a> Turkish commander <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atsiz_ibn_Uvaq" title="Atsiz ibn Uvaq">AtsÄ±z</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[175]</a></sup> After AtsÄ±z was killed, the Seljuk prince <a href="/wiki/Tutush_I" title="Tutush I">Tutush I</a> granted the city to <a href="/wiki/Artuk_Bey" title="Artuk Bey">Artuk Bey</a>, another Seljuk commander. After Artuk's death in 1091 his sons <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S%C3%B6kmen_of_Artukids" title="SÃ¶kmen of Artukids">SÃ¶kmen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ilghazi" title="Ilghazi">Ilghazi</a> governed in the city up to 1098 when the <a href="/wiki/Fatimid_Caliphate" title="Fatimid Caliphate">Fatimids</a> recaptured the city.
</p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:1099jerusalem.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="802" data-file-width="766" decoding="async" height="178" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/1099jerusalem.jpg/170px-1099jerusalem.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/1099jerusalem.jpg/255px-1099jerusalem.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/1099jerusalem.jpg/340px-1099jerusalem.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:1099jerusalem.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Medieval illustration of capture of Jerusalem during the First Crusade, 1099.</div></div></div>
<p>A messianic <a href="/wiki/Karaite_Judaism" title="Karaite Judaism">Karaite</a> movement to gather in Jerusalem took place at the turn of the millennium, leading to a "Golden Age" of Karaite scholarship there, which was only terminated by the Crusades.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[176]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Crusader.2FAyyubid_period"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Crusader/Ayyubid_period">Crusader/Ayyubid period</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Jerusalem_during_the_Kingdom_of_Jerusalem" title="History of Jerusalem during the Kingdom of Jerusalem">History of Jerusalem during the Kingdom of Jerusalem</a></div>
<p>In 1099, the Fatimid ruler expelled the native Christian population before Jerusalem was <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Jerusalem_(1099)" title="Siege of Jerusalem (1099)">besieged</a> by the soldiers of the <a href="/wiki/First_Crusade" title="First Crusade">First Crusade</a>. After taking the solidly defended city by assault, the Crusaders massacred most of its Muslim and Jewish inhabitants, and made it the capital of their <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Jerusalem" title="Kingdom of Jerusalem">Kingdom of Jerusalem</a>. The city, which had been virtually emptied, was recolonized by a variegated inflow of <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">Greeks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bulgarians" title="Bulgarians">Bulgarians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hungarians" title="Hungarians">Hungarians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Georgians" title="Georgians">Georgians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Armenians" title="Armenians">Armenians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Syrians" title="Syrians">Syrians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Egyptians" title="Egyptians">Egyptians</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nestorians" title="Nestorians">Nestorians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maronites" title="Maronites">Maronites</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jacob_Baradeus" title="Jacob Baradeus">Jacobite</a> Miaphysites, <a href="/wiki/Copts" title="Copts">Copts</a> and others, to block the return of the surviving Muslims and Jews. The north-eastern quarter was repopulated with Eastern Christians from the Transjordan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[177]</a></sup> As a result, by 1099 Jerusalem's population had climbed back to some 30,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[178]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="The material near this tag failed verification of its source citation(s). (October 2017)">failed verification</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>In 1187, the city was wrested from the Crusaders by <a href="/wiki/Saladin" title="Saladin">Saladin</a> who permitted Jews and Muslims to return and settle in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-century1_185-0"><a href="#cite_note-century1-185">[179]</a></sup> Under the terms of surrender, once ransomed, 60,000 Franks were expelled. The Eastern Christian populace was permitted to stay.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[180]</a></sup> Under the <a href="/wiki/Ayyubid_dynasty" title="Ayyubid dynasty">Ayyubid dynasty</a> of Saladin, a period of huge investment began in the construction of houses, markets, <a href="/wiki/Hammam" title="Hammam">public baths</a>, and pilgrim hostels as well as the establishment of religious endowments. However, for most of the 13th century, Jerusalem declined to the status of a village due to city's fall of strategic value and Ayyubid internecine struggles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[181]</a></sup>
</p><p>From 1229 to 1244, Jerusalem peacefully reverted to Christian control as a result of a 1229 treaty agreed between the crusading <a href="/wiki/Frederick_II,_Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor">Holy Roman Emperor Frederick II</a> and <a href="/wiki/Al-Kamil" title="Al-Kamil">al-Kamil</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ayyubid_dynasty" title="Ayyubid dynasty">Ayyubid</a> <a href="/wiki/Sultan" title="Sultan">sultan</a> of <a href="/wiki/Egypt_in_the_Middle_Ages" title="Egypt in the Middle Ages">Egypt</a>, that ended the <a href="/wiki/Sixth_Crusade" title="Sixth Crusade">Sixth Crusade</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Addington01a_188-0"><a href="#cite_note-Addington01a-188">[182]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pringle01a_189-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pringle01a-189">[183]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wharton01a_190-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wharton01a-190">[184]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Askari01a_191-0"><a href="#cite_note-Askari01a-191">[185]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Maoz01a_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-Maoz01a-192">[186]</a></sup> The Ayyubids retained control of the Muslim holy places, and Arab sources suggest that Frederick was not permitted to restore Jerusalem's fortifications.
</p><p>In 1244, <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Jerusalem_(1244)" title="Siege of Jerusalem (1244)">Jerusalem was sacked</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Khwarazmian_army_between_1231_and_1246" title="Khwarazmian army between 1231 and 1246">Khwarezmian Tatars</a>, who decimated the city's Christian population and drove out the Jews.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gilbert25_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gilbert25-193">[187]</a></sup> The Khwarezmian Tatars were driven out by the Ayyubids in 1247.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mamluk_period">Mamluk period</span></h3>
<p>From 1260<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bloom_194-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bloom-194">[188]</a></sup> to 1516/17, Jerusalem was ruled by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mamluk_Sultanate_(Cairo)" title="Mamluk Sultanate (Cairo)">Mamluks</a>. In the wider region and until around 1300, many clashes occurred between the Mamluks on one side, and the crusaders and the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_raids_into_Palestine" title="Mongol raids into Palestine">Mongols</a>, on the other side. The area also suffered from many earthquakes and <a href="/wiki/Black_Death" title="Black Death">black plague</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[189]</a></sup> When <a href="/wiki/Nachmanides" title="Nachmanides">Nachmanides</a> visited in 1267 he found only two Jewish families, in a population of 2,000, 300 of whom were Christians, in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[190]</a></sup> The well-known and far-traveled <a href="/wiki/Lexicography" title="Lexicography">lexicographer</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fairuzabadi" title="Fairuzabadi">Fairuzabadi</a> (1329â1414) spent ten years in Jerusalem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[191]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 13th to 15th centuries was a period of frequent building activity in the city, as evidenced by the 90 remaining structures from this time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bloom_194-1"><a href="#cite_note-Bloom-194">[188]</a></sup> The city was also a significant site of <a href="/wiki/Mamluk_architecture" title="Mamluk architecture">Mamluk architectural</a> patronage. The types of structures built included <a href="/wiki/Madrasa" title="Madrasa">madrasas</a>, libraries, <a href="/wiki/Bimaristan" title="Bimaristan">hospitals</a>, <a href="/wiki/Caravanserai" title="Caravanserai">caravanserais</a>, fountains (or <a href="/wiki/Sebil_(fountain)" title="Sebil (fountain)">sabils</a>), and public baths.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bloom_194-2"><a href="#cite_note-Bloom-194">[188]</a></sup> Much of the building activity was concentrated around the edges of the Temple Mount or Haram al-Sharif.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bloom_194-3"><a href="#cite_note-Bloom-194">[188]</a></sup> Old gates to the Haram lost importance and new gates were built,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bloom_194-4"><a href="#cite_note-Bloom-194">[188]</a></sup> while significant parts of the northern and western porticoes along the edge of the Temple Mount plaza were built or rebuilt in this period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Burgoyne_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-Burgoyne-198">[192]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tankiz" title="Tankiz">Tankiz</a>, the Mamluk <a href="/wiki/Emir" title="Emir">amir</a> in charge of <a href="/wiki/Syria_(region)" title="Syria (region)">Syria</a> during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Al-Nasir_Muhammad" title="Al-Nasir Muhammad">al-Nasir Muhammad</a>, built a new market called <i>Suq al-Qattatin</i> (Cotton Market) in 1336â7, along with the gate known as <i>Bab al-Qattanin</i> (Cotton Gate), which gave access to the Temple Mount from this market.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bloom_194-5"><a href="#cite_note-Bloom-194">[188]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Burgoyne_198-1"><a href="#cite_note-Burgoyne-198">[192]</a></sup> The late Mamluk sultan <a href="/wiki/Qaitbay" title="Qaitbay">al-Ashraf Qaytbay</a> also took interest in the city. He commissioned the building of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Madrasa_Al-Ashrafiyya" title="Madrasa Al-Ashrafiyya">Madrasa al-Ashrafiyya</a>, completed in 1482, and the nearby <a href="/wiki/Fountain_of_Qayt_Bay" title="Fountain of Qayt Bay">Sabil of Qaytbay</a>, built shortly after in 1482; both were located on the Temple Mount.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bloom_194-6"><a href="#cite_note-Bloom-194">[188]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Burgoyne_198-2"><a href="#cite_note-Burgoyne-198">[192]</a></sup> Qaytbay's monuments were the last major Mamluk constructions in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Burgoyne_198-3"><a href="#cite_note-Burgoyne-198">[192]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 589â612">:â589â612â</span></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Peregrinatio_in_terram_sanctam_Jerusalem_map_in_color.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2925" data-file-width="5000" decoding="async" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Peregrinatio_in_terram_sanctam_Jerusalem_map_in_color.jpg/220px-Peregrinatio_in_terram_sanctam_Jerusalem_map_in_color.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Peregrinatio_in_terram_sanctam_Jerusalem_map_in_color.jpg/330px-Peregrinatio_in_terram_sanctam_Jerusalem_map_in_color.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Peregrinatio_in_terram_sanctam_Jerusalem_map_in_color.jpg/440px-Peregrinatio_in_terram_sanctam_Jerusalem_map_in_color.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Peregrinatio_in_terram_sanctam_Jerusalem_map_in_color.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Jerusalem, from 'Peregrinatio in Terram Sanctam' by <a href="/wiki/Bernhard_von_Breidenbach" title="Bernhard von Breidenbach">Bernhard von Breydenbach</a> (1486)</div></div></div>
<h3><span id="Ottoman_period_.2816th.E2.80.9319th_centuries.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Ottoman_period_(16thâ19th_centuries)">Ottoman period (16thâ19th centuries)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Expansion_of_Jerusalem_in_the_19th_century" title="Expansion of Jerusalem in the 19th century">Expansion of Jerusalem in the 19th century</a></div><p>In 1517, Jerusalem and its environs fell to the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Turks</a>, who generally remained in control until 1917.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-century1_185-1"><a href="#cite_note-century1-185">[179]</a></sup> Jerusalem enjoyed a prosperous period of renewal and peace under <a href="/wiki/Suleiman_the_Magnificent" title="Suleiman the Magnificent">Suleiman the Magnificent</a>âincluding the rebuilding of magnificent walls around the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Old_City_(Jerusalem)" title="Old City (Jerusalem)">Old City</a>. Throughout much of Ottoman rule, Jerusalem remained a provincial, if religiously important center, and did not straddle the main trade route between <a href="/wiki/Damascus" title="Damascus">Damascus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[193]</a></sup> The English reference book <i>Modern history or the present state of all nations</i>, written in 1744, stated that "Jerusalem is still reckoned the capital city of Palestine, though much fallen from its ancient grandeaur".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[194]</a></sup></p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:View_of_Jerusalem_c._1600_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="569" data-file-width="972" decoding="async" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/View_of_Jerusalem_c._1600_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-View_of_Jerusalem_c._1600_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/View_of_Jerusalem_c._1600_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-View_of_Jerusalem_c._1600_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/View_of_Jerusalem_c._1600_%28cropped%29.jpg/440px-View_of_Jerusalem_c._1600_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:View_of_Jerusalem_c._1600_(cropped).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Topographic_map" title="Topographic map">Topographic map</a> of the city, <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">â1600</span>.</div></div></div><p>The Ottomans brought many innovations: modern postal systems run by the various consulates and regular stagecoach and carriage services were among the first signs of modernization in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hujiOttoman_201-0"><a href="#cite_note-hujiOttoman-201">[195]</a></sup> In the mid 19th century, the Ottomans constructed the first paved road from Jaffa to Jerusalem, and by 1892 the railroad had reached the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hujiOttoman_201-1"><a href="#cite_note-hujiOttoman-201">[195]</a></sup>
</p><p>With the annexation of Jerusalem by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_of_Egypt" title="Muhammad Ali of Egypt">Muhammad Ali of Egypt</a> in 1831, foreign missions and consulates began to establish a foothold in the city. In 1836, <a href="/wiki/Ibrahim_Pasha_of_Egypt" title="Ibrahim Pasha of Egypt">Ibrahim Pasha</a> allowed Jerusalem's Jewish residents to restore four major synagogues, among them the <a href="/wiki/Hurva_Synagogue" title="Hurva Synagogue">Hurva</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gilbert37_202-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gilbert37-202">[196]</a></sup> In the countrywide <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Peasants%27_Revolt_of_1834_(Palestine)" title="Peasants' Revolt of 1834 (Palestine)">Peasants' Revolt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Qasim_al-Ahmad" title="Qasim al-Ahmad">Qasim al-Ahmad</a> led his forces from <a href="/wiki/Nablus" title="Nablus">Nablus</a> and attacked Jerusalem, aided by the <a href="/wiki/Abu_Ghosh" title="Abu Ghosh">Abu Ghosh</a> clan, and entered the city on 31 May 1834. The Christians and Jews of Jerusalem were subjected to attacks. Ibrahim's Egyptian army routed Qasim's forces in Jerusalem the following month.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[197]</a></sup>
</p><p>
Ottoman rule was reinstated in 1840, but many Egyptian Muslims remained in Jerusalem and Jews from <a href="/wiki/Algiers" title="Algiers">Algiers</a> and North Africa began to settle in the city in growing numbers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gilbert37_202-1"><a href="#cite_note-Gilbert37-202">[196]</a></sup> In the 1840s and 1850s, the international powers began a tug-of-war in Palestine as they sought to extend their protection over the region's religious minorities, a struggle carried out mainly through consular representatives in Jerusalem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[198]</a></sup> According to the Prussian consul, the population in 1845 was 16,410, with 7,120 Jews, 5,000 Muslims, 3,390 Christians, 800 Turkish soldiers and 100 Europeans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gilbert37_202-2"><a href="#cite_note-Gilbert37-202">[196]</a></sup> The volume of Christian pilgrims increased under the Ottomans, doubling the city's population around Easter time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gilbert35_205-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gilbert35-205">[199]</a></sup></p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jerusalem_1844_Aqsa.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="945" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="173" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Jerusalem_1844_Aqsa.jpg/220px-Jerusalem_1844_Aqsa.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Jerusalem_1844_Aqsa.jpg/330px-Jerusalem_1844_Aqsa.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Jerusalem_1844_Aqsa.jpg/440px-Jerusalem_1844_Aqsa.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jerusalem_1844_Aqsa.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>1844 <a href="/wiki/Daguerreotype" title="Daguerreotype">daguerreotype</a> by <a href="/wiki/Joseph-Philibert_Girault_de_Prangey" title="Joseph-Philibert Girault de Prangey">Joseph-Philibert Girault de Prangey</a> (the earliest photograph of the city).</div></div></div><p>In the 1860s, new neighborhoods <a href="/wiki/Expansion_of_Jerusalem_in_the_19th_century" title="Expansion of Jerusalem in the 19th century">began to develop</a> outside the Old City walls to house pilgrims and relieve the intense overcrowding and poor sanitation inside the city. The <a href="/wiki/Russian_Compound" title="Russian Compound">Russian Compound</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mishkenot_Sha%27ananim" title="Mishkenot Sha'ananim">Mishkenot Sha'ananim</a> were founded in 1860,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[200]</a></sup> followed by many others that included <a href="/wiki/Mahane_Israel" title="Mahane Israel">Mahane Israel</a> (1868), <a href="/wiki/Nahalat_Shiv%27a" title="Nahalat Shiv'a">Nahalat Shiv'a</a> (1869), <a href="/wiki/German_Colony,_Jerusalem" title="German Colony, Jerusalem">German Colony</a> (1872), <a href="/wiki/Beit_David" title="Beit David">Beit David</a> (1873), <a href="/wiki/Mea_Shearim" title="Mea Shearim">Mea Shearim</a> (1874), <a href="/wiki/Shimon_HaTzadik" title="Shimon HaTzadik">Shimon HaZadiq</a> (1876), <a href="/wiki/Beit_Ya%27akov,_Jerusalem" title="Beit Ya'akov, Jerusalem">Beit Ya'aqov</a> (1877), <a href="/wiki/Abu_Tor" title="Abu Tor">Abu Tor</a> (1880s), <a href="/wiki/American_Colony,_Jerusalem" title="American Colony, Jerusalem">American-Swedish Colony</a> (1882), <a href="/wiki/Yemin_Moshe" title="Yemin Moshe">Yemin Moshe</a> (1891), and <a href="/wiki/Mamilla" title="Mamilla">Mamilla</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wadi_al-Joz" title="Wadi al-Joz">Wadi al-Joz</a> around the turn of the century. In 1867 an American Missionary reports an estimated population of Jerusalem of 'above' 15,000, with 4,000 to 5,000 Jews and 6,000 Muslims. Every year there were 5,000 to 6,000 Russian Christian Pilgrims.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[201]</a></sup> In 1872 Jerusalem became the center of a special administrative district, independent of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Syria_Vilayet" title="Syria Vilayet">Syria Vilayet</a> and under the direct authority of <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a> called the <a href="/wiki/Mutasarrifate_of_Jerusalem" title="Mutasarrifate of Jerusalem">Mutasarrifate of Jerusalem</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[202]</a></sup>
</p><p>The great number of Christian orphans resulting from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1860_Mount_Lebanon_civil_war" title="1860 Mount Lebanon civil war">1860 civil war in Mount Lebanon and the Damascus massacre</a> led in the same year to the opening of the <a href="/wiki/Evangelical_Church_in_Germany#History" title="Evangelical Church in Germany">German Protestant</a> Syrian Orphanage, better known as the <a href="/wiki/Schneller_Orphanage" title="Schneller Orphanage">Schneller Orphanage</a> after its founder.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[203]</a></sup> Until the 1880s there were no formal Jewish orphanages in Jerusalem, as families generally took care of each other. In 1881 the <a href="/wiki/Diskin_Orphanage" title="Diskin Orphanage">Diskin Orphanage</a> was founded in Jerusalem with the arrival of Jewish children orphaned by a Russian <a href="/wiki/Pogrom" title="Pogrom">pogrom</a>. Other orphanages founded in Jerusalem at the beginning of the 20th century were <a href="/wiki/Zion_Blumenthal_Orphanage" title="Zion Blumenthal Orphanage">Zion Blumenthal Orphanage</a> (1900) and <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=General_Israel_Orphan%27s_Home_for_Girls&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="General Israel Orphan's Home for Girls (page does not exist)">General Israel Orphan's Home for Girls</a> (1902).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[204]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px"><div style="width: 235px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 230px;"><div style="margin:33px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%D7%9E%D7%92%D7%93%D7%9C_%D7%93%D7%95%D7%93-%D7%97%D7%9F_%D7%97%D7%A0%D7%94_%D7%A0%D7%97%D7%95%D7%9D.jpg" title="Tower of David citadel and the Ottoman walls"><img alt="Tower of David citadel and the Ottoman walls" data-file-height="1368" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="134" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/%D7%9E%D7%92%D7%93%D7%9C_%D7%93%D7%95%D7%93-%D7%97%D7%9F_%D7%97%D7%A0%D7%94_%D7%A0%D7%97%D7%95%D7%9D.jpg/200px-%D7%9E%D7%92%D7%93%D7%9C_%D7%93%D7%95%D7%93-%D7%97%D7%9F_%D7%97%D7%A0%D7%94_%D7%A0%D7%97%D7%95%D7%9D.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/%D7%9E%D7%92%D7%93%D7%9C_%D7%93%D7%95%D7%93-%D7%97%D7%9F_%D7%97%D7%A0%D7%94_%D7%A0%D7%97%D7%95%D7%9D.jpg/300px-%D7%9E%D7%92%D7%93%D7%9C_%D7%93%D7%95%D7%93-%D7%97%D7%9F_%D7%97%D7%A0%D7%94_%D7%A0%D7%97%D7%95%D7%9D.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/%D7%9E%D7%92%D7%93%D7%9C_%D7%93%D7%95%D7%93-%D7%97%D7%9F_%D7%97%D7%A0%D7%94_%D7%A0%D7%97%D7%95%D7%9D.jpg/400px-%D7%9E%D7%92%D7%93%D7%9C_%D7%93%D7%95%D7%93-%D7%97%D7%9F_%D7%97%D7%A0%D7%94_%D7%A0%D7%97%D7%95%D7%9D.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">

</p>

</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px"><div style="width: 235px">

<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px"><div style="width: 235px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 230px;"><div style="margin:19.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mishkenot_Sha%27ananim_1.jpg" title="Guesthouse in Mishkenot Sha'ananim, the first Jewish neighborhood built outside the walls of the Old City of Jerusalem (1860), on a hill directly across from Mount Zion."><img alt="Guesthouse in Mishkenot Sha'ananim, the first Jewish neighborhood built outside the walls of the Old City of Jerusalem (1860), on a hill directly across from Mount Zion." data-file-height="581" data-file-width="722" decoding="async" height="161" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Mishkenot_Sha%27ananim_1.jpg/200px-Mishkenot_Sha%27ananim_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Mishkenot_Sha%27ananim_1.jpg/300px-Mishkenot_Sha%27ananim_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Mishkenot_Sha%27ananim_1.jpg/400px-Mishkenot_Sha%27ananim_1.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div></div>
