</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul>
<h3><span id="British_Mandate_.281917.E2.80.931948.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="British_Mandate_(1917â1948)">British Mandate (1917â1948)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Subdistrict,_Mandatory_Palestine" title="Jerusalem Subdistrict, Mandatory Palestine">Jerusalem Subdistrict, Mandatory Palestine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:First_Town_Plan_of_Jerusalem,_1918,_William_McLean.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1760" data-file-width="1844" decoding="async" height="210" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/First_Town_Plan_of_Jerusalem%2C_1918%2C_William_McLean.jpg/220px-First_Town_Plan_of_Jerusalem%2C_1918%2C_William_McLean.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/First_Town_Plan_of_Jerusalem%2C_1918%2C_William_McLean.jpg/330px-First_Town_Plan_of_Jerusalem%2C_1918%2C_William_McLean.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/First_Town_Plan_of_Jerusalem%2C_1918%2C_William_McLean.jpg/440px-First_Town_Plan_of_Jerusalem%2C_1918%2C_William_McLean.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:First_Town_Plan_of_Jerusalem,_1918,_William_McLean.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/William_McLean_(civil_servant)" title="William McLean (civil servant)">William McLean's</a> 1918 plan was the first urban planning scheme for Jerusalem. It laid the foundations for what became <a href="/wiki/West_Jerusalem" title="West Jerusalem">West Jerusalem</a> and East Jerusalem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[205]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:VE_day_Jerusalem_1945.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3163" data-file-width="4369" decoding="async" height="159" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/VE_day_Jerusalem_1945.jpg/220px-VE_day_Jerusalem_1945.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/VE_day_Jerusalem_1945.jpg/330px-VE_day_Jerusalem_1945.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/VE_day_Jerusalem_1945.jpg/440px-VE_day_Jerusalem_1945.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:VE_day_Jerusalem_1945.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Jerusalem on <a href="/wiki/Victory_in_Europe_Day" title="Victory in Europe Day">VE Day</a>, 8 May 1945.</div></div></div>
<p>In 1917 after the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_of_Jerusalem_(1917)" title="Battle of Jerusalem (1917)">Battle of Jerusalem</a>, the <a href="/wiki/British_Army" title="British Army">British Army</a>, led by <a href="/wiki/Edmund_Allenby,_1st_Viscount_Allenby" title="Edmund Allenby, 1st Viscount Allenby">General Edmund Allenby</a>, captured the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[206]</a></sup> In 1922, the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a> at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lausanne_Conference_of_1922%E2%80%9323" title="Lausanne Conference of 1922â23">Conference of Lausanne</a> entrusted the United Kingdom to <a href="/wiki/Mandatory_Palestine" title="Mandatory Palestine">administer</a> <a href="/wiki/Palestine_(region)" title="Palestine (region)">Palestine</a>, neighbouring <a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Transjordan" title="Emirate of Transjordan">Transjordan</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Mandate_of_Mesopotamia" title="British Mandate of Mesopotamia">Iraq</a> beyond it.
</p><p>The British had to deal with a conflicting demand that was rooted in Ottoman rule. Agreements for the supply of water, electricity, and the construction of a tramway systemâall under concessions granted by the Ottoman authoritiesâhad been signed by the city of Jerusalem and a Greek citizen, Euripides Mavromatis, on 27 January 1914. Work under these concessions had not begun and, by the end of the war the British occupying forces refused to recognize their validity. Mavromatis claimed that his concessions overlapped with the Auja Concession that the government had awarded to Rutenberg in 1921 and that he had been deprived of his legal rights. The Mavromatis concession, in effect despite earlier British attempts to abolish it, covered Jerusalem and other localities (e.g., Bethlehem) within a radius of 20Â km (12Â mi) around the Church of the Holy Sepulchre.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[207]</a></sup>
</p><p>From 1922 to 1948 the total population of the city rose from 52,000 to 165,000, comprising two-thirds Jews and one-third Arabs (Muslims and Christians).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[208]</a></sup> Relations between Arab Christians and Muslims and the growing Jewish population in Jerusalem deteriorated, resulting in recurring unrest. In Jerusalem, in particular, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1920_Palestine_riots" title="1920 Palestine riots">Arab riots occurred in 1920</a> and <a href="/wiki/1929_Palestine_riots" title="1929 Palestine riots">in 1929</a>. Under the British, new garden suburbs were built in the western and northern parts of the city<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[209]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BIUmandate_216-0"><a href="#cite_note-BIUmandate-216">[210]</a></sup> and institutions of higher learning such as the <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_University_of_Jerusalem" title="Hebrew University of Jerusalem">Hebrew University</a> were founded.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hujiHistory_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-hujiHistory-217">[211]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Divided_city:_Jordanian_and_Israeli_rule_.281948.E2.80.931967.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Divided_city:_Jordanian_and_Israeli_rule_(1948â1967)">Divided city: Jordanian and Israeli rule (1948â1967)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Battle_for_Jerusalem" title="Battle for Jerusalem">Battle for Jerusalem</a> and <a href="/wiki/City_Line_(Jerusalem)" title="City Line (Jerusalem)">City Line (Jerusalem)</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Corpus_separatum_(Jerusalem)" title="Corpus separatum (Jerusalem)">Corpus separatum (Jerusalem)</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_Resolution_194" title="United Nations General Assembly Resolution 194">United Nations General Assembly Resolution 194</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jordanian_annexation_of_the_West_Bank" title="Jordanian annexation of the West Bank">Jordanian annexation of the West Bank</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1045330069" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="sidebar nomobile nowraplinks" style="font-size:100%; line-height:1em"><tbody><tr><td class="sidebar-pretitle"><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations"><img alt="United Nations" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Flag_of_the_United_Nations.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_Nations.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Flag_of_the_United_Nations.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_United_Nations.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Flag_of_the_United_Nations.svg/45px-Flag_of_the_United_Nations.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Partition_Plan_for_Palestine" title="United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine">United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine</a></td></tr><tr><th class="sidebar-title-with-pretitle"><a href="/wiki/Corpus_separatum_(Jerusalem)" title="Corpus separatum (Jerusalem)">Jerusalem Corpus Separatum</a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">
<div class="floatright noresize" role="img" style="width: 358px; line-height: 1; text-align: center; background-color: #ffffff; position: relative;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jerusalem_Corpus_Separatum_(1947_map).png"><img alt="" data-file-height="644" data-file-width="596" decoding="async" height="387" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Jerusalem_Corpus_Separatum_%281947_map%29.png/358px-Jerusalem_Corpus_Separatum_%281947_map%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Jerusalem_Corpus_Separatum_%281947_map%29.png/537px-Jerusalem_Corpus_Separatum_%281947_map%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/3d/Jerusalem_Corpus_Separatum_%281947_map%29.png 2x" width="358"/></a>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:129px; top:59.2px"><a href="/wiki/Lifta" title="Lifta">Lifta</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:170.4px; top:42.4px"><a href="/wiki/Shuafat" title="Shuafat">Shu'fat</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:211.8px; top:87.4px"><b><a class="mw-selflink selflink">JERUSALEM</a></b></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:223.8px; top:101.2px"><a href="/wiki/At-Tur_(Mount_of_Olives)" title="At-Tur (Mount of Olives)">at-Tur</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:248.4px; top:120.4px"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Al-Eizariya" title="Al-Eizariya">al-Eizariya</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:259.8px; top:130px"><a href="/wiki/Abu_Dis" title="Abu Dis">Abu Dis</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:197.4px; top:128.8px"><a href="/wiki/Silwan" title="Silwan">Silwan</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:204px; top:180.4px"><a href="/wiki/Sur_Baher" title="Sur Baher">Sur Baher</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:196.8px; top:207.4px"><a href="/wiki/Umm_Tuba" title="Umm Tuba">Umm Tuba</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:165px; top:190px"><a href="/wiki/Ramat_Rachel" title="Ramat Rachel">Ramat Rahel</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:114px; top:184px"><a href="/wiki/Sharafat,_East_Jerusalem" title="Sharafat, East Jerusalem">Sharafat</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:134.4px; top:177.4px"><a href="/wiki/Beit_Safafa" title="Beit Safafa">Beit Safafa</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:87px; top:237.4px"><a href="/wiki/Beit_Jala" title="Beit Jala">Beit Jala</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:159px; top:224.8px"><b><a href="/wiki/Bethlehem" title="Bethlehem">BETHLEHEM</a></b></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:166.2px; top:263.2px"><a href="/wiki/Beit_Sahour" title="Beit Sahour">Beit Sahur</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:93.6px; top:147.4px"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manahat" title="Manahat">al-Maliha</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:49.2px; top:121px"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ein_Kerem" title="Ein Kerem">Ein Karim</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:72px; top:96.4px"><a href="/wiki/Deir_Yassin" title="Deir Yassin">Deir Yassin</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:59.4px; top:85px"><a href="/wiki/Motza" title="Motza">Motza</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:226.8px; top:60.4px"><a href="/wiki/Isawiya" title="Isawiya">al-'Isawiya</a></div>
</div></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:JerusalemCS" title="Template:JerusalemCS"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:JerusalemCS" title="Template talk:JerusalemCS"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:JerusalemCS&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><br/>
As the British Mandate for Palestine was expiring, the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Partition_Plan_for_Palestine" title="United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine">1947 UN Partition Plan</a> recommended "the creation of a special international regime in the City of Jerusalem, constituting it as a <i><a href="/wiki/Corpus_separatum_(Jerusalem)" title="Corpus separatum (Jerusalem)">corpus separatum</a></i> under the administration of the UN."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[212]</a></sup> The international regime (which also included the city of <a href="/wiki/Bethlehem" title="Bethlehem">Bethlehem</a>) was to remain in force for a period of ten years, whereupon a referendum was to be held in which the residents were to decide the future regime of their city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[213]</a></sup> However, this plan was not implemented, as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1948_Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_war" title="1948 ArabâIsraeli war">1948 war erupted</a>, while the British withdrew from Palestine and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Declaration_of_Independence_(Israel)" title="Declaration of Independence (Israel)">Israel declared its independence</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lapidoth_220-0"><a href="#cite_note-lapidoth-220">[214]</a></sup>
</p><p>In contradiction to the Partition Plan, which envisioned a <a href="/wiki/Corpus_separatum_(Jerusalem)" title="Corpus separatum (Jerusalem)">city</a> separated from the Arab state and the Jewish state, Israel took control of the area which later would become West Jerusalem, along with <a href="/wiki/1948_Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_War#1949_Armistice_Agreements" title="1948 ArabâIsraeli War">major parts of the Arab territory allotted to the future Arab State</a>; Jordan took control of East Jerusalem, along with the West Bank. The war led to displacement of Arab and Jewish populations in the city. The 1,500 residents of the <a href="/wiki/Jewish_Quarter_(Jerusalem)" title="Jewish Quarter (Jerusalem)">Jewish Quarter</a> of the Old City were expelled and a few hundred taken prisoner when the Arab Legion captured the quarter on 28 May.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[215]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[216]</a></sup> Arab residents of <a href="/wiki/Katamon" title="Katamon">Katamon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Talbiya" title="Talbiya">Talbiya</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/German_Colony,_Jerusalem" title="German Colony, Jerusalem">German Colony</a> were driven from their homes. By the time of the armistice that ended active fighting, Israel had control of 12 of Jerusalem's 15 Arab residential quarters. An estimated minimum of 30,000 people had become refugees.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[217]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[218]</a></sup>
</p><p>The war of 1948 resulted in the division of Jerusalem, so that the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Old_City_(Jerusalem)" title="Old City (Jerusalem)">old walled city</a> lay entirely on the Jordanian side of the <a href="/wiki/Green_Line_(Israel)" title="Green Line (Israel)">line</a>. A no-man's land between East and West Jerusalem came into being in November 1948: <a href="/wiki/Moshe_Dayan" title="Moshe Dayan">Moshe Dayan</a>, commander of the Israeli forces in Jerusalem, met with his Jordanian counterpart <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abdullah_el-Tell" title="Abdullah el-Tell">Abdullah el-Tell</a> in a deserted house in Jerusalem's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Musrara,_Jerusalem" title="Musrara, Jerusalem">Musrara</a> neighborhood and marked out their respective positions: Israel's position in red and Jordan's in green. This rough map, which was not meant as an official one, became the final <a href="/wiki/Green_Line_(Israel)" title="Green Line (Israel)">line</a> in the <a href="/wiki/1949_Armistice_Agreements" title="1949 Armistice Agreements">1949 Armistice Agreements</a>, which divided the city and left <a href="/wiki/Mount_Scopus" title="Mount Scopus">Mount Scopus</a> as an Israeli <a href="/wiki/Enclave_and_exclave" title="Enclave and exclave">exclave</a> inside East Jerusalem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[219]</a></sup> Barbed wire and concrete barriers ran down the center of the city, passing close by <a href="/wiki/Jaffa_Gate" title="Jaffa Gate">Jaffa Gate</a> on the western side of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Old_City_(Jerusalem)" title="Old City (Jerusalem)">old walled city</a>, and a crossing point was established at <a href="/wiki/Mandelbaum_Gate" title="Mandelbaum Gate">Mandelbaum Gate</a> slightly to the north of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Old_City_(Jerusalem)" title="Old City (Jerusalem)">old walled city</a>. Military skirmishes frequently threatened the ceasefire.
</p><p>After the establishment of the state of Israel, Jerusalem was declared its capital city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[220]</a></sup> Jordan formally annexed East Jerusalem in 1950, subjecting it to Jordanian law, and in 1953 declared it the "second capital" of Jordan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lapidoth_220-1"><a href="#cite_note-lapidoth-220">[214]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-birzeit_227-0"><a href="#cite_note-birzeit-227">[221]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[222]</a></sup> Only the United Kingdom and <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> formally recognized such annexation, which, in regard to Jerusalem, was on a <i>de facto</i> basis.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[223]</a></sup> Some scholars argue that the view that Pakistan recognized Jordan's annexation is dubious.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[224]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[225]</a></sup>
</p><p>After 1948, since the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Old_City_(Jerusalem)" title="Old City (Jerusalem)">old walled city</a> in its entirety was to the east of the armistice line, <a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan">Jordan</a> was able to take control of all the holy places therein. While Muslim holy sites were maintained and renovated,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Reiter_232-0"><a href="#cite_note-Reiter-232">[226]</a></sup> contrary to the terms of the armistice agreement, Jews were denied access to Jewish holy sites, many of which were destroyed or desecrated. Jordan allowed only very limited access to Christian holy sites,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[227]</a></sup> and restrictions were imposed on the <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_Christians" title="Palestinian Christians">Christian population</a> that led many to leave the city. Of the 58 synagogues in the Old City, half were either razed or converted to stables and hen-houses over the course of the next 19 years, including the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hurva" title="Hurva">Hurva</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Tiferet_Yisrael_Synagogue" title="Tiferet Yisrael Synagogue">Tiferet Yisrael Synagogue</a>. The 3,000-year-old<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cem_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-cem-234">[228]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mount_of_Olives_Jewish_Cemetery" title="Mount of Olives Jewish Cemetery">Mount of Olives Jewish Cemetery</a> was desecrated, with gravestones used to build roads, latrines and Jordanian army fortifications. 38,000 graves in the Jewish Cemetery were destroyed, and Jews were forbidden from being buried there.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[229]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tessler_236-0"><a href="#cite_note-Tessler-236">[230]</a></sup> The Western Wall was transformed into an exclusively Muslim holy site associated with <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Al-Buraq" title="Al-Buraq">al-Buraq</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ricca_237-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ricca-237">[231]</a></sup> Israeli authorities neglected to protect the tombs in the Muslim <a href="/wiki/Mamilla_Cemetery" title="Mamilla Cemetery">Mamilla Cemetery</a> in West Jerusalem, which contains the remains of figures from the early Islamic period,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[232]</a></sup> facilitating the creation of a parking lot and public lavatories in 1964.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[233]</a></sup> Many other historic and religiously significant buildings were demolished and replaced by modern structures during the Jordanian occupation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[234]</a></sup> During this period, the Dome of the Rock and the Al-Aqsa Mosque underwent major renovations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[235]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the 1948 war, the Jewish residents of Eastern Jerusalem <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jewish_refugees" title="Jewish refugees">were expelled</a> by Jordan's <a href="/wiki/Arab_Legion" title="Arab Legion">Arab Legion</a>. Jordan allowed Arab Palestinian refugees from the war to settle in the vacated <a href="/wiki/Jewish_Quarter_(Jerusalem)" title="Jewish Quarter (Jerusalem)">Jewish Quarter</a>, which became known as <i>Harat al-Sharaf</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Oest_242-0"><a href="#cite_note-Oest-242">[236]</a></sup> In 1966 the Jordanian authorities relocated 500 of them to the <a href="/wiki/Shuafat" title="Shuafat">Shua'fat refugee camp</a> as part of plans to turn the Jewish quarter into a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Public_park" title="Public park">public park</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[237]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[238]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px"><div style="width: 235px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 230px;"><div style="margin:19.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mandelbaum_Gate_Jerusalem.jpg" title="Israeli policemen meet a Jordanian Legionnaire near the Mandelbaum Gate (c.â1950)."><img alt="Israeli policemen meet a Jordanian Legionnaire near the Mandelbaum Gate (c.â1950)." data-file-height="600" data-file-width="744" decoding="async" height="161" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Mandelbaum_Gate_Jerusalem.jpg/200px-Mandelbaum_Gate_Jerusalem.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Mandelbaum_Gate_Jerusalem.jpg/300px-Mandelbaum_Gate_Jerusalem.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Mandelbaum_Gate_Jerusalem.jpg/400px-Mandelbaum_Gate_Jerusalem.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Israeli policemen meet a <a href="/wiki/Arab_Legion" title="Arab Legion">Jordanian Legionnaire</a> near the <a href="/wiki/Mandelbaum_Gate" title="Mandelbaum Gate">Mandelbaum Gate</a> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">â1950</span>).
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px"><div style="width: 235px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 230px;"><div style="margin:33px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:King_Hussein_flying_over_Temple_Mount_when_it_was_under_Jordanian_control.jpg" title="King Hussein of Jordan flying over the Temple Mount in East Jerusalem when it was under Jordanian control, 1965."><img alt="King Hussein of Jordan flying over the Temple Mount in East Jerusalem when it was under Jordanian control, 1965." data-file-height="1478" data-file-width="2200" decoding="async" height="134" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/King_Hussein_flying_over_Temple_Mount_when_it_was_under_Jordanian_control.jpg/200px-King_Hussein_flying_over_Temple_Mount_when_it_was_under_Jordanian_control.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/King_Hussein_flying_over_Temple_Mount_when_it_was_under_Jordanian_control.jpg/300px-King_Hussein_flying_over_Temple_Mount_when_it_was_under_Jordanian_control.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/King_Hussein_flying_over_Temple_Mount_when_it_was_under_Jordanian_control.jpg/400px-King_Hussein_flying_over_Temple_Mount_when_it_was_under_Jordanian_control.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Hussein_of_Jordan" title="Hussein of Jordan">King Hussein</a> of <a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan">Jordan</a> flying over the <a href="/wiki/Temple_Mount" title="Temple Mount">Temple Mount</a> in East Jerusalem when it was under Jordanian control, 1965.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul>
<h3><span id="Israeli_rule_.281967.E2.80.93present.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Israeli_rule_(1967âpresent)">Israeli rule (1967âpresent)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Israeli_annexation_of_East_Jerusalem" title="Israeli annexation of East Jerusalem">Israeli annexation of East Jerusalem</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:EastJerusalemMap-en.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="589" data-file-width="384" decoding="async" height="337" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/EastJerusalemMap-en.svg/220px-EastJerusalemMap-en.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/EastJerusalemMap-en.svg/330px-EastJerusalemMap-en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/EastJerusalemMap-en.svg/440px-EastJerusalemMap-en.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:EastJerusalemMap-en.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map of <a href="/wiki/East_Jerusalem" title="East Jerusalem">East Jerusalem</a> (2010)</div></div></div>
<p>In 1967, despite Israeli pleas that Jordan remain neutral during the <a href="/wiki/Six-Day_War" title="Six-Day War">Six-Day War</a>, <a href="/wiki/Six-Day_War#West_Bank" title="Six-Day War">Jordan, which had concluded a defense agreement with Egypt on 30 May 1967, attacked Israeli-held West Jerusalem on the war's second day</a>. After hand-to-hand fighting between Israeli and Jordanian soldiers on the Temple Mount, the <a href="/wiki/Israel_Defense_Forces" title="Israel Defense Forces">Israel Defense Forces</a> captured East Jerusalem, along with the entire West Bank. On 27 June 1967, three weeks after the war ended, in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reunification_of_Jerusalem" title="Reunification of Jerusalem">reunification of Jerusalem</a>, Israel extended its law and jurisdiction to East Jerusalem, including the city's Christian and Muslim holy sites, along with some nearby West Bank territory which comprised 28 Palestinian villages, incorporating it into the Jerusalem Municipality,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[239]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[240]</a></sup> although it carefully avoided using the term "annexation". On 10 July, Foreign Minister Abba Eban explained to the UN Secretary General: "<i>The term 'annexation' which was used by supporters of the vote is not accurate. The steps that were taken [by Israel] relate to the integration of Jerusalem in administrative and municipal areas, and served as a legal basis for the protection of the holy places of Jerusalem."</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[241]</a></sup> Israel conducted a census of Arab residents in the areas annexed. Residents were given permanent residency status and the option of applying for Israeli citizenship. Since 1967, new Jewish residential areas have mushroomed in the eastern sector, while no new Palestinian neighbourhoods have been created.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thrall_248-0"><a href="#cite_note-Thrall-248">[242]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jewish and Christian access to the holy sites inside the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Old_City_(Jerusalem)" title="Old City (Jerusalem)">old walled city</a> was restored. Israel left the Temple Mount under the jurisdiction of an Islamic <i><a href="/wiki/Waqf" title="Waqf">waqf</a></i>, but opened the Western Wall to Jewish access. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Moroccan_Quarter" title="Moroccan Quarter">Moroccan Quarter</a>, which was located adjacent to the Western Wall, was evacuated and razed<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[243]</a></sup> to make way for a plaza for those visiting the wall.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[244]</a></sup> On 18 April 1968, an expropriation order by the Israeli Ministry of Finance more than doubled the size of the Jewish Quarter, evicting its Arab residents and seizing over 700 buildings of which 105 belonged to Jewish inhabitants prior to the Jordanian occupation of the city.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The order designated these areas for public use, but they were intended for Jews alone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[245]</a></sup> The government offered 200 <a href="/wiki/Jordanian_dinar" title="Jordanian dinar">Jordanian dinars</a> to each displaced Arab family.
</p><p>After the Six-Day War the population of Jerusalem increased by 196%. The Jewish population grew by 155%, while the Arab population grew by 314%. The proportion of the Jewish population fell from 74% in 1967 to 72% in 1980, to 68% in 2000, and to 64% in 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[246]</a></sup> Israeli Agriculture Minister <a href="/wiki/Ariel_Sharon" title="Ariel Sharon">Ariel Sharon</a> proposed building a ring of Jewish neighborhoods around the city's eastern edges. The plan was intended to <a href="/wiki/Judaization_of_Jerusalem" title="Judaization of Jerusalem">make East Jerusalem more Jewish</a> and prevent it from becoming part of an urban Palestinian bloc stretching from <a href="/wiki/Bethlehem" title="Bethlehem">Bethlehem</a> to <a href="/wiki/Ramallah" title="Ramallah">Ramallah</a>. On 2 October 1977, the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Israel" title="Cabinet of Israel">Israeli cabinet</a> approved the plan, and seven neighborhoods were subsequently built on the city's eastern edges. They became known as the <a href="/wiki/Ring_Neighborhoods,_Jerusalem" title="Ring Neighborhoods, Jerusalem">Ring Neighborhoods</a>. Other Jewish neighborhoods were built within East Jerusalem, and Israeli Jews also settled in Arab neighborhoods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253"><a href="#cite_note-253">[247]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[248]</a></sup>
</p><p>The annexation of East Jerusalem was met with international criticism. The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Israel)" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Israel)">Israeli Foreign Ministry</a> disputes that the annexation of Jerusalem was a violation of international law.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[249]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[250]</a></sup> The final status of Jerusalem has been one of the most important areas of discord between Palestinian and Israeli negotiators for peace. Areas of discord have included whether the Palestinian flag can be raised over areas of Palestinian custodianship and the specificity of Israeli and Palestinian territorial borders.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Abbas-090900_257-0"><a href="#cite_note-Abbas-090900-257">[251]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_status">Political status</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Positions_on_Jerusalem" title="Positions on Jerusalem">Positions on Jerusalem</a></div>
<p>From 1923 until 1948, Jerusalem served as the administrative capital of <a href="/wiki/Mandatory_Palestine" title="Mandatory Palestine">Mandatory Palestine</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[252]</a></sup>
</p><p>From 1949 until 1967, West Jerusalem served as Israel's capital, but was not recognized as such internationally because <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_Resolution_194" title="United Nations General Assembly Resolution 194">UN General Assembly Resolution 194</a> envisaged Jerusalem as an <a href="/wiki/International_city" title="International city">international city</a>. As a result of the Six-Day War in 1967, the whole of Jerusalem <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reunification_of_Jerusalem" title="Reunification of Jerusalem">came under Israeli control</a>. On 27 June 1967, the government of <a href="/wiki/Levi_Eshkol" title="Levi Eshkol">Levi Eshkol</a> extended Israeli law and jurisdiction to East Jerusalem, but agreed that administration of the Temple Mount compound would be maintained by the <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Islamic_Waqf" title="Jerusalem Islamic Waqf">Jordanian waqf</a>, under the Jordanian Ministry of Religious Endowments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[253]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1988, Israel ordered the closure of <a href="/wiki/Orient_House" title="Orient House">Orient House</a>, home of the Arab Studies Society, but also the headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/Palestine_Liberation_Organization" title="Palestine Liberation Organization">Palestine Liberation Organization</a>, for security reasons. The building reopened in 1992 as a Palestinian guesthouse.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[254]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[255]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Oslo_Accords" title="Oslo Accords">Oslo Accords</a> stated that the final status of Jerusalem would be determined by negotiations with the <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_National_Authority" title="Palestinian National Authority">Palestinian Authority</a>. The accords banned any official Palestinian presence in the city until a final peace agreement, but provided for the opening of a Palestinian trade office in East Jerusalem. The Palestinian Authority regards East Jerusalem as the capital of a future Palestinian state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-umd_262-0"><a href="#cite_note-umd-262">[256]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[257]</a></sup> President <a href="/wiki/Mahmoud_Abbas" title="Mahmoud Abbas">Mahmoud Abbas</a> has said that any agreement that did not include East Jerusalem as the capital of Palestine would be unacceptable.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[258]</a></sup> Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has similarly stated that Jerusalem would remain the undivided capital of Israel. Due to its proximity to the city, especially the Temple Mount, <a href="/wiki/Abu_Dis" title="Abu Dis">Abu Dis</a>, a Palestinian suburb of Jerusalem, has been proposed as the future capital of a Palestinian state by Israel. Israel has not incorporated Abu Dis within its security wall around Jerusalem. The Palestinian Authority has built a possible future parliament building for the <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_Legislative_Council" title="Palestinian Legislative Council">Palestinian Legislative Council</a> in the town, and its Jerusalem Affairs Offices are all located in Abu Dis.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[259]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="International_status">International status</span></h3>
<p>While the international community regards East Jerusalem, including the entire Old City, as part of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Occupied_Palestinian_territories" title="Occupied Palestinian territories">occupied Palestinian territories</a>, neither part, West or East Jerusalem, is recognized as part of the territory of Israel or the <a href="/wiki/State_of_Palestine" title="State of Palestine">State of Palestine</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[260]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[261]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[262]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[263]</a></sup> Under the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Partition_Plan_for_Palestine" title="United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine">United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine</a> adopted by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/General_Assembly_of_the_United_Nations" title="General Assembly of the United Nations">General Assembly of the United Nations</a> in 1947, Jerusalem was envisaged to become a <a href="/wiki/Corpus_separatum_(Jerusalem)" title="Corpus separatum (Jerusalem)">corpus separatum</a> administered by the United Nations. In the war of 1948, the western part of the city was occupied by forces of the nascent state of Israel, while the eastern part was occupied by Jordan. The international community largely considers the legal status of Jerusalem to derive from the partition plan, and correspondingly refuses to recognize Israeli sovereignty over the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[264]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Status_under_Israeli_rule">Status under Israeli rule</span></h3>
<p>Following the 1967 Six-Day War, Israel extended its jurisdiction and administration over East Jerusalem, establishing new municipal borders.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:PikiWiki_Israel_44557_Art_of_Israel.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2306" data-file-width="3079" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/PikiWiki_Israel_44557_Art_of_Israel.JPG/220px-PikiWiki_Israel_44557_Art_of_Israel.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/PikiWiki_Israel_44557_Art_of_Israel.JPG/330px-PikiWiki_Israel_44557_Art_of_Israel.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/PikiWiki_Israel_44557_Art_of_Israel.JPG/440px-PikiWiki_Israel_44557_Art_of_Israel.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:PikiWiki_Israel_44557_Art_of_Israel.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Knesset" title="Knesset">Knesset</a> houses the <a href="/wiki/Legislature" title="Legislature">legislature</a> of Israel</div></div></div>
<p>In 2010, Israel approved legislation giving Jerusalem the highest national priority status in Israel. The law prioritized construction throughout the city, and offered grants and tax benefits to residents to make housing, infrastructure, education, employment, business, tourism, and cultural events more affordable. Communications Minister <a href="/wiki/Moshe_Kahlon" title="Moshe Kahlon">Moshe Kahlon</a> said that the bill sent "a clear, unequivocal political message that Jerusalem will not be divided", and that "all those within the Palestinian and international community who expect the current Israeli government to accept any demands regarding Israel's sovereignty over its capital are mistaken and misleading".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[265]</a></sup>
</p><p>
The status of the city, and especially its holy places, remains a core issue in the IsraeliâPalestinian conflict. The Israeli government has approved building plans in the Muslim Quarter of the Old City<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[266]</a></sup> in order to expand the Jewish presence in East Jerusalem, while some Islamic leaders have made claims that Jews have no historical connection to Jerusalem, alleging that the 2,500-year-old Western Wall was constructed as part of a mosque.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[267]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[268]</a></sup> Palestinians regard Jerusalem as the capital of the <a href="/wiki/State_of_Palestine" title="State of Palestine">State of Palestine</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PalestinianPosition_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-PalestinianPosition-275">[269]</a></sup> and the city's borders have been the subject of bilateral talks. A team of experts assembled by the then Israeli Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Ehud_Barak" title="Ehud Barak">Ehud Barak</a> in 2000 concluded that the city must be divided, since Israel had failed to achieve any of its national aims there.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Amirav01a_276-0"><a href="#cite_note-Amirav01a-276">[270]</a></sup> However, Israeli Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Netanyahu" title="Benjamin Netanyahu">Benjamin Netanyahu</a> said in 2014 that "Jerusalem will never be divided".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[271]</a></sup> A poll conducted in June 2013 found that 74% of Israeli Jews reject the idea of a Palestinian capital in any portion of Jerusalem, though 72% of the public regarded it as a divided city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[272]</a></sup> A poll conducted by Palestinian Center for Public Opinion and American Pechter Middle East Polls for the Council on Foreign Relations, among East Jerusalem Arab residents in 2011 revealed that 39% of East Jerusalem Arab residents would prefer Israeli citizenship contrary to 31% who opted for Palestinian citizenship. According to the poll, 40% of Palestinian residents would prefer to leave their neighborhoods if they would be placed under Palestinian rule.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[273]</a></sup></p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2767" data-file-width="4217" decoding="async" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg/220px-Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg/330px-Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg/440px-Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Israel" title="Supreme Court of Israel">Supreme Court of Israel</a></div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Jerusalem_as_capital_of_Israel">Jerusalem as capital of Israel</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hutz.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1712" data-file-width="2288" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Hutz.JPG/220px-Hutz.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Hutz.JPG/330px-Hutz.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Hutz.JPG/440px-Hutz.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hutz.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Foreign_Ministry_of_Israel" title="Foreign Ministry of Israel">Israeli Foreign Ministry</a> building</div></div></div>
<p>On 5 December 1949, Israel's first Prime Minister, <a href="/wiki/David_Ben-Gurion" title="David Ben-Gurion">David Ben-Gurion</a>, proclaimed Jerusalem as Israel's "eternal" and "sacred" capital, and eight days later specified that only the war had "compelled" the Israeli leadership "to establish the seat of Government in Tel Aviv", while "for the State of Israel there has always been and always will be one capital only â Jerusalem the Eternal", and that after the war, efforts had been ongoing for creating the conditions for "the Knesset... returning to Jerusalem."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BGurion_280-0"><a href="#cite_note-BGurion-280">[274]</a></sup> This indeed took place, and since the beginning of 1950 all branches of the <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Israel" title="Politics of Israel">Israeli government</a>â<a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Israel#Legislative_branch" title="Politics of Israel">legislative</a>, <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Israel#Judicial_system" title="Politics of Israel">judicial</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Israel#Prime_Ministers_and_governments_in_the_last_ten_years" title="Politics of Israel">executive</a>âhave resided there, except for the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defense_(Israel)" title="Ministry of Defense (Israel)">Ministry of Defense</a>, which is located at <a href="/wiki/HaKirya" title="HaKirya">HaKirya</a> in <a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv" title="Tel Aviv">Tel Aviv</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[275]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JTA_282-0"><a href="#cite_note-JTA-282">[276]</a></sup> At the time of Ben Gurion's proclamations and the ensuing Knesset vote of 24 January 1950,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JTA_282-1"><a href="#cite_note-JTA-282">[276]</a></sup> Jerusalem was divided between Israel and Jordan, and thus the proclamation only applied to West Jerusalem.
</p><p>In July 1980, Israel passed the <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Law" title="Jerusalem Law">Jerusalem Law</a> as <a href="/wiki/Basic_Laws_of_Israel" title="Basic Laws of Israel">Basic Law</a>. The law declared Jerusalem the "complete and united" capital of Israel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-basiclaw_283-0"><a href="#cite_note-basiclaw-283">[277]</a></sup> The Jerusalem Law was condemned by the international community, which did not recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel. The United Nations Security Council passed <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_478" title="United Nations Security Council Resolution 478">Resolution 478</a> on 20 August 1980, which declared that the Jerusalem Law is <i>"a violation of international law"</i>, is <i>"null and void and must be rescinded forthwith"</i>. Member states were called upon to withdraw their diplomatic representation from Jerusalem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[278]</a></sup> Following the resolution, 22 of the 24 countries that previously had their embassy in (West) Jerusalem relocated them in Tel Aviv, where many embassies already resided prior to Resolution 478. <a href="/wiki/Costa_Rica" title="Costa Rica">Costa Rica</a> and <a href="/wiki/El_Salvador" title="El Salvador">El Salvador</a> followed in 2006.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[279]</a></sup> There are two embassiesâUnited States and Guatemalaâand two consulates located within the city limits of Jerusalem, and two <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin American</a> states maintain embassies in the <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_District" title="Jerusalem District">Jerusalem District</a> <a href="/wiki/Local_council_(Israel)" title="Local council (Israel)">town</a> of <a href="/wiki/Mevaseret_Zion" title="Mevaseret Zion">Mevaseret Zion</a> (<a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paraguay" title="Paraguay">Paraguay</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-embassies_286-0"><a href="#cite_note-embassies-286">[280]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[281]</a></sup> There are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Consulates-General_in_Jerusalem" title="List of Consulates-General in Jerusalem">a number of consulates-general</a> located in Jerusalem, which work primarily either with Israel, or the Palestinian authorities.
</p><p>In 1995, the United States Congress passed the <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Embassy_Act" title="Jerusalem Embassy Act">Jerusalem Embassy Act</a>, which required, subject to conditions, that its embassy be moved from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[282]</a></sup> On 6 December 2017 <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">U.S. President</a> <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> officially <a href="/wiki/United_States_recognition_of_Jerusalem_as_capital_of_Israel" title="United States recognition of Jerusalem as capital of Israel">recognized Jerusalem</a> as Israel's capital and announced his intention to move the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Embassy_of_the_United_States,_Tel_Aviv" title="Embassy of the United States, Tel Aviv">American embassy</a> to Jerusalem, reversing decades of United States policy on the issue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[283]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[284]</a></sup> The move was criticized by many nations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[285]</a></sup> A resolution condemning the US decision was supported by all the 14 other members of the UN Security Council, but was vetoed by the US on 18 December 2017,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[286]</a></sup> and a subsequent resolution condemning the US decision was passed in the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly" title="United Nations General Assembly">United Nations General Assembly</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[287]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[288]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[289]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[290]</a></sup> On 14 May 2018, the United States officially moved the location of <a href="/wiki/Embassy_of_the_United_States,_Jerusalem" title="Embassy of the United States, Jerusalem">its embassy to Jerusalem</a>, transforming its Tel Aviv location into a consulate. Due to the general lack of international recognition of Jerusalem as Israel's capital, some non-Israeli media outlets use Tel Aviv as a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Metonym" title="Metonym">metonym</a> for Israel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[291]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[292]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[293]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[294]</a></sup>
</p><p>In April 2017, the Russian Foreign Ministry announced it viewed Western Jerusalem as Israel's capital in the context of UN-approved principles which include the status of East Jerusalem as the capital of the future Palestinian state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[295]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[296]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[297]</a></sup> On 15 December 2018, <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">Australia</a> officially recognized West Jerusalem as Israel's capital, but said their embassy in Tel Aviv would stay until a two-state resolution was settled.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[298]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_precinct_and_national_institutions">Government precinct and national institutions</span></h4>
<p>Many national institutions of Israel are located in <a href="/wiki/Kiryat_HaMemshala" title="Kiryat HaMemshala">Kiryat HaMemshala</a> in <a href="/wiki/Givat_Ram" title="Givat Ram">Givat Ram</a> in Jerusalem as a part of the <a href="/wiki/Kiryat_HaLeom" title="Kiryat HaLeom">Kiryat HaLeom</a> project which is intended to create a large district that will house most government agencies and national cultural institutions. Some government buildings are located in <a href="/wiki/Kiryat_Menachem_Begin" title="Kiryat Menachem Begin">Kiryat Menachem Begin</a>. The city is home to the Knesset,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[299]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Israel" title="Supreme Court of Israel">Supreme Court</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[300]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_Israel" title="Bank of Israel">Bank of Israel</a>, the <a href="/wiki/National_Headquarters_of_the_Israel_Police" title="National Headquarters of the Israel Police">National Headquarters of the Israel Police</a>, the official residences of the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Israel" title="President of Israel">President</a> and <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Israel" title="Prime Minister of Israel">Prime Minister</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Israel" title="Cabinet of Israel">Cabinet</a>, and all ministries except for the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defense_(Israel)" title="Ministry of Defense (Israel)">Ministry of Defense</a> (which is located in central Tel Aviv's <a href="/wiki/HaKirya" title="HaKirya">HaKirya</a> district) and the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Agriculture_and_Rural_Development_(Israel)" title="Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (Israel)">Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development</a> (which is located in <a href="/wiki/Rishon_LeZion" title="Rishon LeZion">Rishon LeZion</a>, in the wider Tel Aviv <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_area" title="Metropolitan area">metropolitan area</a>, near <a href="/wiki/Beit_Dagan" title="Beit Dagan">Beit Dagan</a>).
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Jerusalem_as_capital_of_Palestine">Jerusalem as capital of Palestine</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/East_Jerusalem#Jerusalem_as_capital" title="East Jerusalem">East Jerusalem Â§Â Jerusalem as capital</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Orient_House.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="568" data-file-width="790" decoding="async" height="158" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Orient_House.jpg/220px-Orient_House.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Orient_House.jpg/330px-Orient_House.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Orient_House.jpg/440px-Orient_House.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Orient_House.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Orient_House" title="Orient House">Orient House</a> in East Jerusalem that served as the headquarters of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PLO" title="PLO">PLO</a> in the 1980s and 1990s. It was closed by Israel in 2001, two days after the <a href="/wiki/Sbarro_restaurant_suicide_bombing" title="Sbarro restaurant suicide bombing">Sbarro restaurant suicide bombing</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_National_Authority" title="Palestinian National Authority">Palestinian National Authority</a> views East Jerusalem as occupied territory according to <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_242" title="United Nations Security Council Resolution 242">United Nations Security Council Resolution 242</a>. The Palestinian Authority claims Jerusalem, including the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Haram_al-Sharif" title="Haram al-Sharif">Haram al-Sharif</a>, as the capital of the State of Palestine,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PalestinianPosition_275-1"><a href="#cite_note-PalestinianPosition-275">[269]</a></sup> The PLO claims that West Jerusalem is also subject to permanent status negotiations. However, it has stated that it would be willing to consider alternative solutions, such as making Jerusalem an <a href="/wiki/Open_city" title="Open city">open city</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PLO-NAD_307-0"><a href="#cite_note-PLO-NAD-307">[301]</a></sup>
</p><p>The PLO's position is that East Jerusalem, as defined by the pre-1967 municipal boundaries, shall be the capital of Palestine and West Jerusalem the capital of Israel, with each state enjoying full sovereignty over its respective part of the city and with its own municipality. A joint <i>development council</i> would be responsible for coordinated development.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[302]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some states, such as <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[303]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[304]</a></sup> recognize the Palestinian state with East Jerusalem as its capital. <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_Resolution_58/292" title="United Nations General Assembly Resolution 58/292">United Nations General Assembly Resolution 58/292</a> affirmed that the Palestinian people have the right to sovereignty over East Jerusalem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[305]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Municipal_administration">Municipal administration</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Municipality_of_Jerusalem" title="Municipality of Jerusalem">Municipality of Jerusalem</a></div>
<p>The Jerusalem <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/City_council" title="City council">City Council</a> is a body of 31 elected members headed by the mayor, who serves a five-year term and appoints eight deputies. The former mayor of Jerusalem, <a href="/wiki/Uri_Lupolianski" title="Uri Lupolianski">Uri Lupolianski</a>, was elected in 2003.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-corridors_312-0"><a href="#cite_note-corridors-312">[306]</a></sup> In the November 2008 city elections, <a href="/wiki/Nir_Barkat" title="Nir Barkat">Nir Barkat</a> was elected. In November 2018, <a href="/wiki/Moshe_Lion" title="Moshe Lion">Moshe Lion</a> was elected mayor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[307]</a></sup>
</p><p>Apart from the mayor and his deputies, City Council members receive no salaries and work on a voluntary basis. The longest-serving Jerusalem mayor was <a href="/wiki/Teddy_Kollek" title="Teddy Kollek">Teddy Kollek</a>, who spent 28 yearsâsix consecutive termsâin office. Most of the meetings of the Jerusalem City Council are private, but each month, it holds a session that is open to the public.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-corridors_312-1"><a href="#cite_note-corridors-312">[306]</a></sup> Within the city council, religious political parties form an especially powerful faction, accounting for the majority of its seats.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[308]</a></sup> The headquarters of the Jerusalem Municipality and the mayor's office are at <a href="/wiki/Safra_Square" title="Safra Square">Safra Square</a> (<i>Kikar Safra</i>) on <a href="/wiki/Jaffa_Road" title="Jaffa Road">Jaffa Road</a>. The municipal complex, comprising two modern buildings and ten renovated historic buildings surrounding a large plaza, opened in 1993 when it moved from the <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Old_Town_Hall" title="Jerusalem Old Town Hall">old town hall</a> building built by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mandate_Palestine" title="Mandate Palestine">Mandate authorities</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[309]</a></sup> The city falls under the <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_District" title="Jerusalem District">Jerusalem District</a>, with Jerusalem as the district's capital. 37% of the population is Palestinian, but in 2014 not more than 10% of tax revenues were allocated for them. In East Jerusalem, 52% of the land was excluded from development, 35% designated for Jewish settlements, and 13% for Palestinian use, almost all of which was already built on.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thrall_248-1"><a href="#cite_note-Thrall-248">[242]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;overflow:hidden;width:auto;max-width:1008px"><div class="thumbinner"><div class="noresize" style="overflow:auto"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Panor%C3%A1mica_de_Jerusal%C3%A9n_desde_el_Monte_de_los_Olivos.jpg" title="Panorama of the Temple Mount (Haram al-Sharif or Al-Aqsa compound), including Al-Aqsa Mosque, and Dome of the Rock, from the Mount of Olives"><img alt="" data-file-height="1894" data-file-width="14002" decoding="async" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Panor%C3%A1mica_de_Jerusal%C3%A9n_desde_el_Monte_de_los_Olivos.jpg/1000px-Panor%C3%A1mica_de_Jerusal%C3%A9n_desde_el_Monte_de_los_Olivos.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Panor%C3%A1mica_de_Jerusal%C3%A9n_desde_el_Monte_de_los_Olivos.jpg/1500px-Panor%C3%A1mica_de_Jerusal%C3%A9n_desde_el_Monte_de_los_Olivos.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Panor%C3%A1mica_de_Jerusal%C3%A9n_desde_el_Monte_de_los_Olivos.jpg/2000px-Panor%C3%A1mica_de_Jerusal%C3%A9n_desde_el_Monte_de_los_Olivos.jpg 2x" width="1000"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="text-align:center"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Panor%C3%A1mica_de_Jerusal%C3%A9n_desde_el_Monte_de_los_Olivos.jpg" title="File:PanorÃ¡mica de JerusalÃ©n desde el Monte de los Olivos.jpg"> </a></div>Panorama of the <a href="/wiki/Temple_Mount" title="Temple Mount">Temple Mount</a> (Haram al-Sharif or Al-Aqsa compound), including <a href="/wiki/Al-Aqsa_Mosque" title="Al-Aqsa Mosque">Al-Aqsa Mosque</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Dome_of_the_Rock" title="Dome of the Rock">Dome of the Rock</a>, from the <a href="/wiki/Mount_of_Olives" title="Mount of Olives">Mount of Olives</a></div></div></div>
<p>Jerusalem is situated on the southern spur of a <a href="/wiki/Plateau" title="Plateau">plateau</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Judaean_Mountains" title="Judaean Mountains">Judaean Mountains</a>, which include the <a href="/wiki/Mount_of_Olives" title="Mount of Olives">Mount of Olives</a> (East) and <a href="/wiki/Mount_Scopus" title="Mount Scopus">Mount Scopus</a> (North East). The elevation of the Old City is approximately 760Â m (2,490Â ft).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[310]</a></sup> The whole of Jerusalem is surrounded by valleys and dry <a href="/wiki/Wadi" title="Wadi">riverbeds</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Wadi" title="Wadi">wadis</a></i>). The <a href="/wiki/Kidron_Valley" title="Kidron Valley">Kidron</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gehenna" title="Gehenna">Hinnom</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tyropoeon_Valley" title="Tyropoeon Valley">Tyropoeon</a> Valleys intersect in an area just south of the Old City of Jerusalem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bergsohn_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-bergsohn-317">[311]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Kidron_Valley" title="Kidron Valley">Kidron Valley</a> runs to the east of the Old City and separates the <a href="/wiki/Mount_of_Olives" title="Mount of Olives">Mount of Olives</a> from the city proper. Along the southern side of old Jerusalem is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gehenna" title="Gehenna">Valley of Hinnom</a>, a steep ravine associated in biblical <a href="/wiki/Eschatology" title="Eschatology">eschatology</a> with the concept of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gehenna" title="Gehenna">Gehenna</a> or <a href="/wiki/Hell" title="Hell">Hell</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[312]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Tyropoeon_Valley" title="Tyropoeon Valley">Tyropoeon Valley</a> commenced in the northwest near the <a href="/wiki/Damascus_Gate" title="Damascus Gate">Damascus Gate</a>, ran south-southeasterly through the center of the Old City down to the <a href="/wiki/Pool_of_Siloam" title="Pool of Siloam">Pool of Siloam</a>, and divided the lower part into two hills, the Temple Mount to the east, and the rest of the city to the west (the lower and the upper cities described by <a href="/wiki/Josephus" title="Josephus">Josephus</a>). Today, this valley is hidden by debris that has accumulated over the centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bergsohn_317-1"><a href="#cite_note-bergsohn-317">[311]</a></sup>
In biblical times, Jerusalem was surrounded by forests of almond, olive and pine trees. Over centuries of warfare and neglect, these forests were destroyed. Farmers in the Jerusalem region thus built stone terraces along the slopes to hold back the soil, a feature still very much in evidence in the Jerusalem landscape.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2010)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Water supply has always been a major problem in Jerusalem, as attested to by the intricate network of ancient <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aqueduct_(watercourse)" title="Aqueduct (watercourse)">aqueducts</a>, tunnels, pools and cisterns found in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[313]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jerusalem is 60Â km (37Â mi)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[314]</a></sup> east of <a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv" title="Tel Aviv">Tel Aviv</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a>. On the opposite side of the city, approximately 35Â km (22Â mi)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[315]</a></sup> away, is the <a href="/wiki/Dead_Sea" title="Dead Sea">Dead Sea</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Extremes_on_Earth" title="Extremes on Earth">lowest body of water</a> on Earth. Neighboring cities and towns include <a href="/wiki/Bethlehem" title="Bethlehem">Bethlehem</a> and <a href="/wiki/Beit_Jala" title="Beit Jala">Beit Jala</a> to the south, <a href="/wiki/Abu_Dis" title="Abu Dis">Abu Dis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ma%27ale_Adumim" title="Ma'ale Adumim">Ma'ale Adumim</a> to the east, <a href="/wiki/Mevaseret_Zion" title="Mevaseret Zion">Mevaseret Zion</a> to the west, and <a href="/wiki/Ramallah" title="Ramallah">Ramallah</a> and <a href="/wiki/Giv%27at_Ze%27ev" title="Giv'at Ze'ev">Giv'at Ze'ev</a> to the north.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[316]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-map_323-0"><a href="#cite_note-map-323">[317]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[318]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Mount_Herzl" title="Mount Herzl">Mount Herzl</a>, at the western side of the city near the <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Forest" title="Jerusalem Forest">Jerusalem Forest</a>, serves as the national cemetery of Israel.
</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px"><div style="width: 235px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 230px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jerusalem,_Israel.JPG" title="Astronauts' view of Jerusalem."><img alt="Astronauts' view of Jerusalem." data-file-height="435" data-file-width="639" decoding="async" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Jerusalem%2C_Israel.JPG/199px-Jerusalem%2C_Israel.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Jerusalem%2C_Israel.JPG/298px-Jerusalem%2C_Israel.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Jerusalem%2C_Israel.JPG/397px-Jerusalem%2C_Israel.JPG 2x" width="199"/></a></div></div>

</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px"><div style="width: 235px">

</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%D7%94%D7%A2%D7%99%D7%A8_%D7%94%D7%A2%D7%AA%D7%99%D7%A7%D7%94_%D7%91%D7%99%D7%A8%D7%95%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%99%D7%9D_%D7%91%D7%9C%D7%91%D7%9F.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1066" data-file-width="1599" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/%D7%94%D7%A2%D7%99%D7%A8_%D7%94%D7%A2%D7%AA%D7%99%D7%A7%D7%94_%D7%91%D7%99%D7%A8%D7%95%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%99%D7%9D_%D7%91%D7%9C%D7%91%D7%9F.jpg/220px-%D7%94%D7%A2%D7%99%D7%A8_%D7%94%D7%A2%D7%AA%D7%99%D7%A7%D7%94_%D7%91%D7%99%D7%A8%D7%95%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%99%D7%9D_%D7%91%D7%9C%D7%91%D7%9F.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/%D7%94%D7%A2%D7%99%D7%A8_%D7%94%D7%A2%D7%AA%D7%99%D7%A7%D7%94_%D7%91%D7%99%D7%A8%D7%95%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%99%D7%9D_%D7%91%D7%9C%D7%91%D7%9F.jpg/330px-%D7%94%D7%A2%D7%99%D7%A8_%D7%94%D7%A2%D7%AA%D7%99%D7%A7%D7%94_%D7%91%D7%99%D7%A8%D7%95%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%99%D7%9D_%D7%91%D7%9C%D7%91%D7%9F.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/%D7%94%D7%A2%D7%99%D7%A8_%D7%94%D7%A2%D7%AA%D7%99%D7%A7%D7%94_%D7%91%D7%99%D7%A8%D7%95%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%99%D7%9D_%D7%91%D7%9C%D7%91%D7%9F.jpg/440px-%D7%94%D7%A2%D7%99%D7%A8_%D7%94%D7%A2%D7%AA%D7%99%D7%A7%D7%94_%D7%91%D7%99%D7%A8%D7%95%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%99%D7%9D_%D7%91%D7%9C%D7%91%D7%9F.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%D7%94%D7%A2%D7%99%D7%A8_%D7%94%D7%A2%D7%AA%D7%99%D7%A7%D7%94_%D7%91%D7%99%D7%A8%D7%95%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%99%D7%9D_%D7%91%D7%9C%D7%91%D7%9F.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Snow visible on roofs in the Old City of Jerusalem.</div></div></div>
<p>The city is characterized by a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hot-summer_Mediterranean_climate" title="Hot-summer Mediterranean climate">hot-summer Mediterranean climate</a> (<a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="KÃ¶ppen climate classification">KÃ¶ppen</a>: <i>Csa</i>), with hot, dry summers, and mild, wet winters. Snow flurries usually occur once or twice a winter, although the city experiences heavy <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Snowfall" title="Snowfall">snowfall</a> every three to four years, on average, with short-lived accumulation.
</p><p>January is the coldest month of the year, with an average temperature of 9.1Â Â°C (48.4Â Â°F); July and August are the hottest months, with an average temperature of 24.2Â Â°C (75.6Â Â°F), and the summer months are usually rainless. The average annual precipitation is around 537Â mm (21Â in), with rain occurring almost entirely between October and May.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-weather_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-weather-325">[319]</a></sup> Snowfall is rare, and large snowfalls are even more rare.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-snow2013-1_326-0"><a href="#cite_note-snow2013-1-326">[320]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-snow2013-2_327-0"><a href="#cite_note-snow2013-2-327">[321]</a></sup> Jerusalem received over 30Â cm (12Â in) of snow on 13 December 2013, which nearly paralyzed the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-snow2013-1_326-1"><a href="#cite_note-snow2013-1-326">[320]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-snow2013-2_327-1"><a href="#cite_note-snow2013-2-327">[321]</a></sup> A day in Jerusalem has on average, 9.3 sunshine hours. With summers averaging similar temperatures as the coastline, the maritime influence from the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a> is strong, in particular given that Jerusalem is located on a similar latitude as scorching hot deserts not far to its east.
</p><p>The highest recorded temperature in Jerusalem was 44.4Â Â°C (111.9Â Â°F) on 28 and 30 August 1881, and the lowest temperature recorded was â6.7Â Â°C (19.9Â Â°F) on 25 January 1907.
</p><p>Most of the air pollution in Jerusalem comes from vehicular traffic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-friction_328-0"><a href="#cite_note-friction-328">[322]</a></sup> Many main streets in Jerusalem were not built to accommodate such a large volume of traffic, leading to traffic congestion and more <a href="/wiki/Carbon_monoxide" title="Carbon monoxide">carbon monoxide</a> released into the air. Industrial pollution inside the city is sparse, but emissions from factories on the <a href="/wiki/Israeli_coastal_plain" title="Israeli coastal plain">Israeli Mediterranean coast</a> can travel eastward and settle over the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-friction_328-1"><a href="#cite_note-friction-328">[322]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[323]</a></sup>
</p>
<div>

</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographic_history">Demographic history</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographic_history_of_Jerusalem" title="Demographic history of Jerusalem">Demographic history of Jerusalem</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:363px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Demographic_history_of_Jerusalem_by_religion.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1614" data-file-width="2680" decoding="async" height="217" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Demographic_history_of_Jerusalem_by_religion.png/361px-Demographic_history_of_Jerusalem_by_religion.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Demographic_history_of_Jerusalem_by_religion.png/542px-Demographic_history_of_Jerusalem_by_religion.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Demographic_history_of_Jerusalem_by_religion.png/722px-Demographic_history_of_Jerusalem_by_religion.png 2x" width="361"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Demographic_history_of_Jerusalem_by_religion.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Demographic history of Jerusalem by religion based on available data</div></div></div>
<p>Jerusalem's population size and composition has shifted many times over its 5,000-year history. Since medieval times, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Old_City_(Jerusalem)" title="Old City (Jerusalem)">Old City</a> of Jerusalem has been divided into <a href="/wiki/Jewish_Quarter_(Jerusalem)" title="Jewish Quarter (Jerusalem)">Jewish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Muslim_Quarter_(Jerusalem)" title="Muslim Quarter (Jerusalem)">Muslim</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christian_Quarter" title="Christian Quarter">Christian</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Quarter" title="Armenian Quarter">Armenian quarters</a>.
</p><p>Most population data before 1905 is based on estimates, often from foreign travellers or organisations, since previous census data usually covered wider areas such as the <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_District" title="Jerusalem District">Jerusalem District</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335">[329]</a></sup> These estimates suggest that since the end of the <a href="/wiki/Crusades" title="Crusades">Crusades</a>, Muslims formed the largest group in Jerusalem until the mid-nineteenth century.
</p><p>Between 1838 and 1876, a number of estimates exist which conflict as to whether Jews or Muslims were the largest group during this period, and between 1882 and 1922 estimates conflict as to exactly when Jews became an absolute majority of the population.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Current_demographics">Current demographics</span></h3>
<p>In December 2007, Jerusalem had a population of 747,600â63.7% were Jewish, 33.1% Muslim, and 2% Christian.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CBS2008_336-0"><a href="#cite_note-CBS2008-336">[330]</a></sup> At the end of 2005, the population density was 5,750.4/km<sup>2</sup> (14,893/sqÂ mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cbs_337-0"><a href="#cite_note-cbs-337">[331]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[332]</a></sup> According to a study published in 2000, the percentage of Jews in the city's population had been decreasing; this was attributed to a higher Muslim <a href="/wiki/Birth_rate" title="Birth rate">birth rate</a>, and Jewish residents leaving. The study also found that about nine percent of the Old City's 32,488 people were Jews.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[333]</a></sup> Of the Jewish population, 200,000 live in East Jerusalem settlements which are considered illegal under international law.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[334]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2005, 2,850 new immigrants settled in Jerusalem, mostly from the United States, France and the former <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>. In terms of the local population, the number of outgoing residents exceeds the number of incoming residents. In 2005, 16,000 left Jerusalem and only 10,000 moved in.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cbs_337-1"><a href="#cite_note-cbs-337">[331]</a></sup> Nevertheless, the population of Jerusalem continues to rise due to the high birth rate, especially in the <a href="/wiki/Haredi_Judaism" title="Haredi Judaism">Haredi Jewish</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arab_people" title="Arab people">Arab</a> communities. Consequently, the <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">total fertility rate</a> in Jerusalem (4.02) is higher than in Tel Aviv (1.98) and well above the national average of 2.90. The average size of Jerusalem's 180,000 households is 3.8 people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cbs_337-2"><a href="#cite_note-cbs-337">[331]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2005, the total population grew by 13,000 (1.8%)âsimilar to the Israeli national average, but the religious and ethnic composition is shifting.
