While 31% of the Jewish population is made up of children below the age fifteen, the figure for the Arab population is 42%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cbs_337-3"><a href="#cite_note-cbs-337">[331]</a></sup> This would seem to corroborate the observation that the percentage of Jews in Jerusalem has declined over the past four decades. In 1967, Jews accounted for 74 percent of the population, while the figure for 2006 is down nine percent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341">[335]</a></sup> Possible factors are the high cost of housing, fewer job opportunities and the increasingly religious character of the city, although proportionally, young <a href="/wiki/Haredi_Judaism" title="Haredi Judaism">Haredim</a> are leaving in higher numbers.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2009)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The percentage of secular Jews, or those who 'wear their faith lightly' is dropping, with some 20,000 leaving the city over the past seven years (2012). They now number 31% of the population, the same percentage as the rising Haredi population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[336]</a></sup> Many move to the suburbs and coastal cities in search of cheaper housing and a more secular lifestyle.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-drop_343-0"><a href="#cite_note-drop-343">[337]</a></sup>
</p><p>
In 2009, the percentage of Haredim in the city was increasing. As of 2009<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Jerusalem&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, out of 150,100 schoolchildren, 59,900 or 40% are in state-run secular and <a href="/wiki/Religious_Zionism" title="Religious Zionism">National Religious</a> schools, while 90,200 or 60% are in Haredi schools. This correlates with the high number of children in Haredi families.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[338]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[339]</a></sup></p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Israeli_Air_Force_Fly_By._Israel_73rd_Independence_Day,_April_2021._XIV.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1020" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="140" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Israeli_Air_Force_Fly_By._Israel_73rd_Independence_Day%2C_April_2021._XIV.jpg/220px-Israeli_Air_Force_Fly_By._Israel_73rd_Independence_Day%2C_April_2021._XIV.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Israeli_Air_Force_Fly_By._Israel_73rd_Independence_Day%2C_April_2021._XIV.jpg/330px-Israeli_Air_Force_Fly_By._Israel_73rd_Independence_Day%2C_April_2021._XIV.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Israeli_Air_Force_Fly_By._Israel_73rd_Independence_Day%2C_April_2021._XIV.jpg/440px-Israeli_Air_Force_Fly_By._Israel_73rd_Independence_Day%2C_April_2021._XIV.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Israeli_Air_Force_Fly_By._Israel_73rd_Independence_Day,_April_2021._XIV.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Rehavia" title="Rehavia">Rehavia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kiryat_Wolfson" title="Kiryat Wolfson">Kiryat Wolfson</a>, two Jewish neighborhoods, as seen from <a href="/wiki/Givat_Ram" title="Givat Ram">Givat Ram</a></div></div></div><p>While some Israelis avoid Jerusalem for its relative lack of development and religious and political tensions, the city has attracted Palestinians, offering more jobs and opportunity than any city in the <a href="/wiki/West_Bank" title="West Bank">West Bank</a> or <a href="/wiki/Gaza_Strip" title="Gaza Strip">Gaza Strip</a>. Palestinian officials have encouraged Arabs over the years to stay in the city to maintain their claim.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[340]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[341]</a></sup> Palestinians are attracted to the access to jobs, <a href="/wiki/Health_care" title="Health care">healthcare</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Social_security" title="Social security">social security</a>, other benefits, and <a href="/wiki/Quality_of_life" title="Quality of life">quality of life</a> Israel provides to Jerusalem residents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[342]</a></sup> Arab residents of Jerusalem who choose not to have Israeli citizenship are granted an Israeli identity card that allows them to pass through checkpoints with relative ease and to travel throughout Israel, making it easier to find work. Residents also are entitled to the subsidized healthcare and social security benefits Israel provides its citizens, and have the right to vote in municipal elections. Arabs in Jerusalem can send their children to Israeli-run schools, although not every neighborhood has one, and universities. Israeli doctors and highly regarded hospitals such as <a href="/wiki/Hadassah_Medical_Center" title="Hadassah Medical Center">Hadassah Medical Center</a> are available to residents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[343]</a></sup>
</p><p>Demographics and the Jewish-Arab population divide play a major role in the dispute over Jerusalem. In 1998, the <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Development_Authority" title="Jerusalem Development Authority">Jerusalem Development Authority</a> proposed expanding city limits to the west to include more areas heavily populated with Jews.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-laub2006_23-1"><a href="#cite_note-laub2006-23">[20]</a></sup>
</p><p>
Within the past few years, there has been a steady increase in the Jewish birthrate and a steady decrease in the Arab birthrate. In May 2012, it was reported that the Jewish birthrate had overtaken the Arab birthrate. The city's birthrate stands about 4.2 children per Jewish family and 3.9 children per Arab family.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[344]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[345]</a></sup> In addition, increasing numbers of Jewish immigrants chose to settle in Jerusalem. In the last few years, thousands of Palestinians have moved to previously fully Jewish neighborhoods of East Jerusalem, built after the 1967 Six-Day War. In 2007, 1,300 Palestinians lived in the previously exclusively Jewish neighborhood of <a href="/wiki/Pisgat_Ze%27ev" title="Pisgat Ze'ev">Pisgat Ze'ev</a> and constituted three percent of the population in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neve_Ya%27akov" title="Neve Ya'akov">Neve Ya'akov</a>. In the <a href="/wiki/French_Hill" title="French Hill">French Hill</a> neighborhood, Palestinians today constitute one-sixth of the overall population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[346]</a></sup></p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jerusalem_vista.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2446" data-file-width="3264" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Jerusalem_vista.jpg/220px-Jerusalem_vista.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Jerusalem_vista.jpg/330px-Jerusalem_vista.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Jerusalem_vista.jpg/440px-Jerusalem_vista.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jerusalem_vista.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Jarrah" title="Sheikh Jarrah">Sheikh Jarrah</a>, a predominantly Arab neighborhood on the road to <a href="/wiki/Mount_Scopus" title="Mount Scopus">Mount Scopus</a>.</div></div></div><p>At the end of 2008, the population of East Jerusalem was 456,300, comprising 60% of Jerusalem's residents. Of these, 195,500 (43%) were Jews, (comprising 40% of the Jewish population of Jerusalem as a whole), and 260,800 (57%) were Muslim (comprising 98% of the Muslim population of Jerusalem).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353">[347]</a></sup> In 2008, the <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_Central_Bureau_of_Statistics" title="Palestinian Central Bureau of Statistics">Palestinian Central Bureau of Statistics</a> reported the number of Palestinians living in East Jerusalem was 208,000 according to a recently completed census.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-grow_354-0"><a href="#cite_note-grow-354">[348]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jerusalem's Jewish population is overwhelmingly religious. Only 21% of Jewish residents are secular. In addition, <a href="/wiki/Haredi_Judaism" title="Haredi Judaism">Haredi Jews</a> comprise 30% of the city's adult Jewish population. In a phenomenon seen rarely around the world, the percentage of Jewish men who work, 47%, is exceeded by the percentage of Jewish women who work, 50%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355"><a href="#cite_note-355">[349]</a></sup> The young and less religious continue to leave according to a 2016 Central Bureau of Statistics report which noted 6,740 people left. The opening of high speed rail transit to Tel Aviv in 2018 and the New <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Gateway" title="Jerusalem Gateway">Jerusalem Gateway</a> Business District<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[350]</a></sup> currently under construction is designed to alter business, tourism, and hopefully reverse the population exodus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[351]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jerusalem had a population of 804,400 in 2011, of which Jews comprised 499,400 (62.1%), Muslims 281,100 (34.9%), Christians 14,700 (1.8%), and 9,000 (1.1%) were not classified by religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PopRel_25-1"><a href="#cite_note-PopRel-25">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jerusalem had a population of 882,700 in 2016, of which Jews comprised 536,600 (60.8%), Muslims 319,800 (36.2%), Christians 15,800 (1.8%), and 10,300 unclassified (1.2%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PopRel_25-2"><a href="#cite_note-PopRel-25">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p>
According to <a href="/wiki/Peace_Now" title="Peace Now">Peace Now</a>, approvals for building in Israeli settlements in East Jerusalem have expanded by 60% since Trump became U.S. president in 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[352]</a></sup> Since 1991, Palestinians who make up the majority of the residents in the area have only received 30% of the building permits.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[353]</a></sup></p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Armenian_Patriarchate_Road_sign_in_Armenian,_Jerusalem.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1875" data-file-width="3030" decoding="async" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Armenian_Patriarchate_Road_sign_in_Armenian%2C_Jerusalem.jpg/220px-Armenian_Patriarchate_Road_sign_in_Armenian%2C_Jerusalem.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Armenian_Patriarchate_Road_sign_in_Armenian%2C_Jerusalem.jpg/330px-Armenian_Patriarchate_Road_sign_in_Armenian%2C_Jerusalem.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Armenian_Patriarchate_Road_sign_in_Armenian%2C_Jerusalem.jpg/440px-Armenian_Patriarchate_Road_sign_in_Armenian%2C_Jerusalem.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Armenian_Patriarchate_Road_sign_in_Armenian,_Jerusalem.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Sign in <a href="/wiki/Armenian_language" title="Armenian language">Armenian</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Quarter" title="Armenian Quarter">Armenian Quarter</a>.</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urban_planning_issues">Urban planning issues</span></h3>
<p>Critics of efforts to promote a Jewish majority in Jerusalem say that government planning policies are motivated by demographic considerations and seek to limit Arab construction while promoting Jewish construction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[354]</a></sup> According to a <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> report, the number of recorded building violations between 1996 and 2000 was four and half times higher in Jewish neighborhoods but four times fewer demolition orders were issued in West Jerusalem than in East Jerusalem; Arabs in Jerusalem were less likely to receive construction permits than Jews, and "the authorities are much more likely to take action against Palestinian violators" than Jewish violators of the permit process.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-worldbank_361-0"><a href="#cite_note-worldbank-361">[355]</a></sup> In recent years, private Jewish foundations have received permission from the government to develop projects on disputed lands, such as the <a href="/wiki/City_of_David_(archaeological_site)" title="City of David (archaeological site)">City of David archaeological site</a> in the 60% Arab neighborhood of <a href="/wiki/Silwan" title="Silwan">Silwan</a> (adjacent to the Old City),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362">[356]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Museum_of_Tolerance_Jerusalem" title="Museum of Tolerance Jerusalem">Museum of Tolerance</a> on Mamilla Cemetery (adjacent to Zion Square).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-worldbank_361-1"><a href="#cite_note-worldbank-361">[355]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363"><a href="#cite_note-363">[357]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Religious_significance">Religious significance</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religious_significance_of_Jerusalem" title="Religious significance of Jerusalem">Religious significance of Jerusalem</a></div><p>Jerusalem has been sacred to Judaism for roughly 3000 years, to Christianity for around 2000 years, and to Islam for approximately 1400 years. The 2000 Statistical Yearbook of Jerusalem lists 1204 synagogues, 158 churches, and 73 mosques within the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364"><a href="#cite_note-364">[358]</a></sup> Despite efforts to maintain peaceful religious coexistence, some sites, such as the Temple Mount, have been a continuous source of friction and controversy.
</p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:THE_OLD_CITY_JERUSALEM.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4000" data-file-width="6000" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/THE_OLD_CITY_JERUSALEM.JPG/220px-THE_OLD_CITY_JERUSALEM.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/THE_OLD_CITY_JERUSALEM.JPG/330px-THE_OLD_CITY_JERUSALEM.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/THE_OLD_CITY_JERUSALEM.JPG/440px-THE_OLD_CITY_JERUSALEM.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:THE_OLD_CITY_JERUSALEM.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Old_City_(Jerusalem)" title="Old City (Jerusalem)">Old City</a> is home to many sites of seminal <a href="/wiki/Religious_significance_of_Jerusalem" title="Religious significance of Jerusalem">religious importance</a> for the three major <a href="/wiki/Abrahamic_religions" title="Abrahamic religions">Abrahamic religions</a>â<a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a></div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Judaism">Judaism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_in_Judaism" title="Jerusalem in Judaism">Jerusalem in Judaism</a></div>
<p>Jerusalem has been the <a href="/wiki/Four_Holy_Cities" title="Four Holy Cities">holiest city</a> in Judaism and the ancestral and spiritual homeland of the Jewish people since King David proclaimed it his capital in the 10th century BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bible-david_27-1"><a href="#cite_note-bible-david-27">[note 5]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1000BCE_31-1"><a href="#cite_note-1000BCE-31">[26]</a></sup> Without counting its other names, Jerusalem appears in the <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_Bible" title="Hebrew Bible">Hebrew Bible</a> 669 times.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[359]</a></sup> The first section, the <a href="/wiki/Torah" title="Torah">Torah</a> (Pentateuch), only mentions <a href="/wiki/Moriah" title="Moriah">Moriah</a>, but in later parts of the Bible, the city is mentioned explicitly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[360]</a></sup> The Temple Mount, which was the site of Solomon's Temple and the Second Temple, is the holiest site in Judaism and the place Jews turn towards during prayer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[361]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[362]</a></sup> The Western Wall, a remnant of the wall surrounding the Second Temple, is the holiest place where Jews are permitted to pray.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[363]</a></sup> Synagogues around the world are traditionally built with the Holy Ark facing Jerusalem,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[364]</a></sup> and Arks within Jerusalem face the <a href="/wiki/Holy_of_Holies" title="Holy of Holies">Holy of Holies</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-returning_371-0"><a href="#cite_note-returning-371">[365]</a></sup> As prescribed in the <a href="/wiki/Mishnah" title="Mishnah">Mishna</a> and codified in the <i><a href="/wiki/Shulchan_Aruch" title="Shulchan Aruch">Shulchan Aruch</a></i>, daily prayers are recited while facing towards Jerusalem and the Temple Mount. Many Jews have "<a href="/wiki/Mizrah" title="Mizrah">Mizrach</a>" plaques hung on a wall of their homes to indicate the direction of prayer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-returning_371-1"><a href="#cite_note-returning-371">[365]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[366]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Christianity">Christianity</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_in_Christianity" title="Jerusalem in Christianity">Jerusalem in Christianity</a></div>
<p>Jerusalem is generally considered the cradle of Christianity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[367]</a></sup> Christianity reveres Jerusalem for its <a href="/wiki/Old_Testament" title="Old Testament">Old Testament</a> history, and also for its significance in the life of Jesus. According to the <a href="/wiki/New_Testament" title="New Testament">New Testament</a>, Jesus was brought to Jerusalem soon after his birth<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[368]</a></sup> and later in his life cleansed the Second Temple.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[369]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Cenacle" title="Cenacle">Cenacle</a>, believed to be the site of Jesus' <a href="/wiki/Last_Supper" title="Last Supper">Last Supper</a>, is located on <a href="/wiki/Mount_Zion" title="Mount Zion">Mount Zion</a> in the same building that houses the <a href="/wiki/David%27s_Tomb" title="David's Tomb">Tomb of King David</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376">[370]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377">[371]</a></sup> Another prominent Christian site in Jerusalem is <a href="/wiki/Calvary" title="Calvary">Golgotha</a>, the site of the <a href="/wiki/Crucifixion" title="Crucifixion">crucifixion</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_John" title="Gospel of John">Gospel of John</a> describes it as being located outside Jerusalem,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[372]</a></sup> but recent archaeological evidence suggests Golgotha is a short distance from the Old City walls, within the present-day confines of the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-worldwide_379-0"><a href="#cite_note-worldwide-379">[373]</a></sup> The land occupied by the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre" title="Church of the Holy Sepulchre">Church of the Holy Sepulchre</a> is considered one of the top candidates for Golgotha and thus has been a Christian pilgrimage site for the past 2000 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-worldwide_379-1"><a href="#cite_note-worldwide-379">[373]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[374]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[375]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre" title="Church of the Holy Sepulchre">Church of the Holy Sepulchre</a> is generally considered the most important church in <a href="/wiki/Christendom" title="Christendom">Christendom</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[376]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Islam">Islam</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jerusalem_in_Islam" title="Jerusalem in Islam">Jerusalem in Islam</a></div><p>
Jerusalem is the third-holiest city in <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni Islam</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3rd_38-1"><a href="#cite_note-3rd-38">[33]</a></sup> Islamic tradition holds that for approximately a year, before it was permanently switched to the <a href="/wiki/Kaaba" title="Kaaba">Kaaba</a> in <a href="/wiki/Mecca" title="Mecca">Mecca</a>, the <i><a href="/wiki/Qibla" title="Qibla">qibla</a></i> (direction of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salat" title="Salat">prayer</a>) for Muslims was Jerusalem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[377]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[378]</a></sup> The city's lasting place in Islam, however, is primarily due to <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a>'s <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Isra_and_Mi%27raj" title="Isra and Mi'raj">Night Journey</a> (c. 620 CE). Muslims believe that Muhammad was miraculously transported one night from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Great_Mosque_of_Mecca" title="Great Mosque of Mecca">Great Mosque of Mecca</a> to the Temple Mount in Jerusalem, whereupon he ascended to <a href="/wiki/Jannah" title="Jannah">Heaven</a> to meet previous <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prophets_of_Islam" title="Prophets of Islam">prophets of Islam</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[379]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[380]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[381]</a></sup> The first verse in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Qur%27an" title="Qur'an">Qur'an</a>'s <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Al-Isra" title="Al-Isra"><i>Surat al-Isra</i></a> notes the destination of Muhammad's journey as <i>al-masjid al-aqá¹£Ä</i> ("the farthest place of prayer").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[382]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[383]</a></sup> In the earliest days of Islam, this was understood as a reference to a site in the heavens,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:8_390-0"><a href="#cite_note-:8-390">[384]</a></sup> however, Post-<a href="/wiki/Rashidun_Caliphate" title="Rashidun Caliphate">Rashidun</a> Islamic scholars understood it as relating to Jerusalem, and particularly to the site of the former Jewish Temple.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[385]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Hadith" title="Hadith">hadith</a>, a collection of the sayings of Muhammad, mentions that the location of the Al-Aqsa Mosque is in Jerusalem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[386]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Qibli_Mosque" title="Qibli Mosque">Al-Aqsa Mosque</a>, originally named  after the wider compound it sits within,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[387]</a></sup> was built on the Temple Mount under the Umayyad Caliph <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Al-Walid_ibn_Abd_al-Malik" title="Al-Walid ibn Abd al-Malik">Al-Walid</a> several decades after Muhammad's death to commemorate the place from which Muslims believe he had ascended to Heaven.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[388]</a></sup></p><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 150px;"><div style="margin:37.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:THE_TEMPLE_MOUNT_JERUSALEM.jpg" title="The Temple Mount is the holiest spot in Judaism and the third holiest site in Islam. Jews venerate it as the site of the two former Temples and Muslims believe that Muhammad was transported from the Great Mosque of Mecca to this location during the Night Journey."><img alt="The Temple Mount is the holiest spot in Judaism and the third holiest site in Islam. Jews venerate it as the site of the two former Temples and Muslims believe that Muhammad was transported from the Great Mosque of Mecca to this location during the Night Journey." data-file-height="1410" data-file-width="2256" decoding="async" height="75" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/THE_TEMPLE_MOUNT_JERUSALEM.jpg/120px-THE_TEMPLE_MOUNT_JERUSALEM.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/THE_TEMPLE_MOUNT_JERUSALEM.jpg/180px-THE_TEMPLE_MOUNT_JERUSALEM.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/THE_TEMPLE_MOUNT_JERUSALEM.jpg/240px-THE_TEMPLE_MOUNT_JERUSALEM.jpg 2x" width="120"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Temple_Mount" title="Temple Mount">Temple Mount</a> is the holiest spot in <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a> and the third holiest site in Islam. Jews venerate it as the site of the two former <a href="/wiki/Temple_in_Jerusalem" title="Temple in Jerusalem">Temples</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muslim" title="Muslim">Muslims</a> believe that <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_in_Islam" title="Muhammad in Islam">Muhammad</a> was transported from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Great_Mosque_of_Mecca" title="Great Mosque of Mecca">Great Mosque of Mecca</a> to this location during the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Isra_and_Mi%27raj" title="Isra and Mi'raj">Night Journey</a>.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 150px;"><div style="margin:35px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Western_Wall_at_night_(20063).jpg" title="The Western Wall, also known as the Wailing Wall and the Kotel, is a remnant of the Second Temple and the holiest place where Jews are permitted to pray"><img alt="The Western Wall, also known as the Wailing Wall and the Kotel, is a remnant of the Second Temple and the holiest place where Jews are permitted to pray" data-file-height="2247" data-file-width="3372" decoding="async" height="80" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Western_Wall_at_night_%2820063%29.jpg/120px-Western_Wall_at_night_%2820063%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Western_Wall_at_night_%2820063%29.jpg/180px-Western_Wall_at_night_%2820063%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Western_Wall_at_night_%2820063%29.jpg/240px-Western_Wall_at_night_%2820063%29.jpg 2x" width="120"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Western_Wall" title="Western Wall">Western Wall</a>, also known as the Wailing Wall and the Kotel, is a remnant of the <a href="/wiki/Second_Temple" title="Second Temple">Second Temple</a> and the holiest place where Jews are permitted to pray
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 150px;"><div style="margin:35px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre-Jerusalem.JPG" title="The Church of the Holy Sepulchre contains the two holiest sites in Christianity: the site where Jesus was crucified, and Jesus's empty tomb, where he is believed by Christians to have been buried and resurrected."><img alt="The Church of the Holy Sepulchre contains the two holiest sites in Christianity: the site where Jesus was crucified, and Jesus's empty tomb, where he is believed by Christians to have been buried and resurrected." data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4288" decoding="async" height="80" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/The_Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre-Jerusalem.JPG/120px-The_Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre-Jerusalem.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/The_Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre-Jerusalem.JPG/180px-The_Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre-Jerusalem.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/The_Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre-Jerusalem.JPG/240px-The_Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre-Jerusalem.JPG 2x" width="120"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre" title="Church of the Holy Sepulchre">Church of the Holy Sepulchre</a> contains the two holiest sites in <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>: the site where <a href="/wiki/Jesus" title="Jesus">Jesus</a> was <a href="/wiki/Crucifixion_of_Jesus" title="Crucifixion of Jesus">crucified</a>, and Jesus's empty tomb, where he is believed by Christians to have been <a href="/wiki/Burial_of_Jesus" title="Burial of Jesus">buried</a> and <a href="/wiki/Resurrection_of_Jesus" title="Resurrection of Jesus">resurrected</a>.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 150px;"><div style="margin:41.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Al-Aqsa_Mosque_(Jerusalem).jpg" title="Al-Aqsa Mosque, the primary Muslim prayer hall on the Temple Mount (Haram al-Sharif or Al-Aqsa compound)"><img alt="Al-Aqsa Mosque, the primary Muslim prayer hall on the Temple Mount (Haram al-Sharif or Al-Aqsa compound)" data-file-height="719" data-file-width="1280" decoding="async" height="67" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Al-Aqsa_Mosque_%28Jerusalem%29.jpg/120px-Al-Aqsa_Mosque_%28Jerusalem%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Al-Aqsa_Mosque_%28Jerusalem%29.jpg/180px-Al-Aqsa_Mosque_%28Jerusalem%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Al-Aqsa_Mosque_%28Jerusalem%29.jpg/240px-Al-Aqsa_Mosque_%28Jerusalem%29.jpg 2x" width="120"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Qibli_Mosque" title="Qibli Mosque">Al-Aqsa Mosque</a>, the primary Muslim prayer hall on the Temple Mount (Haram al-Sharif or Al-Aqsa compound)
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 150px;"><div style="margin:35px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jerusalem-Garden-Tomb-KTM-1266.jpg" title="The Garden Tomb â a new holy site established by British Protestants in the 19th century"><img alt="The Garden Tomb â a new holy site established by British Protestants in the 19th century" data-file-height="3648" data-file-width="5472" decoding="async" height="80" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Jerusalem-Garden-Tomb-KTM-1266.jpg/120px-Jerusalem-Garden-Tomb-KTM-1266.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Jerusalem-Garden-Tomb-KTM-1266.jpg/180px-Jerusalem-Garden-Tomb-KTM-1266.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Jerusalem-Garden-Tomb-KTM-1266.jpg/240px-Jerusalem-Garden-Tomb-KTM-1266.jpg 2x" width="120"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/The_Garden_Tomb" title="The Garden Tomb">The Garden Tomb</a> â a new holy site established by British <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestants</a> in the 19th century
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:PikiWiki_Israel_19135_Israel_Bank_in_Jerusalem.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/PikiWiki_Israel_19135_Israel_Bank_in_Jerusalem.JPG/220px-PikiWiki_Israel_19135_Israel_Bank_in_Jerusalem.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/PikiWiki_Israel_19135_Israel_Bank_in_Jerusalem.JPG/330px-PikiWiki_Israel_19135_Israel_Bank_in_Jerusalem.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/PikiWiki_Israel_19135_Israel_Bank_in_Jerusalem.JPG/440px-PikiWiki_Israel_19135_Israel_Bank_in_Jerusalem.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:PikiWiki_Israel_19135_Israel_Bank_in_Jerusalem.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Bank_of_Israel" title="Bank of Israel">Bank of Israel</a></div></div></div>
<p>Historically, Jerusalem's economy was supported almost exclusively by religious pilgrims, as it was far from the major ports of <a href="/wiki/Jaffa" title="Jaffa">Jaffa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gaza_City" title="Gaza City">Gaza</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-politics67_395-0"><a href="#cite_note-politics67-395">[389]</a></sup> Jerusalem's religious and cultural landmarks today remain the top draw for foreign visitors, with the majority of tourists visiting the Western Wall and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Old_City_(Jerusalem)" title="Old City (Jerusalem)">Old City</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cbs_337-4"><a href="#cite_note-cbs-337">[331]</a></sup> In 2010, Jerusalem was named the top leisure travel city in Africa and the Middle East by <a href="/wiki/Travel_%2B_Leisure" title="Travel + Leisure"><i>Travel + Leisure magazine</i></a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[390]</a></sup>
in 2013, 75% of the 3.5Â million tourists to Israel visited Jerusalem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[391]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hotzvimview.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1446" data-file-width="2192" decoding="async" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Hotzvimview.jpg/220px-Hotzvimview.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Hotzvimview.jpg/330px-Hotzvimview.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Hotzvimview.jpg/440px-Hotzvimview.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hotzvimview.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Har_Hotzvim" title="Har Hotzvim">Har Hotzvim</a> high-tech park</div></div></div>
<p>Since the establishment of the State of Israel, the national government has remained a major player in Jerusalem's economy. The government, centered in Jerusalem, generates a large number of jobs, and offers subsidies and incentives for new business initiatives and start-ups.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-politics67_395-1"><a href="#cite_note-politics67-395">[389]</a></sup> Although Tel Aviv remains Israel's financial center, a growing number of <a href="/wiki/High_tech" title="High tech">high tech</a> companies are moving to Jerusalem, providing 12,000 jobs in 2006.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[392]</a></sup> Northern Jerusalem's <a href="/wiki/Har_Hotzvim" title="Har Hotzvim">Har Hotzvim</a> industrial park and the <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Technology_Park" title="Jerusalem Technology Park">Jerusalem Technology Park</a> in south Jerusalem are home to large <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Research_and_Development" title="Research and Development">Research and Development</a> centers of international tech companies, among them <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Intel_Corporation" title="Intel Corporation">Intel</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cisco_Systems" title="Cisco Systems">Cisco Systems</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Teva_Pharmaceutical_Industries" title="Teva Pharmaceutical Industries">Teva Pharmaceutical Industries</a>, <a href="/wiki/IBM" title="IBM">IBM</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mobileye" title="Mobileye">Mobileye</a>, <a href="/wiki/Johnson_%26_Johnson" title="Johnson &amp; Johnson">Johnson &amp; Johnson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Medtronic" title="Medtronic">Medtronic</a> and more.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[393]</a></sup> In April 2015, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Time_Magazine" title="Time Magazine">Time Magazine</a> picked Jerusalem as one of the five emerging tech hubs in the world, proclaiming that "The city has become a flourishing center for biomed, cleantech, Internet/mobile startups, accelerators, investors and supporting service providers."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[394]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jerusalem_Israel,_Jerusal%C3%A9m_-_Shopping_de_Rua_(5172398236).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1696" data-file-width="2544" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Jerusalem_Israel%2C_Jerusal%C3%A9m_-_Shopping_de_Rua_%285172398236%29.jpg/220px-Jerusalem_Israel%2C_Jerusal%C3%A9m_-_Shopping_de_Rua_%285172398236%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Jerusalem_Israel%2C_Jerusal%C3%A9m_-_Shopping_de_Rua_%285172398236%29.jpg/330px-Jerusalem_Israel%2C_Jerusal%C3%A9m_-_Shopping_de_Rua_%285172398236%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Jerusalem_Israel%2C_Jerusal%C3%A9m_-_Shopping_de_Rua_%285172398236%29.jpg/440px-Jerusalem_Israel%2C_Jerusal%C3%A9m_-_Shopping_de_Rua_%285172398236%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jerusalem_Israel,_Jerusal%C3%A9m_-_Shopping_de_Rua_(5172398236).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mamilla_Mall" title="Mamilla Mall">Mamilla Mall</a> adorned with upscale shops stands just outside the Old City Walls.</div></div></div>
<p>Higher than average percentages are employed in education (17.9% vs. 12.7%); health and welfare (12.6% vs. 10.7%); community and social services (6.4% vs. 4.7%); hotels and restaurants (6.1% vs. 4.7%); and public administration (8.2% vs. 4.7%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[395]</a></sup> During the British Mandate, a law was passed requiring all buildings to be constructed of <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_stone" title="Jerusalem stone">Jerusalem stone</a> in order to preserve the unique historic and aesthetic character of the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BIUmandate_216-1"><a href="#cite_note-BIUmandate-216">[210]</a></sup> Complementing this building code, which is still in force, is the discouragement of <a href="/wiki/Heavy_industry" title="Heavy industry">heavy industry</a> in Jerusalem; only about 2.2% of Jerusalem's land is zoned for "industry and infrastructure." By comparison, the percentage of land in Tel Aviv zoned for industry and infrastructure is twice as high, and in Haifa, seven times as high.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cbs_337-5"><a href="#cite_note-cbs-337">[331]</a></sup> Only 8.5% of the <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_District" title="Jerusalem District">Jerusalem District</a> work force is employed in the manufacturing sector, which is half the national average (15.8%).
</p><p>Although many statistics indicate economic growth in the city, since 1967, East Jerusalem has lagged behind the development of West Jerusalem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-politics67_395-2"><a href="#cite_note-politics67-395">[389]</a></sup> Nevertheless, the percentage of households with employed persons is higher for Arab households (76.1%) than for Jewish households (66.8%). The unemployment rate in Jerusalem (8.3%) is slightly better than the national average (9.0%), although the civilian <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Labor_force" title="Labor force">labor force</a> accounted for less than half of all persons fifteen years or olderâlower in comparison to that of Tel Aviv (58.0%) and <a href="/wiki/Haifa" title="Haifa">Haifa</a> (52.4%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cbs_337-6"><a href="#cite_note-cbs-337">[331]</a></sup> Poverty remains a problem in the city as 37% of the families in Jerusalem lived in 2011 below the poverty line. According to a report by the <a href="/wiki/Association_for_Civil_Rights_in_Israel" title="Association for Civil Rights in Israel">Association for Civil Rights in Israel</a> (ACRI), 78% of Arabs in Jerusalem lived in poverty in 2012, up from 64% in 2006. While the ACRI attributes the increase to the lack of employment opportunities, infrastructure and a worsening educational system, <a href="/wiki/Ir_Amim" title="Ir Amim">Ir Amim</a> blames the legal status of Palestinians in Jerusalem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hasson_402-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hasson-402">[396]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="High-rise_construction">High-rise construction</span></h3>
<p>Jerusalem has traditionally had a low-rise skyline. About 18 tall buildings were built at different times in the downtown area when there was no clear policy over the matter. One of them, Holyland Tower 1, Jerusalem's tallest building, is a <a href="/wiki/Skyscraper" title="Skyscraper">skyscraper</a> by international standards, rising 32 stories. Holyland Tower 2, which has been approved for construction, will reach the same height.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[397]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[398]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jerusalem_Holyland_Tower_remote_view_from_Rehavia.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Jerusalem_Holyland_Tower_remote_view_from_Rehavia.jpg/220px-Jerusalem_Holyland_Tower_remote_view_from_Rehavia.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Jerusalem_Holyland_Tower_remote_view_from_Rehavia.jpg/330px-Jerusalem_Holyland_Tower_remote_view_from_Rehavia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Jerusalem_Holyland_Tower_remote_view_from_Rehavia.jpg/440px-Jerusalem_Holyland_Tower_remote_view_from_Rehavia.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jerusalem_Holyland_Tower_remote_view_from_Rehavia.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Holyland Tower, Jerusalem's tallest building</div></div></div>
<p>A new master plan for the city will see many high-rise buildings, including skyscrapers, built in certain, designated areas of downtown Jerusalem. Under the plan, towers will line <a href="/wiki/Jaffa_Road" title="Jaffa Road">Jaffa Road</a> and <a href="/wiki/King_George_Street_(Jerusalem)" title="King George Street (Jerusalem)">King George Street</a>. One of the proposed towers along King George Street, the Migdal Merkaz HaYekum, is planned as a 65-story building, which would make it one of the tallest buildings in Israel. At the entrance to the city, near the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Chords_Bridge" title="Jerusalem Chords Bridge">Jerusalem Chords Bridge</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Central_Bus_Station" title="Jerusalem Central Bus Station">Central Bus Station</a>, twelve towers rising between 24 and 33 stories will be built, as part of a complex that will also include an open square and an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Binyanei_HaUma_Railway_Station" title="Jerusalem Binyanei HaUma Railway Station">underground train station</a> serving a new express line between Jerusalem and Tel Aviv, and will be connected by bridges and tunnels. Eleven of the skyscrapers will be either office or apartment buildings, and one will be a 2,000-room hotel. The complex is expected to attract many businesses from Tel Aviv, and become the city's main business hub. In addition, a complex for the city's courts and the prosecutor's office will be built, as well as new buildings for Central Zionist Archives and <a href="/wiki/Israel_State_Archives" title="Israel State Archives">Israel State Archives</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[399]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[400]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[401]</a></sup> The skyscrapers built throughout the city are expected to contain public space, shops, restaurants, and entertainment venues, and it has been speculated that this may lead to a revitalization of downtown Jerusalem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[402]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[403]</a></sup> In August 2015, the city council approved construction of a 344-foot pyramid-shaped skyscraper designed by <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Libeskind" title="Daniel Libeskind">Daniel Libeskind</a> and Yigal Levi, in place of a rejected previous design by Libeskind; it is set to break ground by 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[404]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Jerusalem" title="Transport in Jerusalem">Transport in Jerusalem</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jerusalem_Chords_Bridge.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2366" data-file-width="3562" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Jerusalem_Chords_Bridge.JPG/220px-Jerusalem_Chords_Bridge.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Jerusalem_Chords_Bridge.JPG/330px-Jerusalem_Chords_Bridge.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Jerusalem_Chords_Bridge.JPG/440px-Jerusalem_Chords_Bridge.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jerusalem_Chords_Bridge.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Chords_Bridge" title="Jerusalem Chords Bridge">Jerusalem Chords Bridge</a></div></div></div>
<p>Jerusalem is served by highly developed communication infrastructures, making it a leading logistics hub for Israel.
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Central_Bus_Station" title="Jerusalem Central Bus Station">Jerusalem Central Bus Station</a>, located on <a href="/wiki/Jaffa_Road" title="Jaffa Road">Jaffa Road</a>, is the busiest bus station in Israel. It is served by <a href="/wiki/Egged_(company)" title="Egged (company)">Egged Bus Cooperative</a>, which is the second-largest bus company in the world,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[405]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Dan_Bus_Company" title="Dan Bus Company">Dan</a> serves the <a href="/wiki/Bnei_Brak" title="Bnei Brak">Bnei Brak</a>-Jerusalem route along with Egged, and <a href="/wiki/Superbus_(company)" title="Superbus (company)">Superbus</a> serves the routes between Jerusalem, <a href="/wiki/Modi%27in_Illit" title="Modi'in Illit">Modi'in Illit</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Modi%27in-Maccabim-Re%27ut" title="Modi'in-Maccabim-Re'ut">Modi'in-Maccabim-Re'ut</a>. The companies operate from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Central_Bus_Station" title="Jerusalem Central Bus Station">Jerusalem Central Bus Station</a>. Arab neighborhoods in East Jerusalem and routes between Jerusalem and locations in the <a href="/wiki/West_Bank" title="West Bank">West Bank</a> are served by the <a href="/wiki/East_Jerusalem_Central_Bus_Station" title="East Jerusalem Central Bus Station">East Jerusalem Central Bus Station</a>, a transportation hub located near the Old City's <a href="/wiki/Damascus_Gate" title="Damascus Gate">Damascus Gate</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Light_Rail" title="Jerusalem Light Rail">Jerusalem Light Rail</a> initiated service in August 2011. According to plans, the first rail line will be capable of transporting an estimated 200,000 people daily, and has 23 stops. The route is from Pisgat Ze'ev in the north via the Old City and city center to Mt. Herzl in the south.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:JLR_26,_Jaffa_Street,_2019_(01).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3564" data-file-width="5346" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/JLR_26%2C_Jaffa_Street%2C_2019_%2801%29.jpg/220px-JLR_26%2C_Jaffa_Street%2C_2019_%2801%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/JLR_26%2C_Jaffa_Street%2C_2019_%2801%29.jpg/330px-JLR_26%2C_Jaffa_Street%2C_2019_%2801%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/JLR_26%2C_Jaffa_Street%2C_2019_%2801%29.jpg/440px-JLR_26%2C_Jaffa_Street%2C_2019_%2801%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:JLR_26,_Jaffa_Street,_2019_(01).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Light_Rail" title="Jerusalem Light Rail">Light Rail</a> tram on <a href="/wiki/Jaffa_Road" title="Jaffa Road">Jaffa Road</a></div></div></div>
<p>Another work in progress<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-panacea_412-0"><a href="#cite_note-panacea-412">[406]</a></sup> is a new <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High-speed_railway_to_Jerusalem" title="High-speed railway to Jerusalem">high-speed rail line</a> from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, which became partially operational in 2018 and is expected to be completed in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[407]</a></sup> Its terminus will be a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Binyanei_HaUma_Railway_Station" title="Jerusalem Binyanei HaUma Railway Station">new underground station</a> (80Â m or 262Â ft deep) serving the <a href="/wiki/International_Convention_Center_(Jerusalem)" title="International Convention Center (Jerusalem)">International Convention Center</a> and the Central Bus Station,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[408]</a></sup> and is planned to be extended eventually to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Malha_Railway_Station" title="Jerusalem Malha Railway Station">Malha station</a>. <a href="/wiki/Israel_Railways" title="Israel Railways">Israel Railways</a> operates train services to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Malha_Railway_Station" title="Jerusalem Malha Railway Station">Malha train station</a> from Tel Aviv via <a href="/wiki/Beit_Shemesh" title="Beit Shemesh">Beit Shemesh</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[409]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416"><a href="#cite_note-416">[410]</a></sup>
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Highway_50_(Israel)" title="Highway 50 (Israel)">Begin Expressway</a> is one of Jerusalem's major northâsouth thoroughfares; it runs on the western side of the city, merging in the north with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Route_443_(Israel)" title="Route 443 (Israel)">Route 443</a>, which continues toward Tel Aviv. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Highway_60_(Israel)" title="Highway 60 (Israel)">Route 60</a> runs through the center of the city near the <a href="/wiki/Green_Line_(Israel)" title="Green Line (Israel)">Green Line</a> between East and West Jerusalem. Construction is progressing on parts of a 35Â km (22Â mi) <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beltway" title="Beltway">ring road</a> around the city, fostering faster connection between the suburbs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rings_417-0"><a href="#cite_note-rings-417">[411]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[412]</a></sup> The eastern half of the project was conceptualized decades ago, but reaction to the proposed highway is still mixed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rings_417-1"><a href="#cite_note-rings-417">[411]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Airport">Airport</span></h3>
<p>Jerusalem is served by <a href="/wiki/Ben_Gurion_Airport" title="Ben Gurion Airport">Ben Gurion Airport</a>, some 50Â km (30Â mi) northwest of the Jerusalem, on the route to Tel Aviv. The <a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv%E2%80%93Jerusalem_railway" title="Tel AvivâJerusalem railway">Tel AvivâJerusalem railway</a> runs non-stop from <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem%E2%80%93Yitzhak_Navon_railway_station" title="JerusalemâYitzhak Navon railway station">JerusalemâYitzhak Navon railway station</a> to the airport and began operation in 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[413]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the past, Jerusalem was also served by the local <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atarot_Airport" title="Atarot Airport">Atarot Airport</a>. Atarot ceased operation in 2000.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Universities">Universities</span></h3>
<p>Jerusalem is home to several prestigious universities offering courses in <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_language" title="Hebrew language">Hebrew</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a> and English.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:HADASSA_HOSPITAL_MT._SCOPUS_JERUSALEM.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4400" data-file-width="6600" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/HADASSA_HOSPITAL_MT._SCOPUS_JERUSALEM.jpg/220px-HADASSA_HOSPITAL_MT._SCOPUS_JERUSALEM.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/HADASSA_HOSPITAL_MT._SCOPUS_JERUSALEM.jpg/330px-HADASSA_HOSPITAL_MT._SCOPUS_JERUSALEM.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/HADASSA_HOSPITAL_MT._SCOPUS_JERUSALEM.jpg/440px-HADASSA_HOSPITAL_MT._SCOPUS_JERUSALEM.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:HADASSA_HOSPITAL_MT._SCOPUS_JERUSALEM.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Hebrew_University_of_Jerusalem" title="Hebrew University of Jerusalem">Hebrew University of Jerusalem</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mount_Scopus" title="Mount Scopus">Mount Scopus</a> campus</div></div></div><p>
Founded in 1925, the <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_University_of_Jerusalem" title="Hebrew University of Jerusalem">Hebrew University of Jerusalem</a> has been ranked among the top 100 schools in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[414]</a></sup> The Board of Governors has included such prominent Jewish intellectuals as <a href="/wiki/Albert_Einstein" title="Albert Einstein">Albert Einstein</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sigmund_Freud" title="Sigmund Freud">Sigmund Freud</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hujiHistory_217-1"><a href="#cite_note-hujiHistory-217">[211]</a></sup> The university has produced several <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize" title="Nobel Prize">Nobel</a> laureates; recent winners associated with Hebrew University include <a href="/wiki/Avram_Hershko" title="Avram Hershko">Avram Hershko</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[415]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/David_Gross" title="David Gross">David Gross</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[416]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Kahneman" title="Daniel Kahneman">Daniel Kahneman</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[417]</a></sup> One of the university's major assets is the <a href="/wiki/National_Library_of_Israel" title="National Library of Israel">Jewish National and University Library</a>, which houses over five million books.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424">[418]</a></sup> The library opened in 1892, over three decades before the university was established, and is one of the world's largest repositories of books on Jewish subjects. Today it is both the central library of the university and the national library of Israel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425"><a href="#cite_note-425">[419]</a></sup> The Hebrew University operates three campuses in Jerusalem, on Mount Scopus, on <a href="/wiki/Givat_Ram" title="Givat Ram">Giv'at Ram</a> and a medical campus at the <a href="/wiki/Hadassah_Medical_Center" title="Hadassah Medical Center">Hadassah Ein Kerem hospital</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Academy_of_the_Hebrew_Language" title="Academy of the Hebrew Language">Academy of the Hebrew Language</a> are located in the Hebrew university in Givat Ram and the <a href="/wiki/Israel_Academy_of_Sciences_and_Humanities" title="Israel Academy of Sciences and Humanities">Israel Academy of Sciences and Humanities</a> located near the <a href="/wiki/Beit_HaNassi" title="Beit HaNassi">Presidents House</a>.</p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Du-leshoni-2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2112" data-file-width="2816" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Du-leshoni-2.jpg/220px-Du-leshoni-2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Du-leshoni-2.jpg/330px-Du-leshoni-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Du-leshoni-2.jpg/440px-Du-leshoni-2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Du-leshoni-2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Hand_in_Hand:_Center_for_Jewish-Arab_Education_in_Israel" title="Hand in Hand: Center for Jewish-Arab Education in Israel">Hand in Hand</a>, a bilingual Jewish-Arab school in Jerusalem</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hebron_yeshiva_1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="336" data-file-width="448" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Hebron_yeshiva_1.jpg/220px-Hebron_yeshiva_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Hebron_yeshiva_1.jpg/330px-Hebron_yeshiva_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Hebron_yeshiva_1.jpg/440px-Hebron_yeshiva_1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hebron_yeshiva_1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Hebron_Yeshiva" title="Hebron Yeshiva">Hebron Yeshiva</a> in <a href="/wiki/Givat_Mordechai" title="Givat Mordechai">Givat Mordechai</a> neighborhood</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_College_of_Technology" title="Jerusalem College of Technology">Jerusalem College of Technology</a>, founded in 1969, combines training in engineering and other high-tech industries with a Jewish studies program.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[420]</a></sup> It is one of many schools in Jerusalem, from elementary school and up, that combine secular and religious studies. Numerous religious educational institutions and <a href="/wiki/Yeshiva" title="Yeshiva"><i>Yeshivot</i></a>, including some of the most prestigious yeshivas, among them the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brisk_yeshiva" title="Brisk yeshiva">Brisk</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chevron_yeshiva" title="Chevron yeshiva">Chevron</a>, <a href="/wiki/Midrash_Shmuel_Yeshiva" title="Midrash Shmuel Yeshiva">Midrash Shmuel</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mir_yeshiva_(Jerusalem)" title="Mir yeshiva (Jerusalem)">Mir</a>, are based in the city, with the Mir Yeshiva claiming to be the largest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427">[421]</a></sup> There were nearly 8,000 twelfth-grade students in Hebrew-language schools during the 2003â2004 school year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cbs_337-7"><a href="#cite_note-cbs-337">[331]</a></sup> However, due to the large portion of students in <a href="/wiki/Haredi_Judaism" title="Haredi Judaism">Haredi Jewish</a> frameworks, only fifty-five percent of twelfth graders took <a href="/wiki/Matriculation" title="Matriculation">matriculation</a> exams (<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bagrut" title="Bagrut">Bagrut</a></i>) and only thirty-seven percent were eligible to graduate. Unlike <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Public_school_(government_funded)" title="Public school (government funded)">public schools</a>, many Haredi schools do not prepare students to take standardized tests.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cbs_337-8"><a href="#cite_note-cbs-337">[331]</a></sup> To attract more university students to Jerusalem, the city has begun to offer a special package of financial incentives and housing subsidies to students who rent apartments in downtown Jerusalem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428"><a href="#cite_note-428">[422]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Al-Quds_University" title="Al-Quds University">Al-Quds University</a> was established in 1984<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-quds1_429-0"><a href="#cite_note-quds1-429">[423]</a></sup> to serve as a flagship university for the Arab and Palestinian peoples.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> It describes itself as the "only Arab university in Jerusalem".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[424]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bard_College" title="Bard College">Bard College</a> of Annandale-on-Hudson, New York and Al-Quds University agreed to open a joint college in a building originally built to house the <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_Legislative_Council" title="Palestinian Legislative Council">Palestinian Legislative Council</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yasser_Arafat" title="Yasser Arafat">Yasser Arafat</a>'s office. The college gives <a href="/wiki/Master_of_Arts_in_Teaching" title="Master of Arts in Teaching">Master of Arts in Teaching</a> degrees.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kalman_431-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kalman-431">[425]</a></sup> Al-Quds University resides southeast of the city proper on a 190,000Â m<sup>2</sup> (47-acre) <a href="/wiki/Abu_Dis" title="Abu Dis">Abu Dis</a> campus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-quds1_429-1"><a href="#cite_note-quds1-429">[423]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other institutions of higher learning in Jerusalem are the <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Academy_of_Music_and_Dance" title="Jerusalem Academy of Music and Dance">Jerusalem Academy of Music and Dance</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432"><a href="#cite_note-432">[426]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Bezalel_Academy_of_Arts_and_Design" title="Bezalel Academy of Arts and Design">Bezalel Academy of Art and Design</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[427]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[428]</a></sup> whose buildings are located on the campuses of the Hebrew University.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Arab_schools">Arab schools</span></h3>
<p>Schools for Arabs in Jerusalem and other parts of Israel have been criticized for offering a lower quality education than those catering to Israeli Jewish students.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HumanRights_435-0"><a href="#cite_note-HumanRights-435">[429]</a></sup> While many schools in the heavily Arab East Jerusalem are filled to capacity and there have been complaints of overcrowding, the Jerusalem Municipality is building over a dozen new schools in the city's Arab neighborhoods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[430]</a></sup> Schools in <a href="/wiki/Ras_al-Amud" title="Ras al-Amud">Ras el-Amud</a> and <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Umm_Lison&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Umm Lison (page does not exist)">Umm Lison</a> opened in 2008.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lis_437-0"><a href="#cite_note-lis-437">[431]</a></sup> In March 2007, the Israeli government approved a five-year plan to build 8,000 new classrooms in the city, 40 percent in the Arab sector and 28 percent in the Haredi sector. A budget of 4.6Â billion shekels was allocated for this project.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-438"><a href="#cite_note-438">[432]</a></sup> In 2008, Jewish British philanthropists donated $3Â million for the construction of schools for Arabs in East Jerusalem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lis_437-1"><a href="#cite_note-lis-437">[431]</a></sup> Arab high school students take the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bagrut" title="Bagrut">Bagrut</a></i> matriculation exams, so that much of their curriculum parallels that of other Israeli high schools and includes certain Jewish subjects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HumanRights_435-1"><a href="#cite_note-HumanRights-435">[429]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Billy_Rose_Art_Garden_(14755133799).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3062" data-file-width="4752" decoding="async" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Billy_Rose_Art_Garden_%2814755133799%29.jpg/220px-Billy_Rose_Art_Garden_%2814755133799%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Billy_Rose_Art_Garden_%2814755133799%29.jpg/330px-Billy_Rose_Art_Garden_%2814755133799%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Billy_Rose_Art_Garden_%2814755133799%29.jpg/440px-Billy_Rose_Art_Garden_%2814755133799%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Billy_Rose_Art_Garden_(14755133799).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Shrine_of_the_Book" title="Shrine of the Book">Shrine of the Book</a>, housing the <a href="/wiki/Dead_Sea_Scrolls" title="Dead Sea Scrolls">Dead Sea Scrolls</a>, at the <a href="/wiki/Israel_Museum" title="Israel Museum">Israel Museum</a></div></div></div>
<p>Although Jerusalem is known primarily for its <a href="/wiki/Religious_significance_of_Jerusalem" title="Religious significance of Jerusalem">religious significance</a>, the city is also home to many artistic and cultural venues. The <a href="/wiki/Israel_Museum" title="Israel Museum">Israel Museum</a> attracts nearly one million visitors a year, approximately one-third of them tourists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IMJ_439-0"><a href="#cite_note-IMJ-439">[433]</a></sup> The 8Â ha (20-acre) museum complex comprises several buildings featuring special exhibits and extensive collections of <a href="/wiki/Jewish_ceremonial_art" title="Jewish ceremonial art">Judaica</a>, archaeological findings, and Israeli and European art. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dead_Sea_scrolls" title="Dead Sea scrolls">Dead Sea scrolls</a>, discovered in the mid-20th century in the <a href="/wiki/Qumran_Caves" title="Qumran Caves">Qumran Caves</a> near the Dead Sea, are housed in the Museum's <a href="/wiki/Shrine_of_the_Book" title="Shrine of the Book">Shrine of the Book</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[434]</a></sup> The Youth Wing, which mounts changing exhibits and runs an extensive art education program, is visited by 100,000 children a year. The museum has a large outdoor sculpture garden and includes the <a href="/wiki/Holyland_Model_of_Jerusalem" title="Holyland Model of Jerusalem">Holyland Model of Jerusalem</a>, a scale-model of the city during the late <a href="/wiki/Second_Temple_period" title="Second Temple period">Second Temple period</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IMJ_439-1"><a href="#cite_note-IMJ-439">[433]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ticho_House" title="Ticho House">Ticho House</a> in downtown Jerusalem houses the paintings of <a href="/wiki/Anna_Ticho" title="Anna Ticho">Anna Ticho</a> and the Judaica collections of her husband, an ophthalmologist who opened Jerusalem's first eye clinic in this building in 1912.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[435]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jerusalem_Zoo_spider_monkey.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3648" data-file-width="2736" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Jerusalem_Zoo_spider_monkey.jpg/170px-Jerusalem_Zoo_spider_monkey.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Jerusalem_Zoo_spider_monkey.jpg/255px-Jerusalem_Zoo_spider_monkey.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Jerusalem_Zoo_spider_monkey.jpg/340px-Jerusalem_Zoo_spider_monkey.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jerusalem_Zoo_spider_monkey.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Biblical_Zoo" title="Jerusalem Biblical Zoo">Jerusalem Biblical Zoo</a></div></div></div>
<p>Next to the Israel Museum is the <a href="/wiki/Bible_Lands_Museum" title="Bible Lands Museum">Bible Lands Museum</a>, near <a href="/wiki/Israel_Antiquities_Authority#The_National_Campus_for_the_Archaeology_of_Israel" title="Israel Antiquities Authority">The National Campus for the Archaeology of Israel</a>, which includes the <a href="/wiki/Israel_Antiquities_Authority" title="Israel Antiquities Authority">Israel Antiquities Authority</a> offices. A World Bible Center is planned to be built adjacent to <a href="/wiki/Mount_Zion" title="Mount Zion">Mount Zion</a> at a site called the "Bible Hill". A planned <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=World_Kabbalah_Center&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="World Kabbalah Center (page does not exist)">World Kabbalah Center</a> is to be located on the nearby promenade, overlooking the Old City. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rockefeller_Museum" title="Rockefeller Museum">Rockefeller Museum</a>, located in East Jerusalem, was the first archaeological museum in the Middle East. It was built in 1938 during the British Mandate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[436]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[437]</a></sup> In 2006, a 38Â km (24Â mi) <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Trail" title="Jerusalem Trail">Jerusalem Trail</a> was opened, a hiking trail that goes to many cultural sites and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_parks" title="National parks">national parks</a> in and around Jerusalem. The <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Biblical_Zoo" title="Jerusalem Biblical Zoo">Jerusalem Biblical Zoo</a> has ranked consistently as Israel's top tourist attraction for Israelis.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[438]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[439]</a></sup>
</p><p>The national cemetery of Israel is located at the city's western edge, near the <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Forest" title="Jerusalem Forest">Jerusalem Forest</a> on <a href="/wiki/Mount_Herzl" title="Mount Herzl">Mount Herzl</a>. The western extension of Mount Herzl is the Mount of Remembrance, where the main Holocaust museum of Israel is located. <a href="/wiki/Yad_Vashem" title="Yad Vashem">Yad Vashem</a>, Israel's national memorial to the victims of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Holocaust" title="Holocaust">Holocaust</a>, houses the world's largest library of Holocaust-related information.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-446"><a href="#cite_note-446">[440]</a></sup> It houses an estimated 100,000 books and articles. The complex contains a state-of-the-art museum that explores the genocide of the Jews through exhibits that focus on the personal stories of individuals and families killed in the Holocaust. An art gallery featuring the work of artists who perished is also present. Further, Yad Vashem commemorates the 1.5Â million Jewish children murdered by the Nazis, and honors the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Righteous_among_the_Nations" title="Righteous among the Nations">Righteous among the Nations</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-YV_447-0"><a href="#cite_note-YV-447">[441]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:NLI_building2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="568" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="139" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/NLI_building2.jpg/220px-NLI_building2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/NLI_building2.jpg/330px-NLI_building2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/NLI_building2.jpg/440px-NLI_building2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:NLI_building2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/National_Library_of_Israel" title="National Library of Israel">National Library of Israel</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Symphony_Orchestra" title="Jerusalem Symphony Orchestra">Jerusalem Symphony Orchestra</a>, established in the 1940s,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JSO_448-0"><a href="#cite_note-JSO-448">[442]</a></sup> has appeared around the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JSO_448-1"><a href="#cite_note-JSO-448">[442]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/International_Convention_Center_(Jerusalem)" title="International Convention Center (Jerusalem)">International Convention Center</a> (<i>Binyanei HaUma</i>) near the entrance to city houses the <a href="/wiki/Israel_Philharmonic_Orchestra" title="Israel Philharmonic Orchestra">Israel Philharmonic Orchestra</a>. The Jerusalem Cinemateque, the <a href="/wiki/Gerard_Behar_Center" title="Gerard Behar Center">Gerard Behar Center</a> (formerly Beit Ha'Am) in downtown Jerusalem, the <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Music_Centre" title="Jerusalem Music Centre">Jerusalem Music Center</a> in <a href="/wiki/Yemin_Moshe" title="Yemin Moshe">Yemin Moshe</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449"><a href="#cite_note-449">[443]</a></sup> and the Targ Music Center in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ein_Kerem" title="Ein Kerem">Ein Kerem</a> also present the arts. The <a href="/wiki/Israel_Festival" title="Israel Festival">Israel Festival</a>, featuring indoor and outdoor performances by local and international singers, concerts, plays, and street theater has been held annually since 1961, and Jerusalem has been the major organizer of this event. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Theater" title="Jerusalem Theater">Jerusalem Theater</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Talbiya" title="Talbiya">Talbiya</a> neighborhood hosts over 150 concerts a year, as well as theater and dance companies and performing artists from overseas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-450"><a href="#cite_note-450">[444]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Jerusalem_Khan_Theatre" title="The Jerusalem Khan Theatre">Khan Theater</a>, located in a caravanserai opposite the old Jerusalem train station, is the city's only <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Repertory" title="Repertory">repertoire</a> theater.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-451"><a href="#cite_note-451">[445]</a></sup> The station itself has become a venue for cultural events in recent years as the site of <i>Shav'ua Hasefer</i> (an annual week-long book fair) and outdoor music performances.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-452"><a href="#cite_note-452">[446]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Film_Festival" title="Jerusalem Film Festival">Jerusalem Film Festival</a> is held annually, screening Israeli and international films.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-filmfest_453-0"><a href="#cite_note-filmfest-453">[447]</a></sup> In 1974 the <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Cinematheque" title="Jerusalem Cinematheque">Jerusalem Cinematheque</a> was founded. In 1981 it was moved to a new building on Hebron Road near the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Valley_of_Hinnom" title="Valley of Hinnom">Valley of Hinnom</a> and the Old City.
</p><p>Jerusalem was declared the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2009_Capital_of_Arab_Culture" title="2009 Capital of Arab Culture">Capital of Arab Culture</a> in 2009.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ynetBan_454-0"><a href="#cite_note-ynetBan-454">[448]</a></sup> Jerusalem is home to the <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_National_Theatre" title="Palestinian National Theatre">Palestinian National Theatre</a>, which engages in cultural preservation as well as innovation, working to rekindle Palestinian interest in the arts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-455"><a href="#cite_note-455">[449]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Edward_Said_National_Conservatory_of_Music" title="The Edward Said National Conservatory of Music">The Edward Said National Conservatory of Music</a> sponsors the Palestine Youth Orchestra<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-456"><a href="#cite_note-456">[450]</a></sup> which toured <a href="/wiki/Arab_states_of_the_Persian_Gulf" title="Arab states of the Persian Gulf">Arab states of the Persian Gulf</a> and other Middle East countries in 2009.<sup class="reference"
