id="cite_ref-457"><a href="#cite_note-457">[451]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic_Museum" title="Islamic Museum">Islamic Museum</a> on the Temple Mount, established in 1923, houses many Islamic artifacts, from tiny <a href="/wiki/Kohl_(cosmetics)" title="Kohl (cosmetics)">kohl</a> flasks and rare manuscripts to giant marble columns.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-458"><a href="#cite_note-458">[452]</a></sup> Al-Hoash, established in 2004, is a gallery for the preservation of Palestinian art.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-alhoash_459-0"><a href="#cite_note-alhoash-459">[453]</a></sup> While Israel approves and financially supports some Arab cultural activities,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (August 2013)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Arab Capital of Culture events were banned because they were sponsored by the Palestine National Authority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ynetBan_454-1"><a href="#cite_note-ynetBan-454">[448]</a></sup> In 2009, a four-day culture festival was held in the <a href="/wiki/Beit_%27Anan" title="Beit 'Anan">Beit 'Anan</a> suburb of Jerusalem, attended by more than 15,000 people<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-460"><a href="#cite_note-460">[454]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Museum on the Seam, which explores issues of coexistence through art, is situated on the road dividing eastern and western Jerusalem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-seam_461-0"><a href="#cite_note-seam-461">[455]</a></sup> The Abraham Fund and the Jerusalem Intercultural Center (JICC) promote joint Jewish-Palestinian cultural projects. The Jerusalem Center for Middle Eastern Music and Dance<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-462"><a href="#cite_note-462">[456]</a></sup> is open to Arabs and Jews and offers workshops on Jewish-Arab dialogue through the arts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-463"><a href="#cite_note-463">[457]</a></sup> The Jewish-Arab Youth Orchestra performs both European classical and Middle Eastern music.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-464"><a href="#cite_note-464">[458]</a></sup> In 2008, the <a href="/wiki/Tolerance_Monument" title="Tolerance Monument">Tolerance Monument</a>, an outdoor sculpture by <a href="/wiki/Czes%C5%82aw_D%C5%BAwigaj" title="CzesÅaw DÅºwigaj">CzesÅaw DÅºwigaj</a>, was erected on a hill between Jewish <a href="/wiki/East_Talpiot" title="East Talpiot">Armon HaNetziv</a> and Arab <a href="/wiki/Jabel_Mukaber" title="Jabel Mukaber">Jebl Mukaber</a> as a symbol of Jerusalem's quest for peace.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-465"><a href="#cite_note-465">[459]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3>
<p>Jerusalem is the state broadcasting center of Israel. The <a href="/wiki/Israel_Broadcasting_Authority" title="Israel Broadcasting Authority">Israel Broadcasting Authority</a>'s main office is located in Jerusalem, as well as the TV and radio studios for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Israel_Radio" title="Israel Radio">Israel Radio</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Channel_2_(Israel)" title="Channel 2 (Israel)">Channel 2</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Channel_10_(Israel)" title="Channel 10 (Israel)">Channel 10</a>, and part of the radio studios of <a href="/wiki/BBC_News" title="BBC News">BBC News</a>. <a href="/wiki/The_Jerusalem_Post" title="The Jerusalem Post">The Jerusalem Post</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Times_of_Israel" title="The Times of Israel">The Times of Israel</a> are also headquartered in Jerusalem. Local newspapers include <a href="/wiki/Kol_Ha%27ir" title="Kol Ha'ir">Kol Ha'Ir</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Jerusalem_Times" title="The Jerusalem Times">The Jerusalem Times</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/God_TV" title="God TV">God TV</a>, an international Christian television network is also based in the city.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Beitar_Jerusalem_F.C." title="Beitar Jerusalem F.C.">Beitar Jerusalem F.C.</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hapoel_Jerusalem_B.C." title="Hapoel Jerusalem B.C.">Hapoel Jerusalem B.C.</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Marathon" title="Jerusalem Marathon">Jerusalem Marathon</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%D7%90%D7%A6%D7%98%D7%93%D7%99%D7%95%D7%9F_%D7%98%D7%93%D7%99.jpeg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2126" data-file-width="3024" decoding="async" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/%D7%90%D7%A6%D7%98%D7%93%D7%99%D7%95%D7%9F_%D7%98%D7%93%D7%99.jpeg/220px-%D7%90%D7%A6%D7%98%D7%93%D7%99%D7%95%D7%9F_%D7%98%D7%93%D7%99.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/%D7%90%D7%A6%D7%98%D7%93%D7%99%D7%95%D7%9F_%D7%98%D7%93%D7%99.jpeg/330px-%D7%90%D7%A6%D7%98%D7%93%D7%99%D7%95%D7%9F_%D7%98%D7%93%D7%99.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/%D7%90%D7%A6%D7%98%D7%93%D7%99%D7%95%D7%9F_%D7%98%D7%93%D7%99.jpeg/440px-%D7%90%D7%A6%D7%98%D7%93%D7%99%D7%95%D7%9F_%D7%98%D7%93%D7%99.jpeg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%D7%90%D7%A6%D7%98%D7%93%D7%99%D7%95%D7%9F_%D7%98%D7%93%D7%99.jpeg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Teddy_Stadium" title="Teddy Stadium">Teddy Stadium</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malha" title="Malha">Malha</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jerusalem_Arena_in_a_Playoff_Match2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2322" data-file-width="4128" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Jerusalem_Arena_in_a_Playoff_Match2.jpg/220px-Jerusalem_Arena_in_a_Playoff_Match2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Jerusalem_Arena_in_a_Playoff_Match2.jpg/330px-Jerusalem_Arena_in_a_Playoff_Match2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Jerusalem_Arena_in_a_Playoff_Match2.jpg/440px-Jerusalem_Arena_in_a_Playoff_Match2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jerusalem_Arena_in_a_Playoff_Match2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Pais_Arena" title="Pais Arena">Pais Arena</a></div></div></div>
<p>The two most popular sports are <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">football</a> (soccer) and basketball.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-466"><a href="#cite_note-466">[460]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Beitar_Jerusalem_F.C." title="Beitar Jerusalem F.C.">Beitar Jerusalem Football Club</a> is one of the most well known in Israel. Fans include political figures who often attend its games.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-467"><a href="#cite_note-467">[461]</a></sup> Jerusalem's other major football team, and one of Beitar's top rivals, is <a href="/wiki/Hapoel_Jerusalem_F.C." title="Hapoel Jerusalem F.C.">Hapoel Jerusalem F.C.</a> Whereas Beitar has been <a href="/wiki/Israel_State_Cup" title="Israel State Cup">Israel State Cup</a> champion seven times,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-468"><a href="#cite_note-468">[462]</a></sup> Hapoel has won the Cup only once. Beitar has won the top league six times, while Hapoel has never succeeded. Beitar plays in the more prestigious <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Premier_League" title="Israeli Premier League">Ligat HaAl</a>, while Hapoel is in the second division <a href="/wiki/Liga_Leumit" title="Liga Leumit">Liga Leumit</a>. Since its opening in 1992, <a href="/wiki/Teddy_Stadium" title="Teddy Stadium">Teddy Stadium</a> has been Jerusalem's primary football stadium, with a capacity of 31,733<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-469"><a href="#cite_note-469">[463]</a></sup> The most popular Palestinian football club is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jabal_Al_Mukaber_(football_club)" title="Jabal Al Mukaber (football club)">Jabal Al Mukaber</a> (since 1976) which plays in <a href="/wiki/West_Bank_Premier_League" title="West Bank Premier League">West Bank Premier League</a>. The club hails from Mount Scopus at Jerusalem, part of the <a href="/wiki/Asian_Football_Confederation" title="Asian Football Confederation">Asian Football Confederation</a>, and plays at the <a href="/wiki/Faisal_Al-Husseini_International_Stadium" title="Faisal Al-Husseini International Stadium">Faisal Al-Husseini International Stadium</a> at <a href="/wiki/Al-Ram" title="Al-Ram">Al-Ram</a>, across the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/West_Bank_Barrier" title="West Bank Barrier">West Bank Barrier</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pfa_470-0"><a href="#cite_note-pfa-470">[464]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-footwall_471-0"><a href="#cite_note-footwall-471">[465]</a></sup>
</p><p>In basketball, <a href="/wiki/Hapoel_Jerusalem_B.C." title="Hapoel Jerusalem B.C.">Hapoel Jerusalem</a> is one of the top teams in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Israeli_Basketball_Super_League" title="Israeli Basketball Super League">top division</a>. The club has won Israel's championship in 2015, the <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Basketball_State_Cup" title="Israeli Basketball State Cup">State Cup</a> four times, and the <a href="/wiki/EuroCup_Basketball" title="EuroCup Basketball">ULEB Cup</a> in 2004.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-472"><a href="#cite_note-472">[466]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Marathon" title="Jerusalem Marathon">Jerusalem Marathon</a>, established in 2011, is an international marathon race held annually in Jerusalem in the month of March. The full 42-kilometer race begins at the Knesset, passes through Mount Scopus and the Old City's Armenian Quarter, and concludes at Sacher Park. In 2012, the Jerusalem Marathon drew 15,000 runners, including 1,500 from fifty countries outside Israel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-473"><a href="#cite_note-473">[467]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-474"><a href="#cite_note-474">[468]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-475"><a href="#cite_note-475">[469]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-476"><a href="#cite_note-476">[470]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-477"><a href="#cite_note-477">[471]</a></sup>
</p><p>A popular non-competitive sports event is the <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_March" title="Jerusalem March">Jerusalem March</a>, held annually during the <a href="/wiki/Sukkot" title="Sukkot">Sukkot</a> festival.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="International_relations">International relations</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Israeli_twin_towns_and_sister_cities" title="List of Israeli twin towns and sister cities">List of Israeli twin towns and sister cities</a></div>
<dl><dt>Jerusalem is twinned with</dt></dl>
<ul><li><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Czech_Republic" title="Czech Republic"><img alt="Czech Republic" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Flag_of_the_Czech_Republic.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Czech_Republic.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Flag_of_the_Czech_Republic.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_Czech_Republic.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Flag_of_the_Czech_Republic.svg/45px-Flag_of_the_Czech_Republic.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Prague" title="Prague">Prague</a>, Czech Republic<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Prague_478-0"><a href="#cite_note-Prague-478">[472]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan"><img alt="Japan" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Flag_of_Japan.svg/23px-Flag_of_Japan.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Flag_of_Japan.svg/35px-Flag_of_Japan.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Flag_of_Japan.svg/45px-Flag_of_Japan.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ayabe" title="Ayabe">Ayabe</a>, Japan<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-479"><a href="#cite_note-479">[473]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States"><img alt="United States" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="650" data-file-width="1235" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/46px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a>, United States <i>(since 1993)</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-480"><a href="#cite_note-480">[474]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYsis_481-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYsis-481">[475]</a></sup></li></ul>
<dl><dt>Partner city</dt></dl>
<ul><li><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/France" title="France"><img alt="France" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/23px-Flag_of_France.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/35px-Flag_of_France.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/45px-Flag_of_France.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Marseille" title="Marseille">Marseille</a>, France<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2014)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></li></ul>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-5">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The State of Palestine (according to the Basic Law of Palestine, Title One: Article 3) regards Jerusalem as its capital.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BasicLawPal-T1A3_1-0"><a href="#cite_note-BasicLawPal-T1A3-1">[1]</a></sup> However, the documents of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PLO" title="PLO">PLO</a>'s Negotiations Affairs Department (NAD) often refer to <a href="/wiki/East_Jerusalem" title="East Jerusalem">East Jerusalem</a> (rather than the whole of Jerusalem) as a future capital, and sometimes as the current capital. One of its 2010 documents, described as "for discussion purposes only", says that Palestine has a '"vision"' for a future in which "East Jerusalem ... shall be the capital of Palestine, and West Jerusalem shall be the capital of Israel",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PLO-NAD-2010_2-0"><a href="#cite_note-PLO-NAD-2010-2">[2]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> and one of its 2013 documents refers to "Palestine's capital, East Jerusalem", and states that "Occupied East Jerusalem is the natural socio-economic and political center for the future Palestinian state", while also stating that "Jerusalem has always been and remains the political, administrative and spiritual heart of Palestine" and that "The Palestinian acceptance of the 1967 border, which includes East Jerusalem, is a painful compromise".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PLO-NAD-2013_4-0"><a href="#cite_note-PLO-NAD-2013-4">[4]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-14"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-14">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In other languages: official Arabic in Israel: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">Ø£ÙØ±Ø´ÙÙÙ Ø§ÙÙØ¯Ø³</span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Arabic" title="Romanization of Arabic">romanized</a>:Â </small><span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn">Ê¾ÅªrÅ¡alÄ«m al-Quds</i></span> (combining the Biblical and common usage Arabic names); <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek_language" title="Ancient Greek language">Ancient Greek</a>: <span lang="grc">á¼¹ÎµÏÎ¿ÏÏÎ±Î»Î®Î¼/á¼¸ÎµÏÎ¿ÏÏÎ»ÏÎ¼Î±</span>, <small><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Ancient_Greek" title="Romanization of Ancient Greek">romanized</a>:Â </small><span title="Ancient Greek-language romanization"><i lang="grc-Latn">Hierousalá¸m/HierosÃ³luma</i></span>; <a href="/wiki/Armenian_language" title="Armenian language">Armenian</a>: <span lang="hy">ÔµÖÕ¸ÖÕ½Õ¡Õ²Õ¥Õ´</span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Armenian" title="Romanization of Armenian">romanized</a>:Â </small><span title="Armenian-language romanization"><i lang="hy-Latn">ErusaÅÄm</i></span>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-15"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-15">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Jerusalem is the capital under <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Law" title="Jerusalem Law">Israeli law</a>. The presidential residence, government offices, supreme court and parliament (<a href="/wiki/Knesset" title="Knesset">Knesset</a>) are there. The State of Palestine (according to the Basic Law of Palestine, Title One: Article 3) regards Jerusalem as its capital.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BasicLawPal-T1A3_1-1"><a href="#cite_note-BasicLawPal-T1A3-1">[1]</a></sup> The UN and most countries do not recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital, taking the position that the final status of Jerusalem is pending future negotiations between Israel and the Palestinian Authority. Most countries maintain their embassies in <a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv" title="Tel Aviv">Tel Aviv</a> and its suburbs or suburbs of Jerusalem, such as <a href="/wiki/Mevaseret_Zion" title="Mevaseret Zion">Mevaseret Zion</a> <small>(see <a class="external text" href="https://www.cia.gov/the-world-factbook/countries/israel/" rel="nofollow">CIA Factbook</a> and <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1067248974">.mw-parser-output cite.citation{font-style:inherit;word-wrap:break-word}.mw-parser-output .citation q{quotes:"\"""\"""'""'"}.mw-parser-output .citation:target{background-color:rgba(0,127,255,0.133)}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-free a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-free a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/65/Lock-green.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .id-lock-registration a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-registration a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d6/Lock-gray-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-subscription a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-subscription a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/aa/Lock-red-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .cs1-ws-icon a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg")right 0.1em center/12px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .cs1-code{color:inherit;background:inherit;border:none;padding:inherit}.mw-parser-output .cs1-hidden-error{display:none;color:#d33}.mw-parser-output .cs1-visible-error{color:#d33}.mw-parser-output .cs1-maint{display:none;color:#3a3;margin-left:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-format{font-size:95%}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-left{padding-left:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-right{padding-right:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .citation .mw-selflink{font-weight:inherit}</style><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/israel.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Map of Israel"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Map+of+Israel&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.un.org%2FDepts%2FCartographic%2Fmap%2Fprofile%2Fisrael.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJerusalem"></span>Â <span style="font-size:85%;">(319Â KB)</span>)</small> See <a href="/wiki/Status_of_Jerusalem" title="Status of Jerusalem">Status of Jerusalem</a> for more information.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-24"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-24">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Statistics regarding the demographics of Jerusalem refer to the unified and expanded Israeli municipality, which includes the pre-1967 Israeli and <a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan">Jordanian</a> municipalities as well as several additional <a href="/wiki/Palestinians" title="Palestinians">Palestinian</a> villages and neighborhoods to the northeast. Some of the Palestinian villages and neighborhoods have been relinquished to the <a href="/wiki/West_Bank" title="West Bank">West Bank</a> <i>de facto</i> by way of the <a href="/wiki/Israeli_West_Bank_barrier" title="Israeli West Bank barrier">Israeli West Bank barrier</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-laub2006_23-0"><a href="#cite_note-laub2006-23">[20]</a></sup> but their legal statuses have not been reverted.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-bible-david-27"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-bible-david_27-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-bible-david_27-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Much of the information regarding King David's conquest of Jerusalem comes from <a href="/wiki/Bible" title="Bible">Biblical</a> accounts, but some modern-day historians have begun to give them credit due to a 1993 excavation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[22]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-47"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-47">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/West_Jerusalem" title="West Jerusalem">West Jerusalem</a> comprises approximately one third of the municipal area of Jerusalem, with <a href="/wiki/East_Jerusalem" title="East Jerusalem">East Jerusalem</a> comprising approximately two-thirds. On the annexation of East Jerusalem, Israel also incorporated an area of the West Bank into the Jerusalem municipal area which represented more than ten times the area of East Jerusalem under Jordanian rule.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[39]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[40]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Benvenisti1976_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-Benvenisti1976-46">[41]</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>

<li id="cite_note-Elihay2011-13"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Elihay2011_13-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Elihay2011_13-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFElihay2011">Elihay, Yohanan (2011). <a class="external text" href="https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/783142368" rel="nofollow"><i>Speaking Arabic: a course in conversational Eastern (Palestinian) Arabic</i></a>. Jerusalem: Minerva. p.Â 36. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>Â <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-965-7397-30-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-965-7397-30-5"><bdi>978-965-7397-30-5</bdi></a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OCLC_(identifier)" title="OCLC (identifier)">OCLC</a>Â <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/oclc/783142368" rel="nofollow">783142368</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Speaking+Arabic%3A+a+course+in+conversational+Eastern+%28Palestinian%29+Arabic&amp;rft.place=Jerusalem&amp;rft.pages=36&amp;rft.edition=%5B2009+ed.%5D%2C+reprinted+with+corr.+2011&amp;rft.pub=Minerva&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft_id=info%3Aoclcnum%2F783142368&amp;rft.isbn=978-965-7397-30-5&amp;rft.aulast=Elihay&amp;rft.aufirst=Yohanan&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.worldcat.org%2Foclc%2F783142368&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJerusalem"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-28"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-28">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Tubb, 1998. pp. 13â14.</span>

<li id="cite_note-29"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-29">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Mark Smith in "The Early History of God: Yahweh and Other Deities of Ancient Israel" states "Despite the long regnant model that the Canaanites and Israelites were people of fundamentally different culture, archaeological data now casts doubt on this view. The material culture of the region exhibits numerous common points between Israelites and Canaanites in the Iron I period (c. 1200â1000Â <a href="/wiki/Common_Era" title="Common Era">BCE</a>). The record would suggest that the Israelite culture largely overlapped with and derived from Canaanite culture... In short, Israelite culture was largely Canaanite in nature. Given the information available, one cannot maintain a radical cultural separation between Canaanites and Israelites for the Iron I period." (pp. 6â7). Smith, Mark (2002) "The Early History of God: Yahweh and Other Deities of Ancient Israel" (Eerdman's)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Rendsberg3-30"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Rendsberg3_30-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Rendsberg3_30-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Rendsberg, Gary (2008). "Israel without the Bible". In Frederick E. Greenspahn. The Hebrew Bible: New Insights and Scholarship. NYU Press, pp. 3â5</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-1000BCE-31"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-1000BCE_31-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-1000BCE_31-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Since the 10th century BCE:
<ul><li>"Israel was first forged into a unified nation from Jerusalem some 3,000 years ago, when <a href="/wiki/David" title="David">King David</a> seized the crown and united the <a href="/wiki/Israelites" title="Israelites">twelve tribes</a> from this city... For a thousand years Jerusalem was the seat of Jewish sovereignty, the household site of kings, the location of its legislative councils and courts. In exile, the Jewish nation came to be identified with the city that had been the site of its ancient capital. Jews, wherever they were, prayed for its restoration." Roger Friedland, Richard D. Hecht. <i>To Rule Jerusalem</i>, University of California Press, 2000, p. 8. <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>Â <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-520-22092-7" title="Special:BookSources/0-520-22092-7">0-520-22092-7</a></li>
<li>"The centrality of Jerusalem to Judaism is so strong that even secular Jews express their devotion and attachment to the city, and cannot conceive of a modern State of Israel without it.... For Jews Jerusalem is sacred simply because it exists... Though Jerusalem's sacred character goes back three millennia...". Leslie J. Hoppe. <i>The Holy City: Jerusalem in the theology of the Old Testament</i>, Liturgical Press, 2000, p. 6. <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>Â <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-8146-5081-3" title="Special:BookSources/0-8146-5081-3">0-8146-5081-3</a></li>
<li>"Ever since King David made Jerusalem the capital of Israel 3,000 years ago, the city has played a central role in Jewish existence." Mitchell Geoffrey Bard, <i>The Complete Idiot's Guide to the Middle East Conflict</i>, Alpha Books, 2002, p. 330. <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>Â <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-02-864410-7" title="Special:BookSources/0-02-864410-7">0-02-864410-7</a></li>
<li>"Jerusalem became the center of the Jewish people some 3,000 years ago" Moshe Maoz, Sari Nusseibeh, <i>Jerusalem: Points of Friction â And Beyond</i>, Brill Academic Publishers, 2000, p. 1. <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>Â <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/90-411-8843-6" title="Special:BookSources/90-411-8843-6">90-411-8843-6</a></li></ul>
</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-32"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-32">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130104013732/http://www.adl.org/israel/advocacy/glossary/Jerusalem.asp" rel="nofollow">"Basic Facts you should know: Jerusalem"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Anti-Defamation_League" title="Anti-Defamation League">Anti-Defamation League</a></i>. 2007. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://www.adl.org/israel/advocacy/glossary/jerusalem.asp" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on 4 January 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">28 March</span> 2007</span>. <q>The Jewish people are inextricably bound to the city of Jerusalem. No other city has played such a dominant role in the history, politics, culture, religion, national life and consciousness of a people as has Jerusalem in the life of Jewry and Judaism. Since King David established the city as the capital of the Jewish state circa 1000 BCE, it has served as the symbol and most profound expression of the Jewish people's identity as a nation."</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Anti-Defamation+League&amp;rft.atitle=Basic+Facts+you+should+know%3A+Jerusalem&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.adl.org%2Fisrael%2Fadvocacy%2Fglossary%2Fjerusalem.asp&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJerusalem"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-33"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-33">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Reinoud Oosting, <i><a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=at6SOl54gqAC&amp;pg=PA117" rel="nofollow">The Role of Zion/Jerusalem in Isaiah 40â55: A Corpus-Linguistic Approach</a></i>, p. 117, at <a href="/wiki/Google_Books" title="Google Books">Google Books</a> Brill 2012 pp. 117â18. <a href="/wiki/Book_of_Isaiah" title="Book of Isaiah">Isaiah</a> 48:2; 51:1; <a href="/wiki/Book_of_Nehemiah" title="Book of Nehemiah">Nehemiah</a> 11:1, 18; cf. <a href="/wiki/Book_of_Joel" title="Book of Joel">Joel</a> 4:17: <a href="/wiki/Book_of_Daniel" title="Book of Daniel">Daniel</a> 5:24. The Isaiah section where they occur belong to deutero-Isaiah.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-34"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-34">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Shalom M. Paul, <i><a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=&amp;pg=PA306" rel="nofollow">Isaiah 40â66</a></i>, p. 306, at <a href="/wiki/Google_Books" title="Google Books">Google Books</a> The 'holiness' (<i>qodesh</i>) arises from the temple in its midst, the root <a href="/wiki/Q-D-%C5%A0" title="Q-D-Å ">q-d-Å¡</a> referring to a sanctuary. The concept is attested in Mesopotamian literature, and the epithet may serve to distinguish Babylon, the city of exiles, from the city of the Temple, to where they are enjoined to return.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-35"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-35">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFGolb1997">Golb, Norman (1997). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20131011220541/http://www.bibleinterp.com/articles/Jerusalem_OneCity.shtml" rel="nofollow">"Karen Armstrong's Jerusalem â One City, Three Faiths"</a>. The Bible and Interpretation. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://www.bibleinterp.com/articles/Jerusalem_OneCity.shtml" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on 11 October 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">10 July</span> 2013</span>. <q>The available texts of antiquity indicate that the concept was created by one or more personalities among the Jewish spiritual leadership, and that this occurred no later than the 6th century B.C.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Karen+Armstrong%27s+Jerusalem+%E2%80%93+One+City%2C+Three+Faiths&amp;rft.pub=The+Bible+and+Interpretation&amp;rft.date=1997&amp;rft.aulast=Golb&amp;rft.aufirst=Norman&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bibleinterp.com%2Farticles%2FJerusalem_OneCity.shtml&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJerusalem"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-36"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-36">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Isaiah 52:1 ÏÏÎ»Î¹Ï á¼¡ á¼Î³Î¯Î±.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-37"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-37">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Joseph T. Lienhard, <i>The Bible, the Church, and Authority: The Canon of the Christian Bible in History and Theology</i>, Liturgical Press, 1995 pp. 65â66: 'The Septuagint is a Jewish translation and was also used in the synagogue. But at the end of the first century C.E. many Jews ceased to use the Septuagint because the early Christians had adopted it as their own translation, and it began to be considered a Christian translation.'</span>

<li id="cite_note-55"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-55">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFElon1996">Elon, Amos (1996). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20030310223636/http://www.usna.edu/Users/history/tucker/hh362/TelAvivandJerusalem.HTM" rel="nofollow"><i>Jerusalem</i></a>. HarperCollins Publishers Ltd. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>Â <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-00-637531-6" title="Special:BookSources/0-00-637531-6"><bdi>0-00-637531-6</bdi></a>. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">26 April</span> 2007</span>. <q>The epithet may have originated in the ancient name of JerusalemâSalem (after the pagan deity of the city), which is etymologically connected in the Semitic languages with the words for peace (shalom in Hebrew, salam in Arabic).</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Jerusalem&amp;rft.pub=HarperCollins+Publishers+Ltd&amp;rft.date=1996&amp;rft.isbn=0-00-637531-6&amp;rft.aulast=Elon&amp;rft.aufirst=Amos&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.usna.edu%2FUsers%2Fhistory%2Ftucker%2Fhh362%2FTelAvivandJerusalem.HTM&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJerusalem"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-Naveh2001-77"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Naveh2001_77-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFJoseph_Naveh2001">Joseph Naveh (2001). <li id="cite_note-Baruch-79"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Baruch_79-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Baruch_79-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFBaruch,_YuvalLevi,_DanitReich,_Ronny2020">Baruch, Yuval; Levi, Danit; <a href="/wiki/Ronny_Reich" title="Ronny Reich">Reich, Ronny</a> (2020). <li id="cite_note-93"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-93">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070427222723/http://www.hotzvim.org.il/SiteFiles/1/35/901.asp" rel="nofollow">"The Official Website of Jerusalem"</a>. <li id="cite_note-94"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-94">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFSonbol1996">Sonbol, Amira (1996). <i>Women, the Family, and Divorce Laws in Islamic History</i>. p.Â 133.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Women%2C+the+Family%2C+and+Divorce+Laws+in+Islamic+History&amp;rft.pages=133&amp;rft.date=1996&amp;rft.aulast=Sonbol&amp;rft.aufirst=Amira&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJerusalem"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-NYT7k-95"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-NYT7k_95-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160229012749/http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2016/02/17/world/middleeast/ap-ml-israel-ancient-settlement.html" rel="nofollow">"Israeli Archaeologists Discover 7,000-Year-Old Settlement"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i>. 17 February 2016. Archived from <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2016/02/17/world/middleeast/ap-ml-israel-ancient-settlement.html" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on 29 February 2016<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">25 July</span> 2018</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+York+Times&amp;rft.atitle=Israeli+Archaeologists+Discover+7%2C000-Year-Old+Settlement&amp;rft.date=2016-02-17&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2Faponline%2F2016%2F02%2F17%2Fworld%2Fmiddleeast%2Fap-ml-israel-ancient-settlement.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJerusalem"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-96"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-96">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"No city in the world, not even Athens or Rome, ever played as great a role in the life of a nation for so long a time, as Jerusalem has done in the life of the Jewish people." <a href="/wiki/David_Ben-Gurion" title="David Ben-Gurion">David Ben-Gurion</a>, 1947</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-97"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-97">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"For three thousand years, Jerusalem has been the center of Jewish hope and longing. No other city has played such a dominant role in the history, culture, religion and consciousness of a people as has Jerusalem in the life of Jewry and Judaism. Throughout centuries of exile, Jerusalem remained alive in the hearts of Jews everywhere as the focal point of Jewish history, the symbol of ancient glory, spiritual fulfillment and modern renewal. This heart and soul of the Jewish people engenders the thought that if you want one simple word to symbolize all of Jewish history, that word would be 'Jerusalem.'" <a href="/wiki/Teddy_Kollek" title="Teddy Kollek">Teddy Kollek</a> (DC: Washington Institute For Near East Policy, 1990), pp. 19â20.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Intl1998-98"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Intl1998_98-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFJohn_Quigley1998"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/John_Quigley_(academic)" title="John Quigley (academic)">John Quigley</a> (1998). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=n-3PHZLwq7AC&amp;pg=PA32" rel="nofollow"><i>The Palestine Yearbook of International Law, 1996â1997</i></a>. Martinus Nijhoff Publishers. pp.Â 32â. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>Â <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/90-411-1009-7" title="Special:BookSources/90-411-1009-7"><bdi>90-411-1009-7</bdi></a>. <q>Palestine's claim to Jerusalem is founded on the longtime status of the Palestinian Arabs as the majority population of Palestine. On that basis the Palestinians claim sovereignty over all of Palestine. including Jerusalem, both East and West. The Palestinians claim descent from the Canaanites, the earliest recorded inhabitants of Palestine. Although political control changed hands many times through history, this population, which was Arabized by the Arab conquest of the seventh century A.D., remained into the twentieth century.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Palestine+Yearbook+of+International+Law%2C+1996%E2%80%931997&amp;rft.pages=32-&amp;rft.pub=Martinus+Nijhoff+Publishers&amp;rft.date=1998&amp;rft.isbn=90-411-1009-7&amp;rft.au=John+Quigley&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dn-3PHZLwq7AC%26pg%3DPA32&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJerusalem"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-99"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-99">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"(With reference to Palestinians in <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman</a> times) Although proud of their <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arab_people" title="Arab people">Arab</a> heritage and ancestry, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Palestinian_people" title="Palestinian people">Palestinians</a> considered themselves to be descended not only from Arab conquerors of the seventh century but also from <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples" title="Indigenous peoples">indigenous peoples</a> who had lived in the country since time immemorial, including the ancient <a href="/wiki/Hebrews" title="Hebrews">Hebrews</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canaanites" title="Canaanites">Canaanites</a> before them. Acutely aware of the distinctiveness of Palestinian history, the Palestinians saw themselves as the heirs of its rich associations." <a href="/wiki/Walid_Khalidi" title="Walid Khalidi">Walid Khalidi</a>, 1984, <i>Before Their Diaspora: A Photographic History of the Palestinians, 1876â1948</i>. Institute for Palestine Studies</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Bisharat-100"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Bisharat_100-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBisharat2010"><a href="/wiki/George_Bisharat" title="George Bisharat">Bisharat, George</a> (2010). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=LBOsAgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA311" rel="nofollow">"Maximizing Rights"</a>. However its claims of sovereign rights to the city are stronger with respect to West Jerusalem than with respect to East Jerusalem.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Maximizing+Rights&amp;rft.btitle=International+Law+and+the+Israeli-Palestinian+Conflict%3A+A+Rights-Based+Approach+to+Middle+East+Peace&amp;rft.pages=311&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-136-85098-1&amp;rft.aulast=Bisharat&amp;rft.aufirst=George&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DLBOsAgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA311&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJerusalem"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-110"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-110">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Mark Smith in "The Early History of God: Yahweh and Other Deities of Ancient Israel" states "Despite the long regnant model that the Canaanites and Israelites were people of fundamentally different culture, archaeological data now casts doubt on this view. The material culture of the region exhibits numerous common points between Israelites and Canaanites in the Iron I period (c. 1200â1000Â BCE). The record would suggest that the Israelite culture largely overlapped with and derived from Canaanite culture... In short, Israelite culture was largely Canaanite in nature. Given the information available, one cannot maintain a radical cultural separation between Canaanites and Israelites for the Iron I period." (pp. 6â7). Smith, Mark (2002) "The Early History of God: Yahweh and Other Deities of Ancient Israel" (Eerdman's)</span>

<li id="cite_note-:4-117"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-:4_117-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFFinkelsteinSilberman2002">Finkelstein, Israel; Silberman, Neil Asher (2002). <a class="external text" href="https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/44509358" rel="nofollow"><i>The Bible Unearthed: Archaeology's New Vision of Ancient Israel and the Origin of Its Sacred Texts</i></a>. The conflagration seems to have been general. When activity on the ridge of the City of David resumed in the Persian period, the-new suburbs on the western hill that had flourished since at least the time of Hezekiah were not reoccupied.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Bible+Unearthed%3A+Archaeology%27s+New+Vision+of+Ancient+Israel+and+the+Origin+of+Its+Sacred+Texts&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.pages=307&amp;rft.pub=Free+Press&amp;rft.date=2002&amp;rft_id=info%3Aoclcnum%2F44509358&amp;rft.isbn=0-684-86912-8&amp;rft.aulast=Finkelstein&amp;rft.aufirst=Israel&amp;rft.au=Silberman%2C+Neil+Asher&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.worldcat.org%2Foclc%2F44509358&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJerusalem"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-nytimes-124"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-nytimes_124-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFErlanger2005">Erlanger, Steven (5 August 2005). <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/05/international/middleeast/05jerusalem.html" rel="nofollow">"King David's Palace Is Found, Archaeologist Says"</a>. <i>The New York Times</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-135"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-135">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1 cs1-prop-long-vol" id="CITEREFJulian_Morgenstern1938">Julian Morgenstern (1938). "A Chapter in the History of the High-Priesthood (Concluded)". <i>The American Journal of Semitic Languages and Literatures</i>. The University of Chicago Press. 55 (October 1938) (4): 360â77. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/JSTOR_(identifier)" title="JSTOR (identifier)">JSTOR</a>Â <a class="external text" href="//www.jstor.org/stable/3088118" rel="nofollow">3088118</a>. <q>there is a great mass of evidence scattered throughout biblical literature that at some time very soon after the accession of Xerxes to the Persian throne in 485 B.C. Jerusalem was besieged and captured by a coalition of hostile neighboring states, Edom, Moab, Ammon, Tyre, and Philistia. Its walls were torn down, its buildings razed, the Temple itself burned and destroyed, at least in part, and the great mass of the people scattered...</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+American+Journal+of+Semitic+Languages+and+Literatures&amp;rft.atitle=A+Chapter+in+the+History+of+the+High-Priesthood+%28Concluded%29&amp;rft.volume=55+%28October+1938%29&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.pages=360-77&amp;rft.date=1938&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.jstor.org%2Fstable%2F3088118%23id-name%3DJSTOR&amp;rft.au=Julian+Morgenstern&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJerusalem"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-HarEl68-142"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-HarEl68_142-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-HarEl68_142-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFHar-El1977">Har-El, Menashe (1977). <i>This Is Jerusalem</i>. <li id="cite_note-143"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-143">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFZank">Zank, Michael. <a class="external text" href="http://www.bu.edu/mzank/Michael_Zank/Jerusalem/templemount.html" rel="nofollow">"The Temple Mount"</a>. <li id="cite_note-144"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-144">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFCrossan1993"><a href="/wiki/John_Dominic_Crossan" title="John Dominic Crossan">Crossan, John Dominic</a> (26 February 1993). <span class="cs1-lock-limited" title="Free access subject to limited trial, subscription normally required"><a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/historicaljesusl00cros" rel="nofollow"><i>The Historical Jesus: the life of a Mediterranean Jewish peasant</i></a></span> (ReprintedÂ ed.). San Francisco: HarperCollins. p.Â <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/historicaljesusl00cros/page/92" rel="nofollow">92</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>Â <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-06-061629-6" title="Special:BookSources/0-06-061629-6"><bdi>0-06-061629-6</bdi></a>. <q>from 4 BCE until 6 CE, when Rome, after exiling <a href="/wiki/Herod_Archelaus" title="Herod Archelaus">Herod Archelaus</a> to Gaul, assumed direct prefectural control of his territories</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Historical+Jesus%3A+the+life+of+a+Mediterranean+Jewish+peasant&amp;rft.place=San+Francisco&amp;rft.pages=92&amp;rft.edition=Reprinted&amp;rft.pub=HarperCollins&amp;rft.date=1993-02-26&amp;rft.isbn=0-06-061629-6&amp;rft.aulast=Crossan&amp;rft.aufirst=John+Dominic&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fhistoricaljesusl00cros&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJerusalem"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-:0-145"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-:0_145-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-:0_145-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFWeksler-Bdolah2019">Weksler-Bdolah, Shlomit (16 December 2019). <a class="external text" href="http://worldcat.org/oclc/1170143447" rel="nofollow"><i>Aelia Capitolina - Jerusalem in the Roman period: in light of archaeological research</i></a>. p.Â 3. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>Â <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-90-04-41707-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-90-04-41707-6"><bdi>978-90-04-41707-6</bdi></a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OCLC_(identifier)" title="OCLC (identifier)">OCLC</a>Â <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/oclc/1170143447" rel="nofollow">1170143447</a>. <q>Following the destruction of Jerusalem by the Romans in 70 CE, a new era began in the city's history. The Herodian city was destroyed and a military camp of the Tenth Roman Legion established on part of the ruins. In around 130 CE, the Roman emperor Hadrian founded a new city in place of Herodian Jerusalem next to the military camp. He honored the city with the status of a colony and named it Aelia Capitolina.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Aelia+Capitolina+-+Jerusalem+in+the+Roman+period%3A+in+light+of+archaeological+research&amp;rft.pages=3&amp;rft.date=2019-12-16&amp;rft_id=info%3Aoclcnum%2F1170143447&amp;rft.isbn=978-90-04-41707-6&amp;rft.aulast=Weksler-Bdolah&amp;rft.aufirst=Shlomit&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fworldcat.org%2Foclc%2F1170143447&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJerusalem"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-:1-146"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-:1_146-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFGoodman2008">Goodman, Martin (2008). <a class="external text" href="http://worldcat.org/oclc/1016414322" rel="nofollow"><i>Rome and Jerusalem: The Clash of Ancient Civilizations</i></a>. Penguin. p.Â 25. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>Â <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-14-029127-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-14-029127-8"><bdi>978-0-14-029127-8</bdi></a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OCLC_(identifier)" title="OCLC (identifier)">OCLC</a>Â <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/oclc/1016414322" rel="nofollow">1016414322</a>. <q>The capitulation of the rest of Jerusalem was rapid. Those parts of the lower city already under Roman control were deliberately set on fire. The erection of new towers to break down the walls of the upper city was completed on 7 Elul (in mid-August), and the troops forced their way in. By 8 Elul the whole city was in Roman handsâand in ruins. In recompense for the ferocious fighting they had been required to endure, the soldiers were given free rein to loot and kill, until eventually Titus ordered that the city be razed to the ground, âleaving only the loftiest of the towers, Phasael, Hippicus and Mariamme, and the portion of the wall enclosing the city on the west: the latter as an encampment for the garrison that was to remain, and the towers to indicate to posterity the nature of the city and of the strong defences which had yet yielded to Roman prowess. All the rest of the wall encompassing the city was so completely levelled to the ground as to leave future visitors to the spot no ground for believing that it had ever been inhabited.â</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Rome+and+Jerusalem%3A+The+Clash+of+Ancient+Civilizations&amp;rft.pages=25&amp;rft.pub=Penguin&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft_id=info%3Aoclcnum%2F1016414322&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-14-029127-8&amp;rft.aulast=Goodman&amp;rft.aufirst=Martin&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fworldcat.org%2Foclc%2F1016414322&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJerusalem"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-:2-147"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-:2_147-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFBen-AmiTchekhanovets2011">Ben-Ami, Doron; Tchekhanovets, Yana (2011). <a class="external text" href="https://dx.doi.org/10.5615/bullamerschoorie.364.0061" rel="nofollow">"The Lower City of Jerusalem on the Eve of Its Destruction, 70 CE: A View From Hanyon Givati"</a>. <i>Bulletin of the American Schools of Oriental Research</i>. <b>364</b>: 61â85. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.5615%2Fbullamerschoorie.364.0061" rel="nofollow">10.5615/bullamerschoorie.364.0061</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>Â <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/0003-097X" rel="nofollow">0003-097X</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a>Â <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:164199980" rel="nofollow">164199980</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Bulletin+of+the+American+Schools+of+Oriental+Research&amp;rft.atitle=The+Lower+City+of+Jerusalem+on+the+Eve+of+Its+Destruction%2C+70+CE%3A+A+View+From+Hanyon+Givati&amp;rft.volume=364&amp;rft.pages=61-85&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A164199980%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft.issn=0003-097X&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.5615%2Fbullamerschoorie.364.0061&amp;rft.aulast=Ben-Ami&amp;rft.aufirst=Doron&amp;rft.au=Tchekhanovets%2C+Yana&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fdx.doi.org%2F10.5615%2Fbullamerschoorie.364.0061&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJerusalem"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-:3-148"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-:3_148-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFR.2011">R., Jones, Kenneth (2011). <a class="external text" href="http://worldcat.org/oclc/787865898" rel="nofollow"><i>Jewish reactions to the destruction of Jerusalem in A.D. 70Â : Apocalypses and related Pseudepigrapha</i></a>. Brill, 1995, pp. 249â270. p. 249. They were known as <i>avelei Èion</i> (Mourners of Zion) or <i>Shoshanim</i> (Lilies(among the thorns))</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-183"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-183">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Adrian J. Boas, <i>Jerusalem in the Time of the Crusades</i>, Routledge 2001, pp. 14, 35.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-184"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-184">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFHull1999">Hull, Michael D. <li id="cite_note-Addington01a-188"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Addington01a_188-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFLarry_H._Addington1990"><a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Larry_H._Addington&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Larry H. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">30 May</span> 2014</span>. <q>in the Sixth Crusade, Frederick II ...concluded a treaty with the Saracens in 1229 that placed Jerusalem under Christian control but allowed Muslim and Christian alike freedom of access to the religious shrines of the city. ... Within fifteen years of Frederick's departure from the Holy Land, the Khwarisimian Turks, successors to the Seljuks, rampaged through Syria and Palestine, capturing Jerusalem in 1244. (Jerusalem would not be ruled again by Christians until the British occupied it in December 1917, during World War I).</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Patterns+of+War+Through+the+Eighteenth+Century&amp;rft.series=Midland+book&amp;rft.pages=59&amp;rft.pub=Indiana+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1990&amp;rft.isbn=978-0253205513&amp;rft.au=Larry+H.+Addington&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D4CBEesvW2okC%26pg%3DPA59&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJerusalem"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-hujiOttoman-201"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-hujiOttoman_201-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-hujiOttoman_201-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20091231040026/http://jeru.huji.ac.il/eh1.htm" rel="nofollow">"The Ottoman Period (1517â1917 CE)"</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hebrew_University" title="Hebrew University">Hebrew University</a>. 2002. <li id="cite_note-208"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-208">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFJankowski1997">Jankowski, James P. </li>
<li id="cite_note-210"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-210">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFJaffe1983">Jaffe, Eliezer David (1983). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=eLgOAAAAQAAJ&amp;pg=PA3" rel="nofollow"><i>Israelis in Institutions: Studies in child placement, practice, and policy</i></a>. Taylor &amp; Francis. p.Â 3. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>Â <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-677-05960-4" title="Special:BookSources/0-677-05960-4"><bdi>0-677-05960-4</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Israelis+in+Institutions%3A+Studies+in+child+placement%2C+practice%2C+and+policy&amp;rft.pages=3&amp;rft.pub=Taylor+%26+Francis&amp;rft.date=1983&amp;rft.isbn=0-677-05960-4&amp;rft.aulast=Jaffe&amp;rft.aufirst=Eliezer+David&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DeLgOAAAAQAAJ%26pg%3DPA3&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJerusalem"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-211"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-211">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Elisha Efrat and Allen G. Noble, <a class="external text" href="https://www.jstor.org/stable/215090" rel="nofollow">Planning Jerusalem</a>, Geographical Review, Vol. 78, No. 4 (Oct., 1988), pp. 387-404: "Modern planning began only after the British conquest of Palestine in World War Iâ¦ In 1918 an engineer from Alexandria, William McLean, was commissioned to draft the first city planâ¦ These provisionsâ¦ caused the city to develop mainly to the west and southwest because of the restrictions on construction in the Old City and its immediate environs and the desire to retain the eastern skylineâ¦ McLean wanted Jerusalem to expand to the north, west, and south, with little development to the east because of climatic and topographical limitations. Thus almost from the onset of British colonial rule, development was encouraged in a generally westward direction, and this bias ultimately produced the initial contrasts that distinguished the eastern and western sectors of the city. McLean also adopted the principle of urban dispersal, and he proposed two main axes, one to the northwest and the other to the southwest of the Old City. His guidelines were repeated in most of the subsequent city plans."</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-lapidoth-220"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-lapidoth_220-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-lapidoth_220-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFLapidoth1998">Lapidoth, Ruth (30 June 1998). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130402044938/http://www.israel-mfa.gov.il/mfa/peace%2Bprocess/guide%2Bto%2Bthe%2Bpeace%2Bprocess/jerusalem-%2Blegal%2Band%2Bpolitical%2Bbackground" rel="nofollow">"Jerusalem: Legal and Political Background"</a>. <li id="cite_note-263"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-263">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFMÃ¸ller,_BjÃ¸rn2002">MÃ¸ller, BjÃ¸rn (November 2002). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20040106192631/http://shop.ceps.be/downfree.php?item_id=171" rel="nofollow">"A Cooperative Structure for IsraeliâPalestinian Relations: Working Paper No. 1"</a>. <i>Centre for European Policy Studies</i>. <li id="cite_note-265"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-265">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Bard, Mitchell G. <i>Will Israel Survive?</i></span>

<li id="cite_note-266"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-266">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="https://berkleycenter.georgetown.edu/essays/the-controversial-sovereignty-over-the-city-of-jerusalem" rel="nofollow">The Controversial Sovereignty over the City of Jerusalem (22 June 2015, The National Catholic Reporter)</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20181121191334/https://berkleycenter.georgetown.edu/essays/the-controversial-sovereignty-over-the-city-of-jerusalem" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 21 November 2018 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a> "No U.S. president has ever officially acknowledged Israeli sovereignty over any part of Jerusalem (...) The refusal to recognize Jerusalem as Israeli territory is a near universal policy among Western nations."</span>

<li id="cite_note-267"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-267">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-42218042" rel="nofollow">Jerusalem: Opposition to mooted Trump Israel announcement grows</a>"Israeli sovereignty over Jerusalem has never been recognised internationally"</span>

<li id="cite_note-268"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-268">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Whither Jerusalem (Lapidot) page 17: "Israeli control in west Jerusalem since 1948 was illegal and most states have not recognized its sovereignty there"</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-269"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-269">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Law" title="Jerusalem Law">Jerusalem Law</a> states that "Jerusalem, complete and united, is the capital of Israel" and the city serves as the seat of the government, home to the President's residence, government offices, supreme court, and <a href="/wiki/Knesset" title="Knesset">parliament</a>. <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_478" title="United Nations Security Council Resolution 478">United Nations Security Council Resolution 478</a> (20 August 1980; 14â0, U.S. abstaining) declared the Jerusalem Law "null and void" and called on member states to withdraw their diplomatic missions from Jerusalem (see <a href="#CITEREFKellerman1993">Kellerman 1993</a>, p.Â 140<span class="error harv-error" style="display: none; font-size:100%"> harvnb error: no target: CITEREFKellerman1993 (<a href="/wiki/Category:Harv_and_Sfn_template_errors" title="Category:Harv and Sfn template errors">help</a>)</span>). See <a href="/wiki/Status_of_Jerusalem" title="Status of Jerusalem">Status of Jerusalem</a> for more information.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-270"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-270">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"UN General Assembly Resolution 181 recommended the creation of an international zonea, orÂ corpus separatum, in Jerusalem to be administered by the UN for a 10-year period, after which there would be referendum to determine its future.Â This approach applies equally to West and East Jerusalem and is not affected by the occupation of East jerusalem in 1967.Â To a large extent it is this approach that still guides the diplomatic behaviour of states and thus has greater force in international law" (Susan M. Akram, Michael Dumper, Michael Lynk, Iain Scobbie (eds.),Â International Law and the Israeli-Palestinian Conflict: A Rights-Based Approach to Middle East Peace,Â Routledge, 2010 p.119. )</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-274"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-274">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20090930193650/http://www.nybooks.com/articles/14529" rel="nofollow">"Camp David: An Exchange"</a>. <i>The New York Review of Books</i>. 20 September 2001. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">7 December</span> 2012</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+York+Review+of+Books&amp;rft.atitle=Camp+David%3A+An+Exchange&amp;rft.date=2001-09-20&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nybooks.com%2Farticles%2F14529&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJerusalem"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-PalestinianPosition-275"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-PalestinianPosition_275-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-PalestinianPosition_275-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">In the <a href="/wiki/Palestine_Liberation_Organization" title="Palestine Liberation Organization">Palestine Liberation Organization</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Palestinian Declaration of Independence">Palestinian Declaration of Independence</a> of 1988, Jerusalem is stated to be the capital of the State of Palestine. In 1997, the <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_Legislative_Council" title="Palestinian Legislative Council">Palestinian Legislative Council</a> passed the Palestinian <i>Basic Law</i> (ratified by Chairman <a href="/wiki/Yasser_Arafat" title="Yasser Arafat">Yasser Arafat</a> in 2002), designating the city as such. Article 3: <i>"Jerusalem is the capital of Palestine."</i><br/>
See <a class="external text" href="http://www.palestinianbasiclaw.org/basic-law/2003-amended-basic-law" rel="nofollow"><i>2003 Amended Basic Law</i></a>. Retrieved 2 June 2013; <a class="external text" href="http://english.people.com.cn/200210/06/eng20021006_104530.shtml" rel="nofollow">Arafat Signs Law Making Jerusalem Palestinian Capital</a>, People's Daily, published 6 October 2002; <a class="external text" href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/2302961.stm" rel="nofollow">Arafat names Jerusalem as capital</a>, BBC News, published 6 October 2002.</span>
</li>

Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2 April</span> 2007</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Basic+Law%3A+Jerusalem%2C+Capital+of+Israel&amp;rft.pub=Israel+Ministry+of+Foreign+Affairs&amp;rft.date=1980-07-30&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mfa.gov.il%2FMFA%2FMFAArchive%2F1980_1989%2FBasic%2520Law-%2520Jerusalem-%2520Capital%2520of%2520Israel&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJerusalem"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-284"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-284">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20090205073441/http://daccessdds.un.org/doc/RESOLUTION/GEN/NR0/399/71/IMG/NR039971.pdf?OpenElement" rel="nofollow">"Resolution 478 (1980)"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <li id="cite_note-303"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-303">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="http://www.mid.ru/en/foreign_policy/news/-/asset_publisher/cKNonkJE02Bw/content/id/2717182" rel="nofollow">Foreign Ministry statement regarding Palestinian-Israeli settlement (6 April 2017)</a>"We reaffirm our commitment to the UN-approved principles for a Palestinian-Israeli settlement, which include the status of East Jerusalem as the capital of the future Palestinian state. <li id="cite_note-returning-371"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-returning_371-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-returning_371-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFSegal1987">Segal, Benjamin J. <li id="cite_note-372"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-372">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Jewish injunction to pray toward Jerusalem comes in the <i><a href="/wiki/Orach_Chayim" title="Orach Chayim">Orach Chayim</a></i> section of <i><a href="/wiki/Shulchan_Aruch" title="Shulchan Aruch">Shulchan Aruch</a></i> (94:1) â "When one rises to pray anywhere in the Diaspora, he should face towards the Land of Israel, directing himself also toward Jerusalem, the Temple, and the Holy of Holies."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-373"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-373">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBeckles_Willson2013">Beckles Willson, Rachel (2013). <i>Orientalism and Musical Mission: Palestine and the West</i>. <li id="cite_note-374"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-374">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">From the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Authorized_King_James_Version" title="Authorized King James Version">King James Version of the Bible</a>: "And when the days of her purification according to the law of Moses were accomplished, they brought [Jesus] to Jerusalem, to present him to the Lord;" (<a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Luke" title="Gospel of Luke">Luke</a> 2:22)</span>

<li id="cite_note-376"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-376">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBoas2001">Boas, Adrian J. </li>
<li id="cite_note-377"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-377">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFEndo1999"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shusaku_Endo" title="Shusaku Endo">Endo, Shusaku</a> (1999). Paulist Press. p.Â 116. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>Â <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-8091-2319-3" title="Special:BookSources/0-8091-2319-3"><bdi>0-8091-2319-3</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+Life+of+Jesus&amp;rft.pages=116&amp;rft.pub=Paulist+Press&amp;rft.date=1999&amp;rft.isbn=0-8091-2319-3&amp;rft.aulast=Endo&amp;rft.aufirst=Shusaku&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJerusalem"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-378"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-378">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">From the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Authorized_King_James_Version" title="Authorized King James Version">King James Version of the Bible</a>: "This title then read many of the Jews: for the place where Jesus was crucified was nigh to the city: and it was written in Hebrew, and Greek, and Latin." <li id="cite_note-388"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-388">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">From <a href="/wiki/Abdullah_Yusuf_Ali" title="Abdullah Yusuf Ali">Abdullah Yusuf Ali</a>'s English translation of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Qur%27an" title="Qur'an">Qur'an</a>: "Glory to (Allah) Who did take His servant for a Journey by night from the Sacred Mosque to the farthest Mosque, whose precincts We did bless,- in order that We might show him some of Our Signs: for He is the One Who heareth and seeth (all things)." <li id="cite_note-:8-390"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-:8_390-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1"><i>The Encyclopaedia of Islam</i>.
